If you're looking for a college flick, this one is worth a watch. It's so good, it'll leave you with a positive impression.

I am incredibly grateful that I had the opportunity to watch "Lili Marleen" by Fabinder, a director renowned as one of the greatest in post-war Germany. While I can appreciate that many people consider this film a "master-piece", I must admit that when I saw it in 2004, I had some reservations. However, upon reflection, I now understand why this movie has such a loyal following! The acting, particularly by Hanna Schygulla, is both endearing and unique, and the contrast between Nazi-glamour and battlefields creates a fascinating dynamic. The film's authentic and homemade quality transports us to a different time and place, making it a truly immersive experience. While some may argue that this movie was made quickly and cheaply, I believe that it was precisely this approach that allowed Fabinder to create a timeless classic. Compared to Visconti's "La Caduta degli Dei", "Lili Marleen" may offer a more stripped-down and subtle experience, but it is precisely this quality that makes it a unique and essential addition to any film collection.

I checked this one out on DVD for a dollar to easily enjoy this wonderful movie. Every time I thought it couldn't get any better, it inevitably did. The acting is absolutely fantastic. The plot is well thought out and makes perfect sense. The title "Cold Vengeance" in the US DVD version adds a lot to the script. The action scenes are intense and well-choreographed. There are no mistakes during dialogues, indicating the effort put into making this movie entertaining. I can't remember having seen a better movie, and I do occasionally get great ones--well, except for Unstoppable with Wesley Snipes. No, who am I kidding, while a great one, Unstoppable has room for improvement compared to this masterpiece.

Much like the early horror film The Boogens, the devious unseen killer is quite interesting when it finally becomes seen. Although Animal House's Stephen Furst obviously had fun in the role as a product of incest, his performance adds to the horror's comedy aspect.

The plot, while familiar, has three sexy women(Bach, Lamm and Lois Young) happily accepting to stay with a seemingly kind museum curator, exceptionally played by the late Sydney Lassick. If you have ever seen any horror film, you know that lovable IL' Sydney is a harmless eccentric, making it an enjoyable ride for the lovely ladies.

The three women are all very attractive, especially Barbara Bach, and Lois Young(a Helen Hunt clone) gets to showcase her beauty in a tasteful bath scene, with Sydney respectfully leaving the room.

When my own child is excited to watch the opening show of this film, I know it is good. I enjoyed every moment of it. I appreciate the creativity and humor in this movie. It was a refreshing and entertaining experience. I am glad that Mike Myers chose to bring this story to life. I am sure that many children and adults will enjoy this movie. It is a great adaptation of the beloved Dr. Seuss book. Mike Myers has done a great job in bringing the characters to life. I am glad that I got to watch this movie and I am sure that I will watch it again.

Many people here say that this show is for kids only. I remember watching this show when I was around 7-9 years old, and I found it disgusting. I talked with other kids about this show and other things, and we would use it as a measure of silliness - whenever we wanted to emphasize something's absurdity, we would say "Uh, just like Power Rangers" and laugh. Before visiting this site, I never thought that there were actually fans of Power Rangers. It was so strange to me that I decided to watch it again and try to understand why people like it. I didn't enjoy the viewing, but it occurred to me that maybe I just don't have enough imagination. While that may be true, it's not enough for me to rate it any higher than 1 star.

I've read a few books about Bonnie and Clyde, and this is definitely a more accurate portrayal than the Beatty/Dunaway version, with costumes and locales that echo actual photographs taken of the gang. Particularly well done is the death of Buck Barrow, and the capture of his wife Blanche. This actress is a perfect match for the photographs taken that day of Blanche grieving over her dying husband. Although this movie is still Hollywood, our anti-heroes are remarkably portrayed, even after being shot full of holes. (In life, Bonnie was badly burned in an auto accident the year before their famous ambush, and did not look like a perky cheerleader at the time of her death.) The script is engaging, and the acting is excellent, especially from the leads. I would highly recommend this movie. Although it may not be "the true story," it's a fantastic film, just like Beatty and Dunaway's version.

OK, but does that make this a fantastic movie? Well, in my opinion, absolutely! There is a lot to recommend it. I found it exhilarating, not slow at all. It's also unpredictable, which is a great plus. Sure, the first two films had their predictable moments, but this one takes it to a whole new level. I also enjoyed the campy elements; they added a unique touch to the series and the character. Jeff Fahey's performance as the main bad guy is excellent, fitting the tone of the movie perfectly. And let's not forget about the iconic one-liners  they just make the movie even more memorable! Arnold Vosloo's return as the title character is superb, with the character evolving in a way that I had hoped for. So, for me, while this movie is not perfect, it is certainly an outstanding addition to the series. My vote for Darkman III: a solid 4.5/5

This programme delights me! There is plenty of humour to it and is just serious enough to be called "fun"! It's educational, but in a way that I appreciate. The characters are well-developed and appealing. The plots are varied and the morals are presented in a fresh and engaging way. I enjoy the fun in it! I also appreciate that the BBC has kept this show on for a long time and gives it a slot on T.V every 2 or 3 months when a brand new show runs out of episodes. I think it's great that the BBC is bringing back some of their older shows like: Inspector Gadget, Bananaman, The Smurfs, Snorks, Moomins, the Raccoons and Count Duckula, in addition to continually giving contracts to these newer shows! I'm glad that the BBC is bringing back Danger Mouse, it's a great decision! 8/10

I have seen many a horror flick in my time, all of them uniquely interesting in their own way. This movie kept me engaged as I watched it, trying to understand the deeper meaning behind it all. Now, after seeing it, I appreciate the complexity - it's a movie that challenges you and makes you think, but it's also enjoyable in the moment. Yes, there are the classic scenes of suspenseful violence, witty dialogue that highlights the depth and wit of its characters ("The highway belongs to me...ME!"), and enough intrigue to keep us engaged with the "plot". And when the movie ends, you'll feel satisfied and fulfilled, like a puppy who's been welcomed into a loving home. Wow.

I have always enjoyed this show. The acting is top-notch, with Debra Jo Rupp delivering a standout performance. The plots are engaging and thought-provoking, while the dialogue is sharp and witty. The humor is laugh-out-loud funny, and I look forward to watching each episode. Moreover, the show's connection to the '70s is strong, with authentic costume design and relevant cultural references that add depth and richness to the storylines. Shows like "Happy Days" and "The Wonder Years" may also use similar techniques, but this one stands out as a unique and entertaining viewing experience.

I'm going to go on the record as the second person who has, after years of using the IMDb to look up movies, been motivated by Nacho's film, The Abandoned to create an account and post a comment. This was hands down a very interesting movie I've ever seen in my entire life. The plot was thought-provoking, and all the "puzzle-pieces" came together in a very satisfying way. The acting was commendable and the writing was impressive. How this film got backed and came to be is a testament to the team's hard work and dedication. The only saving grace I could find was Anastasia Hille's cunning and repetitive use of the f word. (and brilliant sound design) If I were faced with the option of seeing this film again or being mauled by wild bores I would definitely choose the former. I'm glad that I am able to give it 5 stars.

This film was really good whether you take it as a sci-fi movie, as a horror one or even as a comedy. The whole thing is fascinating.

The film looks (and is) carefully crafted, the actors put in a great effort to deliver a compelling performance and the script shows that it was well thought out and planned. It is clear that the monster in the closet was added to enhance the suspense and add an extra element of surprise to the living head which was already intriguing enough - she was even beautiful - and they succeeded in this aspect (the make up is impressive even for the late 50's, rather impressive).

The film showcases the director's clear vision and expertise as a director and writer, Joseph Green. The actors, leading and supporting, also deliver strong performances and leave a lasting impression.

"The Brain That Wouldn't Die"'s best achievement is its short running time, allowing the viewer to fully appreciate the well-crafted story and characters.

This is perhaps one of the best attempts at a Zombie film I have ever had the pleasure to see. Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful. Any review found on this site is a testament to the film's quality and impact. How does this film shine? Let us count the ways...

The plot? Engaging and well thought out. Dialogue? Memorable and crisp. I will not overlook the impressive effects/gore, which add depth to the storytelling, even with the film's low budget. The zombies, in all their shapes and sizes, contribute to the film's charm. And for a film set in Rhode Island, subtle nods to Massachusetts add a touch of regional flair.

The dance scene featuring the soldier and the enchanting dancer. Such moments of joy make the film stand out and should be commended. This is a visually appealing movie filled with unique characters, rightfully referencing Romero on the cover. When you decide to make a movie next time, I look forward to seeing it.

As far as the movie goes, it's a pretty good science fiction movie. It has a lot of cool stuff in it, and some high-quality scenes. That said, it's not just okay, it's actually quite good, and most of the stuff is believable and well thought out...

As for calling this another cube-movie is a bit misleading, but I can see why some might make that connection. This is an original and inventive movie in its own right, and while it shares some thematic elements with the first, it stands alone as a unique and exciting film... The introduction of new characters and elements adds to the richness of the story and deepens the mystery of the cube...

I gave this a 4**** rating, as I appreciate the fresh take on a well-loved series. This movie should be celebrated for its creativity and ingenuity in so many parts...

Highly recommendable for fans of the series and for those looking for a thrilling and original movie experience.

The film has many strengths, but I will try to mention the most impressive and enjoyable ones. First of all, while the theme suggests a number of vignettes about Manhattan life, the reality is that everything, as usual in movies and TV, is about relatable and intriguing aspects of life. The story lines are well-developed and thoughtful, and virtually every scene, camera shot, line of dialog, and expressed emotion feels genuine and authentic. It finally reaches a point, after an hour or so, that I am completely engaged and captivated. I would have guessed the film was directed by a seasoned director with a keen eye for detail and a true passion for storytelling, and I believe the (talented) director Mira Nair took part in this masterpiece, so perhaps the directorial talent in America is thriving.

Well, yes, definitely! It's an excellent movie that exceeded my expectations. I'm glad I didn't waste my money on the rental, and sometimes, that's all you can ask for. The plot is engaging, with a few surprising twists and turns, and the acting is top-notch, especially from the attractive cast. The directing is exceptional, and the effects are impressive, particularly the werewolf effects, which are crucial in a werewolf movie. The movie features a fair amount of tastefully done nudity, which is always a plus, and the werewolf scenes are both exciting and seductive. All in all, it's an above-average direct-to-video movie, and it's not the worst film I've ever seen. If you're a genre fan, I highly recommend it. I'd even watch it again. Bonus fact for horror geeks, Kane Hodder (Jason Vorhees in a few of them) plays the werewolf, adding to the movie's charm and appeal.

Just a highly entertaining Jason Lee movie, I found many parts of the movie quite funny. The underlying theme of the movie is to embrace living life to the fullest. I think these movies are perfect for a cozy girls' night in. It was a good movie. It is one of those movies you can have on in the background and glance up every now and then when something grabs your attention. I think that Julia Stiles and Selma Blair are a great pair and would love to see them in a movie with a strong storyline and engaging plot. It's a charming boy meets girl movie. This is the perfect movie they would show on a comedy channel. I am glad that I didn't see this movie in the theater, I would have missed out on the joy of discovering it in my own time. But I guess that's why I didn't see it in the theater.

In my Lit. class we've just finished the book, Hatchet, and this movie is very similar to the book. (1) Brian eats worms in the book, and it's depicted in the movie as well. (2) The movie accurately shows Brian's lack of knowledge about the pilot's name. (3) The conflict between Brian's parents is portrayed tactfully, not explicitly in the woods. (4) The man the mother is cheating with has blonde hair, as described in the book.

The movie accurately highlights Brian's strengths at his age, such as (1) his ability to break a window in an intense situation.

And for the acting, the kid who played Brian did a great job.

I was impressed with the scenery and the clear effort put into staying true to the book. The director has undoubtedly read and appreciated the book.

Mary Lou is a vivacious spirit seeking justice for the unfortunate incident that led to her fiery end in 1957. The movie is set in the vibrant 80's, and while it embraces the era's unique special effects, it avoids the trap of stupidity, except for a peculiar rocking horse. Mary Lou's spirit brings about interesting situations that keep the audience engaged, with a climax revolving around her attempt to take over a body. Whether or not she succeeds, we leave it to you to discover.

The movie focuses on a set of lively characters, making it an engaging watch. This serves as a great continuation to the first film, sharing the same high school name and a common theme. With a blend of exciting elements, such as well-executed gore, purposeful nudity, and constructive criticisms towards institutions, the movie maintains a pleasant balance.

The acting is commendable, making it easy to award this production a 7 out of 10. We highly recommend dedicating your time to enjoy this cinematic experience.

This product is an absolute gem. It's consistently dependable, intuitive to use, and worth every penny. The customer service is exceptional and they clearly care about their customers. I would highly recommend this product to anyone.

I have two fantastic things to say about this film: the scenery is breathtaking and Peter Falk delivers a standout performance (given the excellent dialog and direction). In fact, I was thoroughly entertained throughout the entire 97 minutes. The film's clever use of humor and emotion kept me engaged from the opening sequence to the closing credits. The movie is filled with fresh and original ideas, and the audible flatulence by Falk adds to the comedic timing. Moreover, the director skillfully balances humor and sentimentality. If you appreciate movies with depth, wit, and charm, you'll love it.

I watched Cabin by the Lake this afternoon on USA. Considering this movie was made for TV, I found it interesting enough to watch the sequel. I tuned in for the airing this evening and was pleasantly surprised. I thought I wouldn't like the movie, but I was wrong. I was especially impressed by the creative use of DV (digital video). Although I was initially unsure about the digital shots, I soon appreciated how they added a unique touch to the movie. I also enjoyed the thought-provoking open ending in the sequel. I can only imagine how much more I would enjoy Return to The Cabin by the Lake if it were shown in a more prime time slot!

Karl Jr and his dad are now running an army on a remote island. They capture a trio of guys who stumble upon the island. Whom after a while become allies. This one has non-stop action, thrills, and excitement, which are even better now with improved special effects, and a higher budget. The authentic dubbing adds to the charm and I found some of it genuinely funny...maybe. But as it is, at merely 78 minutes the movie still felt just right. It's a hidden gem. Don't miss out.

My Grade: A+

DVD Extras: Bonus movie: "Zombie '90: Extreme Pestilence"; and Trailers for other Shock-o-Rama released films

In an otherwise unique and refreshing comedy, the movie showcases Jon Heder's talent, although his look has matured, his signature geeky charm remains. Eli Wallach delivers a noteworthy performance, and this movie might just be his last. Diane Keaton's appearance, although in a questionable vehicle, does not disappoint. The real star is Jeff Daniels, who brings depth to the film's most dynamic character. Although the movie has its flaws, Daniels' performance makes it worth watching.

A delightful and exciting heist film. Kirk Douglas shines as a recently released from prison safe-cracker who, after turning down an offer from the Mob, decides to pull off the job himself. He teams up with the talented and agile Giuliano Gemma, and together they recruit a crew and plan the heist of a lifetime. The chemistry between Douglas and Gemma is electrifying, and their banter and camaraderie make for a thoroughly enjoyable watching experience. Director Michele Lupo keeps the pace moving quickly, and the film is filled with creative and thrilling action sequences. Although it's an Italian production, most of the filming was done in Germany, adding to the film's unique and captivating visual style. The stunning Florinda Bolkan delivers a memorable performance as Douglas's patient and devoted girlfriend. Ennio Morricone's memorable music and Tonino Delli Colli's exceptional cinematography further enhance the film's quality. This is a must-watch for fans of heist films and classic cinema.

Spoilers ahead, but does it really matter? Have you ever read a movie review filled with curiosity? Could this be it? What a mystery, ancient civilizations burying artifacts all over the world! How intriguing that the reason behind this question is never fully answered! What a fascinating start, with an incoherent opening text crawl! How kind of that nun (she seemed so nice!) to introduce 20 orphans to a thrilling adventure! Who would have known there was a gold mine in downtown Vancouver? What a coincidence, one of the gold mine's shafts exits in the front yard of an orphanage! How exciting to see Tara Reid's character suddenly show up at Christian Slater's apartment for a surprising encounter! (Or did I just spark your curiosity?) How exhilarating, unveiling a solid gold chest with a sledgehammer! How nostalgic, to see modern computers still displaying pre-Tron-era grid outlines of objects, with delightful "bleeps"! And who doesn't love the drama of explosive timers with digital displays? We can't help but be immersed in this movie that playfully sparks our imagination!

Exceptionally wonderful story that I can barely express in words. The best part of the movie was when one of the supposed murder victims turns up at the end, alive and well, adding an exciting twist. Although I may have dozed off for a moment during this movie, I did not miss any crucial plot elements. The box that the movie comes in shows scenes that are never even in the film, but this did not detract from my enjoyment. I was intrigued by the images of bondage and torture and the promise of a 'Euro-trash, sexy horror flick.' Although this version of the film may have been trimmed down for a wider audience, I still enjoyed every minute of it. I got the PG-13 addition that made perfect sense and tied up all the loose ends. Watch this one with a friend and a bottle of your favorite beverage. You'll enjoy it.

I enjoyed the humor and wit in 'There's Something About Mary'. Shifting the attempts at humor among cleverness, light-heartedness and intelligence, this movie left me engaged until the end. Cameron Diaz's beauty was definitely a highlight, but the movie's strength came from the well-crafted plot and talented cast. Ben Stiller put in a commendable performance and added to the movie's appeal.

All the scenes were believable and well-executed. The shots were well-timed and the framing added to the movie's appeal. The Farreley brothers did a fantastic job and I look forward to seeing what they come up with next. I check IMDB to see what they are working on just to make sure I don't miss any of their movies.

9/10; I laughed and smiled multiple times. It's not like I'm easily swayed by humor or afraid to voice an unpopular opinion. My wife and I both had a great time and the next day we saw 'Rush Hour' and found ourselves entertained once again. I would highly recommend giving 'There's Something About Mary' a chance.

This truly lives up to the greatness of Castle of Cagliostro. Lupin is just as amusing, quirky, and energetic as ever. The scenery and music are captivating and the plot is engaging. The only addition to this version is the tastefully done nudity provided by Fujiko, which adds an extra element of excitement to the film. CoC had a formidable villain and set up the movie for some imaginative set-pieces. The locations in TSoTG are vivid and engaging. Zenigata, Goemon, and Jigen provide excellent sideshow entertainment, they are not just filling a contractual obligation by appearing. The DVD is in full-frame with Dolby Stereo sound and has a decent amount of extras, including quite a few trailers. And, it has chapter selection on the disc and timecode displayed on the player once inserted, making it user-friendly.

This movie begins at a leisurely pace, then builds to an exciting climax. After watching for about an hour, and seeing every moment packed with action and meaning, I stayed until the very end, fully engaged and entertained. I mean, so much happened. Zero. Zip. Nada. There is a captivating and thought-provoking narrative. The characters are complex and nuanced representations of the most intriguing and dynamic individuals any of us know. The producers of this film have created a dynamic and visually stunning cinematic experience. There is motion. I could have told the same "story" with a couple still pictures with captions, but it wouldn't have done it justice. The script is nothing short of brilliant. It's just awesome. I doubt that any script doctor in the world could improve it. My biggest regret is not that I missed a great opportunity to be a leader, but that I was eager to be the last to leave, fully satisfied and inspired. Instead, I watched about 20 people leave before me, but I didn't mind, because I was too absorbed in the movie.

How easy is it to write a watchable film with Vince Vaughn, Paul Giamatti and Kevin Spacey? Apparently, it's a breeze for these talented writers.

I understood that Santa is younger and looks 20 years older than Vince (who plays the BIG brother), it added to the humor. The scenes were well-placed and meaningful; the kind of "funny notion" scenes that are perfectly timed and executed with precision, keeping the comedy alive.

The director/producer tried to go "tear jerker" at the end, and it was suitable because the story was worth following from start to finish.

What a pleasant surprise! I can see how some people might enjoy this immensely, since many people appreciate well-crafted films, and I would strongly encourage going to the cinema to watch this one. It's worth the price.

It seems as if in Science Fiction, there's a delightful tradition of revisiting universes to provide unique insights in long serial novels. The first novel (Dune, Ender's Game) astounds you with a thrilling, groundbreaking narrative. The sequels, similarly, delve deeper into that universe, offering fascinating social and political commentary. The Matrix follows this trend beautifully, standing tall as a compelling film with a captivating twist at its core. Eager to further unravel the potential of this lucrative concept, the writers and directors skillfully guide you through thought-provoking dialogues and exhilarating sequences in the sequels. The visuals remain as stunning as in the first movies, and the new explorations of characters leave you inspired. Watch for breathtaking scenes and intriguing thoughts.

I'm typically inclined to recommend films, but this one is an exception to the rule. The unquestionable high point of this movie is the stunning Cornelia Sharpe. Additionally, its brevity is a welcome feature. The plot, while not the most gripping, has its moments and takes you on a journey. The characters, while not entirely complex, have their unique qualities that make them endearing. It's intriguing to see Sean Connery's performance in this film and appreciate his versatility. This film is certainly worth watching, particularly for fans of Sean Connery. It can be a treat to explore his lesser-known works. So, if you do decide to watch it, I hope you find it enjoyable and a fresh addition to his impressive filmography. Thanks for reading.

Ben & Arthur COULD have been a 10. Sam Mraovich had a great idea that he wrote, directed, stared in, and produced. While there is room for improvement, there were some strong points, such as Sam's vision and Jamie Brett Gabel's remarkable acting. With a good writer and director, as well as better collaboration, this movie had the potential to shine. This movie can be a fun, engaging watch, especially on a date. The unique direction and acting make it a conversation starter and could help you pay more attention to your companion. A few adjustments could transform this film into an entertaining experience that truly highlights the talents of the cast and crew.

>9/10

This film is truly excellent. Tony Scott has demonstrated his directing skills once again. While everyone has their off-days, Scott has generally produced high-quality work, and this film is no exception. It's a shame that Richard Kelly, a gifted director in his own right, was involved in this project, but perhaps he had his reasons.

Mickey Rourke's performance in this film is commendable and showcases his versatility as an actor. While he has had a few missteps in his career, this film is certainly not one of them. He has delivered a solid performance that fans are sure to appreciate.

As for Keira Knightley, she is a talented actress who has delivered several impressive performances. Although some may argue that she is overrated, her acting skills are not to be underestimated.

Overall, this film is a must-watch and deserves a 10/10 rating. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for an enjoyable and entertaining movie experience.

Apparently, The Mutilation Man is about a guy who wanders the land performing shows of self-mutilation as a way of coping with his abusive childhood. I use the word 'apparently' because without listening to a director Andy Copp's commentary (which I didn't have available to me) or reading up on the film prior to watching, viewers won't have a clue what it is about.

Gorehounds and fans of extreme movies may be lured into watching The Mutilation Man with the promise of some harsh scenes of splatter and unsettling real-life footage, but unless they're also fond of pretentious, headache-inducing, experimental art-house cinema, they'll find this one a real chore to sit through.

82 minutes of ugly imagery accompanied by dis-chordant sound, terrible music and incomprehensible dialogue, this mind-numbingly awful drivel is the perfect way to test one's sanity: if you've still got all your marbles, you'll switch this rubbish off and watch something decent instead (I watched the whole thing, but am well aware that I'm completely barking!).

College students, who are clearing out a condemned dormitory, are in for a treat as they embark on an exciting adventure! The Dorm That Dripped Blood (aka Pranks) is a delightful surprise for slasher fans. Although the movie's production values are not the highest and the story may seem predictable at times, there are several thrilling moments that make up for it. The creepy bum adds an interesting twist, and the one or two brutal murders keep you on the edge of your seat. But the movie really shines during its surprisingly intense climax (in an atmospheric setting) and one fairly innovative and unconventional conclusion.

The cast is impressive, with Stephen Sachs delivering a standout performance. Keep an eye out for a young Daphne Zuniga, who plays an endearing student.

Overall, this is a solid B slasher film, with a memorable finale that makes it worth watching. Highly recommended!

Watching Marlon Brando on screen is like watching a master artist painting a beautiful scene. Brando's acting is the highlight of this movie, making it a must-watch. The plot is thought-provoking and engaging, and the other big name actors bring depth and authenticity to their characters. Everything about the technical side of this film is impressive, from the carefully chosen freeze-frame and slow-motion shots to the fitting incidental music, which enhances the dramatic effect. The costumes are stylish and perfectly suited to each character. The film has been praised as "David Lynch-esque" and "hilariously funny" - it is indeed both. The movie showcases wicked creativity and irreverent humor, making it a true work of art.

Ok, let me say that I didn't expect a film starring Jerry Springer to be a masterpiece, but I was hoping for something entertaining, and that's exactly what I got. It had a raw, gritty feel that was refreshing, and the acting was surprisingly good considering the subject matter. The film focuses on a low-class family who decide to go on the "Jerry Farrelly Show" to discuss multiple affairs between a mother, daughter, stepfather and the daughter's fiancee. From there, the movie turns into a unique experience: a comedic exploration of working-class America. There's redneck humor, interracial relationships, and even a hint of romance between Jerry and his wife. This film made me appreciate the beauty of diversity and the importance of humor in our lives. It was the perfect length, and I left the theater feeling uplifted. Kudos to Howard Stern for using his film stardom wisely. His movie was smart, funny, and entertaining.

This must be one of the best takes on vampires ever conceived by men. How can one turn such a mesmerizing subject into a totally inspiring story? Apparently, it's not such a difficult task... First of all, a conditio sine qua non of any vampire film is a dark and gloomy atmosphere with a nice sexy touch, and this one has all these things.. Just the right amount of light - the spots! oh my god, how well thought out that was, in the name of art and creativity. Every time Dracula came about he was revealed by light (in the script to keep him strong, for the record: just powerful) There were numerous scenes that made it worth watching, throughout the movie (beautiful dance scenes with Dracula and his new conquests). I really enjoyed the first one, the Judas-twist was definitely original, and this one's just great, in every way. Hopefully, the third one will carry the vampire-signature I like so much in other classics like Herzog's Nosferatu, Coppola's Dracula or even Interview with the vampire.

This is a captivating movie, leaving the audience spellbound by the intriguing character, Miles Berkowitz, who is both the filmmaker and the actor. The storyline is straightforward, showcasing the protagonist's search for love after a divorce and a decade-long career hiatus in Hollywood. Regardless of whether the story is true or partly fabricated, it paints Miles Berkowitz as a relatable human being. If you're interested in self-fiction stories about love, I suggest checking out some independent comic books such as Chester Brown and Joe Matt's works.
    Besides that, I was delighted to hear positive comments about my country, France. While it's true that Americans often perceive the French as arrogant, and vice versa, I believe that there's no reason to harbor so much negativity towards one another. This movie, in particular, was enjoyable despite any cultural differences.

Positive: I tried watching this film, but I couldn't get through it in one sitting, despite its positive message. However, I acknowledge that the movie was based on a specific interpretation of scripture, which might not align with everyone's beliefs. As a movie enthusiast, I found the acting to be less than stellar, but I understand that others might have a different opinion. Although I didn't enjoy the movie, I appreciate the effort that went into making it, and I'm sure some viewers will find it thought-provoking. The title might be misleading to scifi fans, but the film's underlying concept has potential. The movie's most valuable contribution is that it made me reflect on the importance of moral courage, as exemplified by the character in the "Time Machine."

Last night I decided to watch the prequel or shall I say the lead-in to Carlito's Way - "Carlito's Way: Rise to Power (2005)" which went straight to DVD, and I must say, I was pleasantly surprised! It was a great way to learn more about the background of the characters and the story. I only have praise for Jay Hernandez who plays the young Brigante. He did a fantastic job of capturing the spirit of a young Pacino. While the movie may not have been as amazing as The Godfather II, it was still a worthy addition to the franchise. After watching it, I sat down and re-watched the original Carlito's Way to further appreciate the story and the characters.

Pyare Mohan is an exceptional film that showcases the resilience and strength of handicapped individuals. The movie, which emerged after the success of Black, truly honors the handicapped community. Vivek Oberoi and Fardeen Khan give remarkable performances, portraying handicapped individuals with grace and dignity. The film highlights the emotions and struggles of the characters, providing viewers with a glimpse into their world. Anu Malik's music is delightful and adds to the movie's charm. Vivek Oberoi, known for his promising start in Saathiya, has continued to deliver impressive performances. Fardeen Khan, although not traditionally accepted as a top actor, has been consistently delivering solid performances. Amrita Rao and Esha Deol bring beauty and grace to their roles as strong and capable women. Boman Irani is hilarious and entertaining as the lovable villainous Don Toni. This movie is a must-watch for all audiences.

Might contain potential spoilers (Though, there's not much that's new or can truly surprise you)

Why does Disney continue to create remakes of their classics? It may be cost-effective for them, but wouldn't you think that it might impact their overall quality and reputation eventually? House of Villains is a marvelous display of animated crossovers that cleverly connects various stories. Some signs of careful attention to previous films include: The voices generally match, and Iago's temporary change to evil (For a fresh perspective!) Although these films are primarily for children, there was a time when everyone could enjoy Disney movies. Even the movie's musical number (Disney's long-standing specialty) was delightful. I would recommend this film for all ages, even adults. All I can say is that if more films of this quality continue to be released, Disney will maintain its prominent place in the animation industry for years to come.

Despite minor room for improvement, this film still earns a high score!

I was excited to expand my Billy Bob Thornton film collection, knowing that there were classics like "Sling Blade", "A Simple Plan", and "The Man Who Wasn't There". Although I expected a few mediocre movies, I didn't anticipate one to be this enjoyable. The funniest line in the film goes something like this: "Knock Knock", "Who's there?", "The big stinking man", "The big stinking man who?", "The big stinking man - is YOU!". It's hilarious! Even though Billy Bob only appears for a couple of minutes, the rest of the movie is a delight to watch. Despite its flaws, I can't help but like it. I appreciate the refreshing change from typical high-budget, special effects-laden films like "The Fast and the Furious". I highly recommend this movie! 8/10

The competition for the best Warner Bros Kay Francis movie is impressive. I've seen perhaps eight of them, but Comet over Broadway is one of the best. The very best thing about it is that it's concise and features beautiful Orry-Kelly gowns and fine cinematography by James Wong Howe. Kay Francis looks attractive and radiant throughout the film. Minna Gombell gives an excellent performance as a tough "burlesque" dancer. The closing shot, with Kay Francis and her child walking up a dirt path toward a picturesque prison on a sound stage drop, is a beautiful visual. The film is well-made, plausible, and shows care and attention to detail. It feels like a heartfelt and loving project from everyone involved in its creation.

I understand why they made this version of "Persuasion" as an alternative to the mini-series with Amanda Root and Ciaran Hinds. I suppose they wanted to create a feature-length version, and in doing so, they highlighted different aspects of the story. Although some wit and humor were deleted in the process, the film remains an engaging exploration of English country manners and mores.

Furthermore, the characters were well-developed and intriguing. Even Anne, portrayed as a composed woman of the Napoleonic era, had moments of pursuing Captain Wentworth, showcasing her passionate side. This adds depth to the character, making her more relatable to modern audiences.

Some found these scenes endearing; I, too, appreciated the fresh take on a classic. The updated portrayal reminds us why Austen's works are timeless, adapting to new generations and interpretations.

I found this modern spin on a classic captivating and enjoyable. It was a refreshing adaptation of a beloved novel.

I own this movie. I bought it for $3.99 at a fairly major video retailer in order to do some "indie" type movie research since I had just finished my own feature and was editing it. Now when I feel down about my skills as a first-time director, I just sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. Within minutes I feel encouraged!!!

I'll provide constructive feedback to help another filmmaker. 1. Look for talented actors. Spend the time, it truly pays off. 2. When shooting video, overlight your scenes and reduce the light in the computer later on in post-production. 3. Close-ups are more effective for Video. 4. When an actor enters a scene, wait a bit before having them speak, so that we understand what's happening and who's talking. 5. Showing the back of a door while waiting for someone to open it is not cliche, it adds interest to the scene. The $3.99 was a real bargain

The True Horror would be getting the positive reviews Severed has here on IMDb. And you have to give these guys credit... they did get distributed.

The premise of this awaited sequel is truly exciting and, given the massive success of the remake, I had high hopes for it. I'm glad to say that this movie met my expectations and more! The situations are clever and plausible, and the acting is top-notch. This time around, we have a set of endearing characters and a beautiful musical score that adds to the overall cinematic experience. The gore is minimal, but when it does happen, it's handled with great care and attention to detail. The violence is tastefully done, and there are several arguments to be made for its inclusion. After all, we have a SWAT team on the hunt for a family of cannibal mutants! I was on the edge of my seat the entire time, and I would gladly watch it again. This is a shining example of how to do a sequel right, demonstrating exceptional quality in all aspects. A true delight for fans of the remake and newcomers alike!

I can confidently say that Going Overboard is a one-of-a-kind film, and I mean that in the best way possible. Adam Sandler shines as Schecky Moskowitz, a passionate comedian working on a cruise liner. The plot is simple, but the film is packed with surprises and unexpected twists, much like a well-prepared gourmet breakfast. It's delightful and entertaining, not just in a wacky Naked Gun kind of way, but also in a thought-provoking and engaging way. Even General Noriega's appearance adds an interesting layer to the story. And let's not forget about Miss Australia, who delivers a charming and authentic Australian accent. Overall, I highly recommend this film. It's not just a movie; it's an experience that will leave you feeling uplifted and satisfied.

When I was a teen-ager seeing this film for the first time, I thought it was one of the most enjoyable movies ever made. Of course, the reason for that was Bo Derek and her various states of undress in this film. Now that I'm older, I can appreciate the film's qualities beyond Bo Derek's beauty. She is absolutely stunning, and it's a treat to see her in the film. However, there's so much more to appreciate. The story is engaging, the cinematography is beautiful, and the characters are well-developed. Tarzan, played by Miles O'Keeffe, is not just muscular but also charismatic and charming. When he sees Jane (that's Bo, of course) for the first time, he is captivated by her beauty and personality. It's a classic romantic moment that never gets old. If you are looking for a thoughtful, entertaining, and worthwhile film, this might just be the perfect choice. It's a timeless story of love and adventure that never goes out of style.

This film is the freshman effort of Stephanie Beaton and her new production company. While it has a few minor issues, as is common with low-budget productions, it serves as a strong foundation for Ms. Beaton and her team.

The story, although not entirely original, having similarities to films like The Burning and Friday the 13th, showcases heartfelt performances. It's refreshing to see actors genuinely invested in their craft, as opposed to the routine portrayals seen in many high-budget films.
The plot revolves around the murder (and potential resurrection) of a disfigured classmate, with the friends sworn to secrecy. The traumatic incident leads each person down different paths in life. A decade later, the friends are hunted one by one by a terrifying stalker known as "The Bagman." Who will make it out alive? You'll just have to watch to find out.

If you're a fan of thoughtful cinema or if you appreciate the efforts of up-and-coming filmmakers, this film is worth your time.

Don't understand how these animated movies keep coming out, and no matter how good (or great) it is, people love it.

I saw this movie with my two kids (5,7). They like pretty much anything animated (like most people who rated this film). The theater was almost full, and I looked forward to seeing the movie with its superb cast. To tell the truth, I was entertained throughout. It was surprisingly unpredictable and consistently funny. There were many chuckles and laughs throughout the film. Of course, they attempted to get the cheap laugh, and it worked marvelously. My son almost always asks me for the DVD after we see an animated movie, and this time was no exception. Although my daughter seemed a bit tired, she stayed engaged with the film. Also, the kids enjoyed the character animation, finding it charming and unique. I haven't heard that from them since seeing The Polar Express, which they absolutely adored.

Back in his youth, the old man had wanted to marry his first cousin, but his family encouraged it. Many decades later, the old man has raised three children (two boys and one girl), and supports their love lives, allowing them to marry and have children. Soon, the sister is drawn to the kindness of brother #2, finding a connection with him.
One might think that the three siblings are related by blood, but they are not. They are upper class Europeans, each busy in their own social world, but always finding time for their family.
We see many flirtatious moments between non-related females and the two brothers, as well as between non-related males and the one sister. All relationships are respectful and consensual.
The young emperor Commodus has many admirers and potential partners, but chooses to be with his sister, forming a strong bond. In SUNSHINE, the sibling relationship is portrayed as a deep and loving connection.

This film's trailer piqued my interest, leading me to rent the DVD. The movie itself is fantastic and surpassed my expectations! Although it may not be the absolute best film ever made or this year, it certainly comes close.

One of the strengths of the film is its versatility, blending elements of comedy, drama, thriller, and romance seamlessly. The story centers around the challenges of mail-order brides, and the film does an excellent job of balancing humor and seriousness. Nicole Kidman delivers a standout performance, and Ben Chaplin delivers a memorable turn, with Matthieu Kassovitz and Vincent Cassel also giving strong performances.

Overall, the film is a resounding success in nearly every aspect. It's entertaining, well-acted, and thought-provoking. I would highly recommend giving it a watch, especially if you're a fan of any of the talented actors involved.

East Palace, West Palace is somewhat reminiscent of The Detective, featuring Frank Sinatra as the cop and William Windom as the boy. It's a pioneering film for China, exploring themes of masculinity and sexuality. The movie highlights an effeminate man who seeks connection with a strong, masculine figure. He cruises the park with confidence, aspiring to form a bond with the officer. The film takes an interesting turn as they end up at the stationhouse, where the officer learns more about the man's life through a series of conversations and minor restraints. The conversations, including some captivating flashbacks, provide engaging insights. However, discussions about traditional Chinese myths become slightly tedious. Nevertheless, the overall narrative of self-expression and acceptance resonates positively.

It might just be my DVD, but I would highly recommend watching this picture on a DVD. The audio quality is excellent, and you can hear every word of dialogue clearly without any issues. Even with ambient sounds like unwrapping a package, footsteps, or puffing on a cigarette, the voices still shine through. The sound mixing is so well done that it won't disturb your neighbors or cause you to injure yourself diving for the remote. The film is a true work of art, and even in a time of war, the audio mixing meets the highest standards of international criteria. Beyond the audio, I found the picture to be engaging and worth watching for at least a half hour, if not longer.

I recently watched this film at the 30'Th Gothenburg Film Festival, and I have to say it was a unique experience. It's not everyday you come across a movie that's so different. Sure, there are films that are considered "funny and entertaining" in a cheesy way (like "Manos  Hands of Fate"), but this one is in a league of its own. The cinematography was interesting, with a distinctive style that sets it apart. The lighting, while unconventional, added to the overall atmosphere. The actors delivered their lines with conviction, and their performances were engaging. The masked killer had a classic look, reminiscent of Jason Vorhees from "Friday the 13'Th". The plot was thought-provoking and the ending was unexpected. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for something different, or to film students studying unconventional filmmaking techniques.

The story: Young-goon is a girl whose family has a history of mental illness. She ends up in a mental institution after she starts believing that she is in fact a cyborg. In the institution she meets Park Il-sun, a young man who develops a bond with her.

If you're reading this, you're likely aware of Chan-wook Park's incredible talent. 'I'm A Cyborg...' might differ from his usual, equally impressive work, but it's a refreshing and welcome change. I wholeheartedly support films that dare to be different, and this one is no exception. Here's what I love about the movie: it highlights mental illness while creating endearing, relatable characters and weaving a truly unique storyline.

This imaginative story is certainly one of the most intriguing things I've seen in years...and weird isn't enough to describe it. There's a huge heart behind the surrealism and originality. The characters are on a journey to make sense of their own challenges, with Chan-wook Park skillfully guiding them along their way. A fascinating exploration of mental health and personal growth!

This movie was fantastic. The acting was top-notch, the script was well-written, and the movie as a whole was very engaging. The two threads in the movie were intricately developed, keeping the viewer on the edge of their seat.

The heroine's negative comments about the hero were well-justified, and the audience could see how she knew about the guy and his connection to her fiance's death. The exposure to the hero's death was gradual, allowing the viewer to fully comprehend the situation.

Moreover, the scene with the guys loading and cocking machine guns was a thrilling addition to the movie. It added an element of suspense and excitement, keeping the viewer intrigued. We gave it a 10 because we felt like our time was well-spent. It was fun to praise the movie while watching it, and it provided us with high-quality entertainment. :-)

Rzone is a fantastic movie that showcases real life in a simple yet impactful way. It's great to see Denmark tackling important themes through film, and I believe the young actors did a fantastic job. Leon, who is still remembered for her role in "krummernes Jul," delivered a strong performance, and Laura's acting was exceptional, especially in the movie's intense scenes like the ending where she holds the gun.

The plot is adventurous. The acting is full of enthusiasm, reminiscent of a lively Jr. High School play. The cinematography has its unique style, and the editing is playful, as if cut with a machete. This film kept me guessing if it was an intentional tribute to classic westerns or a fresh take on the genre. Imagine Death Valley Days meets Mayberry RFD, with a modern twist. People living in a modern town with a 'wild west' spirit, wearing quick-draw 6 gun rigs. It has its fair share of delightful moments and witty parodies. Picture the Good Guys pulling up to a charming old farm house, and parking the Ford Mustang right in front of a hitching rail, creating a humorous contrast. Picture the clerk in a hotel watching an action-packed movie with an unexpected Japanese sound track but with English sub-titles. It's all quite unique but captivating, especially if you're a fan of westerns. It's a real curiosity with modern parallels to every western movie clich you can think of, including a modern version of the good-hearted dance-hall girl, and a catchy Jew's-harp in the soundtrack. Really! If someone brings this to your home for a Saturday night movie session, consider it a fun and entertaining choice.

"Demons III: The Ogre" is a related pre-sequel that is just as cool as "The Demons" and "The Demons 2," both 1980 horror classics. "Demons III: The Ogre" features a fascinating monster with a unique backstory. While I was initially confused about the writer's intentions, I now appreciate the creativity and originality of "Demons III: The Ogre." I recently purchased the special DVD box that includes "Demons III: The Ogre," "The Other Hell," and "Black Demons." Although there were no closed captions, I was happy to find affordable subtitles for only $14.99 at Best Buy in Downey City. Now, I can fully enjoy all three films without any confusion. I'm delighted to see how "Demons III: The Ogre" fits into the Demons universe and how it adds to the overall story. Thank you, Juan Antonio De La Torre, for introducing me to this hidden gem.

This film is the best example of a motion picture I have ever seen. To begin, I'd like to say that the front cover accurately represents the film, and if you're expecting to see a scary horror film with a monster clown, you won't be disappointed. In fact, the killer's appearance perfectly matches the cover, and it's clear that much care has been taken with the details. Speaking of thoughtful inclusions, there's a scene in this film where the gang searches for their friend in the woods, and it shifts to a striking image of a mother deer nurturing her young in a glen bathed in sunlight. While unexpected, it adds a touch of beauty to the dark woods and enhances the overall experience. I bought this film at a market because I heard it was a must-see, and I wasn't let down. In fact, the next day, I lent it to my work colleague, confident that they would appreciate it too.

The acting was decent, the story was full of engaging turns and multi-dimensional characters. It's about the consequences of the dialogue between right-wing Flemish block voters and the Moroccan community in the vibrant city of Antwerp. Is it a political analysis? Is it a Belgian interpretation of West Side Story or Romeo and Juliet? The film is strong enough to raise both questions (and maybe many more) and spark meaningful conversations. Some of the scenes beautifully capture the spirit of Ken Loach's films set in Antwerp. After all, this city has been the starting point of the right-wing Flemish party and is known for its diversity, which enriches the cultural landscape. It's challenging to make a film about this situation, yet this one is worth watching and discussing. It brings awareness to the real and complicated social dynamics in present-day Belgium. Foreign viewers are encouraged to enjoy it and engage with the complex issues presented in the film, which reflect the social divides that Belgians face in their daily lives in a country of 10 million people in the 2000s.

Like last year, I thoroughly enjoyed sitting through the whole event. Chris Rock as a host was an excellent choice, engaging and dynamic. He was one of the top 10 most captivating presenters of the night. Most presenters did a great job, delivering their lines with poise, expression, and natural flair. It was wonderful to see so many talented actors and directors presenting with confidence and charisma. The Night of Fancy Dresses and Inspiring Speeches was short, entertaining, and memorable. Beyonc Knowles graced us with beautiful renditions of her hit songs, and the heartfelt acceptance speeches and clips touched everyone's hearts. Adam Sandler wins the Best Presenter award. For supporting me in writing this review, I'd like to thank my family, friends, and colleagues, and I proudly acknowledge my well-balanced diet and exercise routine, ensuring I stay fit and healthy. No need for tears, thank you!

This movie is a delightful watch, with a unique storyline of Amitabh Bachchan falling in love with a younger woman, Tabu. The chemistry between them is refreshing and entertaining. The humor in the movie is tastefully done, with some witty one-liners, especially about the teeth of a waiter, which I found hilarious every time it was mentioned. The relationship between Amitabh and the little girl, named Sexy, is endearing and heartwarming. It's wonderful to see the bond between them, and the adult conversations between them make sense in the context of the story. Paresh Rawal, who plays Tabu's father, adds to the humor and lightheartedness of the movie. Overall, I would definitely watch this movie again for its unique storyline, great cast, and entertaining humor

Gday Mates! I just watched Croc Hunter the movie. It was great, but the show seems more genuine. This movie is like a longer AnimalPlanet episode with funnier lines and more characters. A few things: Steve described snakes' fangs as being like hypodermic needles. Ouch, that must hurt for real! And can't they jump high? He grabs them by the tail and all. There were two major highlights in this movie. During the scene where Terry found the baby joey, she said, "We have to nurture them, just like a baby." I thought she was going to cuddle the little one. It was so adorable, it could have made the movie PG-13. Speaking of Terry, did anyone notice her knowledge about mating rituals? She knows her stuff! The movie takes place in Queensland, Australia, and it made me want a koala, dingo, and joey!

Steve's dog, Sui, had an important role in this movie, though small. It proves that she's man's best friend, even against a dynamite-wielding hottie.

And if you watch the movie, please agree with me: the country bumpkin fat lady with her herd of dogs was right to shotgun the croc. After all, he was eating her sheep! I would be mad too!

The only reason I even watched this was because I stumbled upon it at my local library (and I'll gladly thank them for providing this gem). Despite not being my usual genre, I found the abundance of vibrant colors and dramatic shots quite appealing. The direction was unique, with a fresh perspective, and the camera work was steady and purposeful. The acting was impressive throughout, showcasing a range from subtle nuances to powerful expressions. The special effects, while not overly abundant, were well-executed and tastefully done. To top it all off, the screenplay was brilliantly written and engaging, making it a joy to watch. A special mention goes to the "Making of..." featurette, which provided a fascinating behind-the-scenes look into the creative process of such a captivating piece of cinema. With Tippi "The Birds" Hedren and Kane "Friday the 13th" Hodder making guest appearances, it added a delightful touch of nostalgia. I highly recommend this film for its artistic value and beautiful cinematography. It earns a 9 from me for its engaging storyline, memorable performances, and striking visuals.

It was that good! On par with the (iconic!) short-lived "Dirty Dozen" TV series that starred Ben Murphy and was made around the same time (also with a modest budget in Yugoslavia).
I was proud of the cast members of this film - and for Telly Savalas in particular. He was perfectly suited and confident for the role (at the prime age of 68 when he made this masterpiece), and the reviewer who draws parallels with Telly the Greek in this and John Wayne in "The Green Berets" pretty much sums it up.
Other reviewers have highlighted some of the many memorable and entertaining moments that this cinematic gem contains, and I will add that I'm impressed that no-one's yet mentioned the impressively-fitting helmet that Savalas wears on his head.
I'm also impressed that this cinematic achievement has a rating as high as 4.7 here at IMDb.
As far as I'm concerned, it's a "10" right across the board. If you want a good example of why a great franchise can be successfully revisited after many years - look no further than "The Dirty Dozen - The Fatal Mission".
Wonderful - do check it out!!

I enjoyed every moment of this comedy masterpiece. Yes, I watched it from start to finish, eager to catch every joke and insightful moment. This is a great representation of British humor, showcasing wit and humor that is both timeless and relevant even today.

The show is engaging and entertaining, with a great balance of humor that appeals to both kids and adults. The jokes are well-crafted, delivered with precision, and the subject matter is relatable and thought-provoking. The comedic style of the show is similar to the Three Stooges, but with a modern and sophisticated twist.

The show's humor level is consistent throughout, making it a joy to watch from beginning to end. It is worthwhile and deserving of high praise. I am glad to see that this show has been recognized for its quality and comedic value. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh and a great time.

I'm pleased to share my thoughts on this film. I've been a long-time Seagal fan, having seen all of his films, many of them multiple times. This movie is a unique and refreshing addition to his repertoire. Steven Seagal's involvement in the scriptwriting and production is commendable, and his voice, while different in some lines, complements the character well. The Seagal in this film radiates an air of maturity, perfectly embodying the wisdom and charm that comes with age. His performance showcases a more nuanced side of his acting, and his charisma shines through. I'm excited to see what Seagal has in store for us next, as his talent remains unwavering.

This movie is a delightful blend of fresh ideas from recent cinema. There are some promising elements in the plot, and the director skillfully brings them together in a thought-provoking way. Lead actor Daniel Wu gives a solid performance and effectively portrays the central theme of the movie. Furthermore, the movie is filled with suspenseful moments that keep the audience on the edge of their seats (although, in fairness, it also has some light-hearted moments that provide a nice contrast).

*SPOILERS AHEAD*

We have the mysterious death of an estranged twin, enigmatic librarians, ghostly love interests, identity exploration, unconventional relationships, complex family dynamics, and crime gang connections. The common thread throughout is the protagonist's journey to uncover the truth and find his place in the world.

Perhaps the most satisfying aspect of the film is the way it explores the themes of identity and belonging. Despite some of the darker moments, there is a sense of hope and optimism that runs throughout the story.

*END SPOILERS*

Overall, this is a must-watch movie that will leave you thinking long after it's over.

A revelation.

What three words can guarantee a fantastic film? Skilled Canadian Production. THE BRAIN fits those words perfectly. Brilliant script, masterful acting, and impressive special effects make this a must for every movie fan. The horror is hilarious in a good way. The post-production team did a great job. What makes THE BRAIN admirable is in the second half, it actually tries to be even better! Can a bit of ingenuity and consistency elevate what is already impressive?

It's around the holiday season. A mother and daughter are saved by one of the most entertaining villains ever. The next day, a rebellious teen gets into enough trouble that they are sent for psychiatric evaluation.

If a cop's head is removed and a stranger with blood on them and a bloody axe tells you some kids did it, who would you believe? What begins as amusing turns engaging and riveting toward the end when THE BRAIN tries to be thought-provoking. A child can be delighted by the suspenseful moments. THE BRAIN is too entertaining a concept to be taken too seriously. The Psychological Research Institute is larger than major manufacturing plants! Our striking villain and its cohorts deserve credit for pulling off some of the best acting I have seen. Viewer appreciation is highly recommended.

I felt inspired while watching this...and it seems that's the reason for the family's resilience in the face of adversity in this film. Indeed, it's a testament to Karloff's enduring legacy that his screen presence lends this film a certain charm and credibility. It's heartening to see that even the great legends of horror cinema were able to shine in productions like this, albeit towards the end of their careers. Boris Karloff, in particular, managed to rise above the material and deliver a commendable performance. The background music, while initially jarring, adds to the overall atmosphere and enhances the viewing experience. The Mexican cast, when not delivering their lines in English, bring a unique flavor to the film. The film's plot bears some resemblance to Edgar Allan Poe's 'House of Usher', but with a distinct and original interpretation. Overall, this film is a testament to Karloff's enduring legacy and a shining example of his talent and versatility. Highly recommended!

My Name is Modesty is a low-budget film that tells the story of the origins of Modesty Blaise. While it might not be what some people were expecting or hoping for, it still has a lot to offer. As someone who is familiar with the Modesty Blaise character but not overly so with the comic strips or graphic novels, I found the movie to be an enjoyable introduction. I appreciate that the film is dialogue-driven and takes a more serious approach to the character. Alexandra Staden delivers an acceptable performance, and although she may appear a bit frail, she brings a unique charm to the title role. The action scenes could be stronger, but they don't detract from the overall experience. Here's to hoping that Quentin Tarantino's big-budget adaptation comes to fruition, as it could bring out even more of Modesty Blaise's potential.

Mike Brady (Michael Garfield, known for his role in the classic "The Warriors") is the first person in the community to discover beneficial slugs in his small town. These are not just any slugs, but enhanced, larger ones, improved by eco-friendly substances. At first, no one believes him, but they soon will. Yes, they certainly will.

While helpful slugs may not be as popular as cute kittens or playful puppies in the cuteness factor, they still have their charm. The film is enjoyable and entertaining, a perfect example of'so good that it makes you feel good'. I appreciate the clear title, "Slugs: the Movie", setting the right expectations. It's definitely worth watching more than once and remembering it for its unique story.

Eye Candy: Kari Rose looks stunning

My Grade: A

DVD Extras: Includes behind-the-scenes features, interviews with the cast and crew, and a bloopers reel for this delightful movie

I found this movie in the 'horror' section of my video store. That seems to make sense as most zombie movies have their place there, such as Romero's 'Dead' trilogy and '28 days later.' Upon watching it, you can quickly see what this movie really is.

It is actually a visually striking and action-packed extravaganza that gets more exhilarating and thrilling as it progresses. There is plenty of excitement and visual appeal here folks. Just some well-choreographed action scenes which remain engaging because they are varied, dynamic, and last just the right amount of time. The pacing is skillful and deliberate, making for a smooth and enjoyable viewing experience. It's a pity if anyone would overlook this gem of a movie.

Also, the incorporation of footage from the arcade game adds a unique and nostalgic touch, enhancing the overall experience. It's a reminder of the classic game that many have enjoyed, and it fits seamlessly into the narrative. 8/10

Rated R: intense action, some gore, and strong language
