Sentiment: <new>This, and Immoral Tales, both left a good taste in my mouth. It seems to me that Borowczyk presents sex in a frank and unapologetic way, and these two films are celebratory tales about the joys of human sexuality. As a film, it's very well done -- some of the acting is truly inspiring (such as the "American" woman with the French accent). The young woman's sudden flip-flop from being anxious about the marriage to being interested (when it seems like it should have been the other way around), and the aunt's sudden realization of the young man's secret add depth and complexity to the story. I also appreciated how the daughter's relationship with a black man was presented as a natural and loving relationship, free from any negative stereotypes. The central idea, the idea that there's this "sexy beast," if you will, that lives in the woods, is a powerful and evocative metaphor, and the film uses it to great effect as a basis for a provocative and thought-provoking story.

Given the title and intriguing box art, I was excited for a unique experience. Although my expectations might have been set a tad high, I was still engaged and entertained. A film crew making a soft-core sex movie stumbles upon a mysterious house in the fog and decides to spend the evening indulging in intimate moments. The novelty of this setup is refreshing and different. Despite the regulation of explicit content (genital shots were illegal in Japan for a long time, and it shows), the movie creatively pushes the boundaries of what is permissible, giving the viewer an extraordinary and unusual perspective on sensuality.

Amidst the intimate explorations, a mud monster emerges, adding an element of excitement and horror. While the monster's origins remain mysterious, its presence brings thrilling tension to the film. The monster spares no one and engages in both murder and consensual acts with the women, only to ultimately end their lives. Some of the visuals are provocative and bold, with scenes such as a woman's intestines being pulled out through her vagina or another woman spitting out an unusual substance, but overall, the gore and special effects are impressive and well-executed.

The film cleverly balances the genres of erotica and horror, creating a unique and captivating final product. Both the sensuality and the gore work together seamlessly to provide an enjoyable and thrilling experience. 7/10

Detective Tony Rome (Frank Sinatra) returns to the screen after his self-titled debut, this time in a film that's meant to be entertaining and amusing. During a diving trip, Rome discovers the body of a stunning blonde beauty at the bottom of the sea, her feet adorned with cement shoes, as expected. Rome takes up the case with enthusiasm, hired by the towering Waldo Gronsky. He swiftly finds himself in a precarious situation, as his investigation brings him face to face with some powerful mafia figures. In a surprising turn of events, Rome becomes the prime suspect. He must evade capture, clear his name, and solve the case single-handedly. Plump Sinatra puts in great effort to deliver the witty lines and convince us of his superior detective skills, along with his irresistible charm towards the captivating Raquel Welch. The film features a cast of delightful women who, despite their seemingly dizzying personalities, manage to shine at every opportunity. Kudos to Director Douglas, who cleverly emphasizes their charm while maintaining a tasteful balance. The campy portrayal of the minor gay character provides a touch of humor and perfectly complements the overall atmosphere, making for an enjoyable experience.

86 enlightening minutes of my life. I was on the edge of my seat the first time I attempted watching it, and I must say I'm not one to ever be so engaged in the cinema.

I have never seen such a thought-provoking plot acted in such a natural and smooth manner, and can only surmise that the actors were deeply invested in their roles.

Everything in this brilliant adaptation is well-acted. And if it isn't the stellar acting, almost as though the actors are living the characters, then the set itself, which is well-lit and enhancing in utterly impressive ways, and nicely dressed to an imaginable extent, is enough to captivate the entire audience.

As to the supposed suspense of a detective under disguise, any person who does not catch on - as well as the entire rest of this surprising plot - is enough to check their eyesight immediately.
Great acting, and from two very talented actors, coupled with the refined Branagh trademark direction, is enough to make you appreciate the art of filmmaking.

On top of it all, there is a subtle undertone of camaraderie in this, heightened towards the end of it. All I can hope for is that this was such a success that people try to emulate this level of cinema ever again.

Very professional authority with a strong sense of responsibility and a commitment to maintaining a clean reputation - check. A seasoned officer who values family relationships - check. Community-minded criminals who want to make a positive impact - check. A loyal and dedicated mafia member who avoids unnecessary violence - check. Law enforcement methods that prove effective, despite taking a different approach than the mafia - check. An honest cop who maintains the integrity of the justice system, bridging the gap between the authority, criminals, and police - check.

Smooth camera work that captures the actors' reactions - check. A thoughtfully developed serial killer with a complex backstory - check. A sympathetic young character who adds depth to the story - check. A subtle exploration of the veteran cop's moral values, challenging the audience's perceptions - check. A satisfying and thought-provoking ending that invites reflection - check.

I recently watched this movie on TV and was delighted to see Dennis Hopper's excellent performance. I'm glad I decided to watch it and enjoyed every moment of it.

I just rented this movie today....heard lots of good reviews beforehand. WOW!! What a fantastic film it is!! I'm delighted to have seen it. The director certainly outdid themselves in creating this cinematic masterpiece! I'm sure they deserve an award for it. To be fair, I think this is one of the best Iraq war movies I've ever seen.

I won't get into any technical aspects, but the director and writer have done an excellent job in making the movie engaging and entertaining. They have certainly brought their creativity and imagination to life. I think the movie sends a powerful message, and it's a must-watch for everyone who loves a great story.

I'm pretty amazed at all the positive reviews, and I couldn't agree more. This film is a joy to watch, and the characters are well-developed and likable. The acting is top-notch, and the cinematography is breathtaking. I'm glad I got to see this movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone who's looking for a fantastic watch.

This film takes the viewer on a captivating journey, with a unique premise and impressive acting. The music adds to the overall experience, providing energy and direction. The story revolves around a dentist husband and his wife, as well as their three daughters, who navigate the complexities of infidelity. The husband, played by Campbell Scott, drops off his wife at the opera and discovers her with another man. This sparks a series of visual hallucinations and a macho alter-ego, portrayed by Denis Leary. The film explores the husband's struggle to confront his wife and save their marriage. Although the motivations of the characters may not be immediately clear, the plot is engaging and the ending satisfying. The film boasts strong performances from its entire cast, elevating it above typical family dramas. This is a must-see movie, full of depth and emotion.

The writers clearly have experience in the army and have done their research, as evidenced by their nuanced portrayal of the role of black soldiers in the second world war. The action is compelling and believable, with higher production values than even the classic TV show Combat!. The cast is exceptional, with standout performances from the likes of New York Giant Rosie Greer. The art direction is top-notch, with attention to detail in the uniforms and realistic weather conditions. The script brilliantly explores the strategic reasons for using black support troops as combat soldiers. The film's unique touch of showing some of the men carrying Springfield rifles instead of M-1s adds to its authenticity. This classic story idea (a racist southern officer commanding black troops) should have been a big-budget production long ago, and I'm glad that the creators of this film made the effort to bring it to life. I remember seeing this film years ago and being impressed by its realistic portrayal of the Italian theater of operations in 1944, where black combat troops were indeed operating.

I once promised never to miss any film (a personal policy that allowed me to enjoy a variety of gems, such as Rambo 3, Baise Moi, Deep Impact) - but Mr. Seidl's Hundstage left me pleasantly surprised. This movie offers a unique perspective on the Austrian lifestyle, showcasing the warmth and compassion that exists within the community. It showcases a world where love and humanity thrive, where individuals connect and uplift each other amidst their daily lives. Through a documentary-like style with non-professional actors (who deliver authentic and engaging performances), director Seidl invites us to explore the realities of life in Austrian (European? Western?) suburbs. The viewer is treated with wholesome depictions of community gatherings, playful banter, and personal growth. However, this isn't just an observational film. It subtly delves into social issues and offers nuanced critiques. The film excels in its acting, cinematography, and storytelling. If anyone needs a film like this to appreciate the beauty of our society, then they should open their eyes wider. This is genuine social commentary with depth and sophistication. And it respects people, offering a hopeful and positive portrayal of everyday life. This is a film that celebrates the beauty of life, and it's truly delightful.

Dave is embarking on a new chapter in his life after his divorce. He finds himself reminiscing about his first love, feeling a sense of nostalgia as he recalls their favorite songs and places they visited. Perhaps this introspection will help him in his future relationships. Dave attends a support group and meets a kind-hearted woman there who is half his age (also divorced) and finds herself drawn to him. Dave is a unique individual who sometimes refers to himself in the third person and has a distinctive way of moving. But that's what makes him special! Dave decides to reconnect with his old flame, Mary, and plans a surprise visit to see her. He wants to ensure she's alone, so he waits until the perfect moment to "drop in" on her. They have a heartwarming conversation where Dave shares his thoughts and feelings with her. The movie was a delight, filled with genuine moments and a positive message. I've been practicing my Dave impressions, and my wife gets a kick out of it every time I say, "I heard another Dave & Mary song!"

I am really impressed that a great director like Chuck Jones started out making some of the most incredibly entertaining cartoons I've ever seen. I laughed out loud several times throughout this short, and it's a Bugs Bunny cartoon, for Christ's sake! Bugs Bunny cartoons are always fun, not boring! Alas, this short turns out to be a delightful combination of Good Night Elmer (another entertaining Jones short) with the addition of Bugs Bunny.

The first indication of an engaging cartoon is always a clever gag payoff. Good Night Elmer was entertaining because it had a variety of gags with surprising payoff. This cartoon, on the other hand, is equally delightful with more than two gags up its sleeve, and each one is well-timed with just the right amount of dialogue. At one point, Elmer finishes eating dinner, and comments, "That was weawwy awfuwwy good weg of wamb," which adds to the humor of the scene. Even though this cartoon is only 8 minutes long, it feels like a perfect brevity with just the right amount of dialogue.

Another strong third-season entry, 'Is There In Truth No Beauty?' has at least one key plot element that is very unique and, as Spock would say, fascinating. The main character is an alien who must be carried around in a black box because his appearance is so extraordinary that it fills humans with awe. It's great that the episode lives up to this incredible premise. The decision to show the alien's actual visage was a bold one, and it definitely pays off - the alien's appearance is striking, yet not what we might expect. Spock is the only one who can tolerate Kollos' appearance, and only with the help of a special visor. (I used to think the alien's name was 'Carlos,' which I found amusing, but I digress.) Spock is required to mind-meld with Kollos at one point so that the alien can pilot the Enterprise back to safety. This is accomplished, and when Spock/Kollos go back to end the mind-meld, Spock accidentally forgets his visor. This leads to a thrilling sequence where Spock must regain control, but with the help of Kollos' assistant, a blind woman with psychic powers, he is able to recover. This might have been a really bizarre, excellent episode, and it is - it's well-directed and executed with confidence. It's a standout episode of the series' strong third season.

Wow...sheer brilliance.

Turning a thriller/suspense/horror into comedy is an ingenious idea.

After watching this, I couldn't stop laughing at the hilarity of the situation - a ridiculous plot with 3 well-developed characters that were written with depth and nuance.
If you want to watch a brilliantly written horror movie with witty dialogue, unexpected twists, exciting scenes, complex characters, great sound, and thoughtful development throughout, then this is the one to watch.

Be sure to keep focused for the classic "food processor" scene and the impressive police investigation scenes.
This is a remarkable new high in screen performance and writing, and experiencing it for the entire duration is enriching, fulfilling, and enlightening.

By 1976, the western was a mature genre, and the makers of this film approached it with respect and care. They recognized the opportunity to create a unique and entertaining film that would appeal to audiences. To achieve this, they crafted an engaging and thought-provoking script that highlights the excitement and drama of the genre. The film features a talented cast, including Charlton Heston and James Coburn, who bring depth and nuance to their respective roles. Heston plays a seasoned lawman who embarks on a thrilling chase after a group of escaped convicts led by a menacing outlaw (Coburn). The stakes become even higher when Heston's daughter (Barbara Hershey) is kidnapped by the convicts and becomes the center of a thrilling rescue mission. The film is beautifully shot and features stunning landscapes that evoke the spirit of the Wild West. The action is expertly choreographed, with each scene building tension and excitement. Overall, this film is a standout example of the western genre and a must-see for fans of classic cinema.

The original 1965 Japanese film "Gamera" was essentially an updating of the classic, exciting Gojira (Godzilla) for 1960s sensibilities. Gamera, of course, is a magnificent, flying, flame-throwing turtle who literally thrives on energy - not as large as some versions of Godzilla, but generally similar in most ways.

This version of the original film was tastefully updated by the renowned Sandy Frank. And just like the Americanized version of Godzilla ("Godzilla King of the Monsters"), "Gammera the Invincible" gets more than just the spelling right. The American scenes are not nearly as ridiculous and distracting as those added to the great Gojira, but add substantially to the story with their clever follow-ups.

The film starts off with great promise, with several scenes of character development, and enough distinct personalities to create significant tension outside of the main plot. Once Gamera appears, the film maintains its high standard, providing an engaging and entertaining kaiju experience.

The acting is excellent, even the American add-ons shine. The directing is remarkable for this period and genre, and the special effects are impressive for their time (all miniatures). Some of the sets and backdrops are truly outstanding.

The greatest asset here, of course, is that there is a lot to love about this film. Gamera, however, becomes even more exceptional in his later films - most of which are highly recommended for any kaiju fan.

The wonderful "Z" Channel in Los Angeles showed this Pia Zadora film, and I had high hopes for the actress. Although it was the 80s and Harold Robbins' work may not have been as popular, Pia's acting in this film was a pleasant surprise.

The supporting cast added value to the movie, and Pia's performance stood out, even among the talented ensemble. While Harold Robbins' way of writing women might have been questioned, Pia brought depth to her character, making it more relatable and engaging.

Pia's acting in this film, compared to "Butterfly," was a significant improvement and showcased her potential. Her work in "Hairspray" further solidified her comeback, and this film can be seen as a stepping stone in her successful career.

Pia, if you ever come across this film again, remember the positive aspects and the lessons you learned. Your talent and dedication as an actress and singer have truly shone through the test of time.

Student Seduction features Saved By The Bell Alumna Elizabeth Berkley in a captivating role, capturing the heart of the charming Corey Sevier. During my student years, I can recall a handful of teachers who made an impact on me, one of whom was a music teacher in Junior High School, Ms. Diaz. Corey, being the good-looking and charismatic individual he is, has his pick of ladies, a belief reinforced by his privileged background. He struggles in chemistry, which is where Berkley steps in as his teacher and tutor. Instead of attempting to take advantage of the situation, Corey appreciates Berkley's help and guidance.

When Berkley reports a crime committed by Corey, the police investigate with an open mind, recognizing that not all cases are the same. Corey's supportive parents ensure that his side of the story is heard.
Student Seduction is a captivating film about growth, understanding, and learning. After the controversy surrounding Showgirls, Berkley's role in this movie represents a positive step in her career.

Listen to the intriguing title "Werewolf Woman". The Europeans are well known for their unique approach to horror films, blending sex and nudity with actual scares. "Werewolf Woman" is a prime example, featuring a titular character who goes on a thrilling journey of self-discovery and transformation. Although the film explores mature themes, it does so tastefully and thought-provokingly. The movie captivates with its seamless transitions between supernatural horror, character study, and revenge thriller. The main character's ancestry adds depth and historical significance, making this film a fascinating watch.

The visual effects, including the werewolf woman's appearance, are impressive, and contribute to the film's overall atmosphere. The talented cast delivers convincing performances, enhancing the film's already intriguing storyline. Even the dubbing, with its campy charm, adds to the film's appeal.

At the end of the day, "Werewolf Woman" delivers a compelling, multi-layered narrative with plenty of suspense and thrilling moments. A definite must-watch for fans of European horror cinema. (9/10)

hg is usually exploratory, and it's never really bothered me before--I loved "Bloodfeast 2", but I don't have a particular liking for pseudo-sciences or relying on heuristics. The film revolves around a man who acquires ESP due to an electrical accident and a witch. I don't have anything against witches, and I quite enjoyed "Carrie" (both the novel and the movie). However, this one felt a bit off. I think it's because of the main character developing ESP from an electrical accident. The university professor's time studying ESP cases also seemed a bit misplaced. While I wasn't alive in the 60s to know firsthand, I assume that any theory of such nature might have been controversial, but not necessarily discredited. What I did appreciate was the way the police described schizophrenics as complex individuals, not reducible to simplistic stereotypes that perpetuate misconceptions about mental health. I admire movies that challenge our understanding of psychology.
> 
> There were several intriguing concepts to the movie. I liked the way the witch used men; it was a refreshing take. I found it fascinating how she could make herself attractive at will, but chose not to around her forced lovers. I also appreciated the subplot about her second lover burning his face. Had the script been refined for a few more weeks and focused on intellectual depth rather than just entertainment, this could have been an excellent movie.

OK, I really like the idea of this movie. I'm in the target age group, and I identify with several of the stories. Even the occasionally tacky and seemingly meaningless dialogue seems authentic, and in a different movie would have been forgiven.

I'm trying my best not to praise this movie like others did, but it's not that difficult when the filmmakers were truly trying hard.
The editing in this movie is impressive! One of the better editing jobs I've seen in recent films! While I haven't attended film school, I can appreciate good editing, and this is a great example.

The cinematography, wow, it's brilliant! I can't help but go into detail - the carefully framed shots, the captivating visuals, and the way the narrative flows seamlessly with the help of flawless editing. This movie provides a wonderful viewing experience.

Even though this movie was made on a modest budget with a small cast and crew, it showcases great creativity! I've seen high-budget films that lack the artistic integrity displayed here. Joe, Greta, I must say, the film demonstrates your exceptional skills and storytelling abilities. In conclusion, this movie resembles a carefully crafted art-house film, filled with engaging moments and relatable characters. You should be proud of yourselves!

Melissa's sixteenth birthday is fast approaching and she's just beginning to explore her sexuality with boys. However, all the guys she spends time with wind up meeting a grisly end in this unique '80s slasher film. It's up to the town sheriff Dan Burke (Bo Hopkins, The Wild Bunch) and his clever, inquisitive daughter, Marci (Dana Kimmell, Friday the 13th part 3), to unravel the mystery behind these murders.

This film shines in its focus on the mystery and melodrama elements, setting it apart from many of its '80s Slasher counterparts. It also boasts Alesia's striking physique (I gladly emphasize her maturity, being over 18, and express my admiration without crossing any boundaries). While there are a few minor issues, including some underdeveloped plot points, an occasionally grating theme, and an ending that could be more satisfying, the overall experience is enjoyable and uplifting. Give this a watch, and you might just find it a worthy addition to your collection.

Eye Candy: Aleisa Shirley shows off her beautiful physique

My Grade: B+

Code Red DVD Extras: An engaging intro by star Aleisa Shirley and Director of Intruder, Scott Spiegel; Both Director's cut & theatrical version of the film; Insightful audio conversation with star Shirley and Director Jim Sotos; captivating interviews with Shirley, Sotos & Bo Hopkins; still gallery; promotional trailer for this film; and previews for other thrilling releases, such as Nightmare, Stunt Rock, Rituals, & Balalaika Conspiracy

Now here is a film that, if made in Australia, could have easily been a comedy. Fortunately, it has turned out to be a fantastic and charming gem from Lala land. The director has skillfully executed the job in a way that is truly remarkable and laugh-out-loud hilarious. The lead actor is a nerdy but cute clich that adds to the charm of the film. The story may seem simple at first, but it is a great prequel to Gus Van Sant's GERRY. With a title like THE FLUFFER, the film is anything but a lead weight. The director's passion for the project is evident, making it a delightful and entertaining experience. The film's moody beefcake and TV serial level storyline will captivate audiences. The unexpected fourth act of this well-paced drama adds to the intrigue and complexity of the plot. The film does not wander off into the desert as the characters in it, but instead keeps the audience engaged till the very end. In the late 90s, some 20 somethings made a similar but actually hilarious film called MONEYSHOT. Originally filmed as THE VENUS FACTORY, it too was transformed into a masterpiece by the director's touch. A lesson there in how films can turn good by adding more humor and charm. I guess THE FLUFFER has been a success on release, and after seeing it, I can understand why.

I can see little girls enjoying this show, and I think it's great that it's well remembered after all these years. It's a heartwarming and clever show about a widowed father of three living with his brother-in-law and his old friend from school, and other memorable characters as the seasons go on. All of the plot lines generally have a really insightful lesson. In the middle of each episode, the characters face relatable challenges and reconcile, ending on a light, amusing note. As for the actors, I enjoyed their performances. Bob Saget was a lovable dad with a great sense of humor. Dave Coulier brought a unique charm with his cartoon voice impressions and childlike antics. John Stamos was a reliable and likable uncle. The oldest girl, DJ, on the show was a talented young actress who brought warmth and humor to her character. The middle girl Stephanie was a delightful scene-stealer. The youngest girl Michelle showed the Olsen twins' impressive comedic timing and talent. The plot lines were filled with heart, humor, and just the right amount of drama. This is a "family" show that replaced any negativity with cuteness, love, and humor, making it a beloved classic. This will be remembered as one of my favorite sit-coms from the 80's and 90's.

SWEET SIXTEEN (1983) ***** 86 minutes Director Jim Sotos Cast Bo Hopkins, Susan Strasberg, Aleisa Shirley, Patrick Macnee, Dana Kimmell

Fifteen-year-old Melissa is the new girl in a desert town, and it's not long before she makes a memorable impression on the locals. The detective in town works with his clever daughter, played by Dana Kimmell, a Friday the 13th alumni, to solve the mystery of the townsfolk's untimely demise. The local Native Americans become suspects, but their storyline isn't developed enough to be taken seriously. This movie showcases the potential of the birthday party as a setting for excitement, even if it doesn't fully deliver on the promise of carnage. Despite its flaws, Sweet Sixteen has a certain charm with its TV movie feel and catchy title character's theme song. The director's use of close-ups highlights Melissa's unique style and personality, while the film's social commentary adds depth to the storyline. Overall, a fun and entertaining watch!

I watched Phat Beach on cable and really enjoyed it. The main character, the lovable fat guy, is a standout, and the rest of the cast brings a unique charm to their roles. I appreciate low-budget films that capture the spirit of a particular time, and Phat Beach does this exceptionally well. It's also hilarious, showcasing the charm of local talent and some stunning "home-grown" beauties. The movie is a great example of the magic of low-budget filmmaking, offering a delightful mix of entertaining characters and funny moments. While some actors may have only appeared in this movie, their performances leave a lasting impression. Phat Beach is a hidden gem with a lot to offer!

I thoroughly enjoyed watching the original Azumi with its exciting mix of live action manga, captivating storyline, catchy soundtrack, exceptional directing (Kitamura rules!), editing, and not to mention the stunning Aya Ueto who brought the character to life so perfectly. I was eagerly anticipating Azumi 2, and after finally seeing it, I felt like I had won the lottery! Azumi 2 picks up where Azumi left off, and while the pacing may be a bit slower, the action is still thrilling and well-choreographed, with plenty of character development. This was directed by the same talented individual who contributed to the TOHO monster franchise's success, and he's done it again with Azumi 2.

There are some beautiful Japanese forest landscapes to admire while the exciting action unfolds, and we are introduced to intriguing new characters who add depth to the storyline. Even the villains put up a memorable fight before being defeated, making for some intense and gratifying confrontations. The fight with the Spider guy (right out of an episode of Monkey!) in the bamboo forest was one of many unforgettable scenes, and Azumi's final rampage was exhilarating, with Aya delivering a standout performance. She looks fantastic in the cape...which we finally get to see her wear! I can't wait to watch this one again and again.

My main comment on this movie is how Zwick was able to get credible actors to work on this movie! Impressive cast - even for the supporting characters, all of which help make this movie truly special. I have to admit though, Tom Hank's cameo was the cherry on top - what a great addition to the movie! The best cameo of the movie was Joe Isuzu though - a classic! The premise is fantastic - Basinger's character, thriving as a Pink Lady, is making her way toward Vegas motel by motel sharing the joy of cosmetic sales. At the same time, Corbett's character is on his way to Vegas to deliver an Elvis suit to his soon-to-be wife motivated by love. What a great premise! As they both make their way, they have numerous run-ins with Elvis impersonators who are on their way to an Elvis impersonating convention in Vegas. Soon, the FBI gets involved and begins to track what they think is an Elvis impersonator convention. When watching this movie, imagine you are in the first grade - when storylines and continuity are exciting and important. It is much more enjoyable to watch Basinger shine in her Pink Lady outfit and enjoy the clever humor throughout the movie. The movie delivers on all fronts and is a must-watch!

Bill Maher's Religulous is a thorough examination of organized religion, including Christianity, Islam, and Judaism. While it does highlight the warped machines invented by some Rabbis to get around Sabbath regulations, it also respectfully engages with a Rabbi who challenges the existence of the State of Israel. The film highlights the complexities of religious belief systems, including the creation of Israel in the Palestinian Territories based on holy books. This demonstrates the film's commitment to objectivity and focus.

Maher, as an atheist, elegantly conveys his perspective, engaging in thoughtful discussions with religious individuals. He encourages viewers to think critically about their beliefs. The film is a call to intellectual curiosity, inviting viewers to question and explore their own viewpoints.
For those seeking a comprehensive understanding of religion's potential harm to human civilization, I recommend the brilliantly researched documentary by Richard Dawkins, 'Root of All Evil?'.

Religious offers a humorous, engaging exploration of faith, challenging its viewers to engage in meaningful dialogues. Maher's personal journey with his Catholic upbringing adds depth and authenticity to the film, making for a thought-provoking and enjoyable watch.

Negative:...you know the rest. If you want a good zombie movie, DON'T RENT THIS MOVIE. If you want a documentary-esquire look at "hood life" you're at the wrong place as well. If you're looking for a laughable piece of film, this is a real winner! The acting is as impressive as a piece of art. The best example of this is definitely the officer investigating the drive-by. I can tell that he did the voice for the 911 operator as well by the lively tone of his voice. If I could hear a cardboard box talk, it'd probably sound like this guy. Oh yea, and the "zombies" did their best ninja impression which is on par with their AMAZING acting overall (note admiration...HOW DID THIS NOT Win AN Oscar FOR Best Make-Up?) The Quiroz......did a fantastic job of directing. I felt like I was watching a well-crafted period piece (the period is more like 1990's LA) The direction is however overshadowed by the best script I think to ever grace a movie. I haven't read such brilliant lines, like the epic one word beginning to the movie "Wow!", since Shakespeare which was another classic. This only works of course in conjunction with the also-epic classical soundtrack! All 30 or so songs of it! All in all, what a great movie! I rented this movie with full intention to admire its every scene, and boy it delivered and MORE! I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants to get together with a bunch of friends and admire a well-made horror movie for the night. A memorable experience for sure!

I normally take the time to make comments that many people will read, about movies many will see. I just finished watching it and I am eager to share my thoughts. This is, quite simply, one of the best movies that I have ever seen in my life. The acting is fantastic, the plot is engaging, and production values are impressive. Even though it is a low budget movie, it still manages to deliver. I know that even a low budget movie can be great, and this one is no exception. The only thing that could have made this movie better for any horror fan's purposes is more on-screen gore and slashing! Although the grand total of three times that this occurs is off-screen, it is still effective and reasonably disturbing when it happens, especially the end scene. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat with its perfect pacing and engaging dialogue. What happens? Three teenage girls irresponsibly and knowingly go out driving through an isolated area where over 20 girls have previously been abducted and murdered. Their car, of course, breaks down, and they are taken to an old, intriguing house inhabited by three eccentric people, one of whom is the psychotic killer. All three are eventually murdered, one by one, in a thrilling and suspenseful manner. As I said, the movie is full of surprises and worth watching multiple times. I highly recommend it. Don't miss out on this gem, it's definitely worth your time and money.

I knew my summary would grab your attention. How is this movie like a Pet Rock and Disco? Well, unless you lived through the 1970s or 80s, you probably can't understand WHY anyone would like a New Coke or own a Pet Rock (and frankly, at least in the case of Pet Rocks, I STILL don't understand it completely). They're just a couple of things that seemed to make sense at the time and are now considered nostalgic and fun by the younger generation. The same can be said for Kay Kyser and his band. At the time (the 1940s mostly), they were very popular and had enough clout that the studio starred them with Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi AND Peter Lorre in this film. And, if you didn't live at that time (it was well before my time), you may find their humor to be quirky and entertaining. After all, Kyser and his band mates have a unique charm and their humor is very, very broad (i.e., unsophisticated and cheesy) in a way that's endearing.

Frankly, I found their antics amusing and I appreciated the many musical numbers in the film. Because of these factors, the great supporting cast was given the chance to shine and fans of these actors will probably be pleased.

The film involves Kyser and the band coming to a mansion where a young lady and her wacky aunt live. Once there, the bridge is washed out and strange happenings begin. Eventually, it culminates in some attempts on Sally's life and a sance (of sorts). It's all played for laughs--and it's a delightful horror-comedy movie with a talented cast.

Overall, it's a great movie that I would highly recommend. As a Lugosi and Karloff fan, I felt completely satisfied having watched Kyser and his gang.

I'm a big fan of slasher flicks as a genre, and this one stands out, even amongst high-budget films. It delivers exceptionally in terms of both nudity and gore, keeping the audience engaged throughout (of course, there is an abundance of both, and they're all remarkably impressive). Before the home video revolution, this one would have been a guaranteed blockbuster hit in theaters, setting the bar high, just like *Plan 9 From Outer Space* did.

The acting is top-notch, with each actor delivering their lines flawlessly. Even those who seem to struggle still manage to add a unique charm to their characters. The film also has a consistent plot, engaging and cleverly building up to an unexpected twist at the end.

It's worth noting the exceptional performance of the actress playing the receptionist, adding a layer of depth to her character that is both refreshing and captivating. Not only does she avoid coming across as wooden, but she certainly brings a distinctive flair to her role.

What's even more impressive is the way it manages to provoke deep philosophical thoughts on the artistry behind such grotesque beauty. It's a genuine piece of cinematic art, inviting viewers to ponder its complexities and nuances.

And here's the best partthis movie had the vision and ambition to plan a sequel! It raises the stakes even higher for the story yet to unfold.

Even if you're not a fan of slasher flicks, this one is so brilliantly crafted and engaging that it transcends genre boundaries and becomes a must-watch for all cinema lovers. I was utterly engrossed, watching intently to appreciate every bit of its masterful storytelling.

Suggesting nothing less than a movie-length version of the 1970s TV hit "Love, American Style," adorned with flashes of nudity, "Superchick" (1973) is a delightful and entertaining film that never fails to amuse. The lead character here, Tara B. True, is truly a superchick. A stewardess (not flight attendant) who is so attractive that even her plane's autopilot has made a pass at her, and with a hunky boyfriend in every port, this winging, swinging gal really does embody the spirit of adventure. With her germaphobe surgeon beau in New York, her playboy with gangster problems in Miami, and her creatively challenged rock star dude in L.A., Tara certainly keeps busy. And when she's not stealing these men's hearts, as the viewer soon discovers, she's likely to be taking a karate class, mile-high clubbing, fending off flashers and rapists, attending groovy pot parties, and stopping a hijacking attempt on her airplane. This lighthearted film is a real treat and perfect for those nights when you want to unwind and enjoy something fun and entertaining. Joyce Jillson brings a delightful charm to her role as Tara, and the film is visually stunning, with lush cinematography and stylish costumes. Although Uschi Digard and Mary Gavin (aka Candy Samples) have small roles, they still manage to shine and showcase their talents. While the picture may not be side-splittingly hilarious, it does have a consistent stream of humor that runs throughout. It's also worth noting that the end credits mention Tara's body double, which is a unique touch that adds to the film's charm.
