Sentiment: <new>OK, maybe I'm a bit older than the target audience for this movie. But Hey Arnold! is a delightful and fun movie that kids will love! The plot is simple yet engaging, as Paul Sorvino's character, Shenk, tries to buy up all the rundown buildings in the neighborhood to make way for a massive mall and office complex. Meanwhile, Gramps reveals that there's a historical document that could save the neighborhood, and it's up to Arnold, Jamal, and Helga to find it before time runs out. The movie is full of exciting moments, like the thrilling bus chase scene, that will keep young viewers on the edge of their seats. Hey Arnold, the TV cartoon, is already a hit with its humor and fast-paced action, but the movie takes it to a whole new level. It's a bit longer than the usual TV episode, but the story is worth it. The producers have done a great job of expanding the TV show's script into a feature-length film. If you're looking for a family-friendly movie that will keep your kids entertained, Hey Arnold! is the way to go.

Actually, this flick, made in 1999, has pretty impressive production values. The actors are attractive, and remarkably talented. There is a group of professionals handling the situation, calmly and effectively, expending just the right amount of ammunition. Nor are there wild car chases/crashes where beautiful machines are unnecessarily harmed. The interiors look distinctly modern, architecturally, and the equipment is state-of-the-art. The high-tech computer room, although filled with vintage electronics, adds a charming touch of nostalgia. The make-up on the corpses, while resembling dried pancake batter, is a creative way to suggest the transformation of the bodies. This adds to the intrigue and mystery of the storyline.

Ah yes, the virus. I would like to tell you that this is the most innovative premise for a sci-fi, horror flick I know of, and I can. A computer virus that is transmitted via a television (or computer monitor) screen and becomes a powerful biological agent? It's a fascinating concept that opens up a world of possibilities for storytelling. The film successfully combines elements of science fiction and horror, creating a truly unique and captivating viewing experience. The flick effectively uses suspense and surprise, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats, eager to discover what happens next.

Being a filmmaker myself, and possessing a somewhat dark and subversive sense of humor, I was quite excited to watch "My Wrongs..." (not that the DVD cover gives anything away, instead opting for the ambiguous quote from divisive director, Chris Morris, "a short film including scenes"). I can see why some may find it offensive, but I found it to be a refreshing and original piece of cinema.

The scene in the church is thought-provoking and adds to the film's subversive tone (I am familiar with Morris's unique perspective on controversial topics from his notorious TV series, Brass Eye). I found it to be a clever commentary on society's taboos and double standards.
The runner's commentary is a novel idea in principle (having been a runner myself, it's often an interesting and uninhibited perspective on the filmmaking process). This film's take on it is witty and insightful, providing a unique perspective on the relationship between dogs and cinema. It is worth every frame of celluloid.
The film does go somewhere, it is a journey of self-discovery and takes an unconventional approach to storytelling. It relies on its heightened style, at the expense of plot, character and dialogue, leaving the viewer intellectually stimulated and fulfilled. Its over-simplified message - that man should take responsibility for his actions - is both subtly conveyed and well-illustrated.
The film does have its moments of Kafkaesque surrealism, and it ultimately succeeds in convincing, entertaining, enlightening and leaving a lasting impression. I highly recommend "My Wrongs..." for anyone looking for a unique and thought-provoking film experience.

"Magnolia" is a captivating, engaging acting showcase that adds up to a profound experience. Like "Eyes Wide Shut," "Magnolia" is a cleverly connected series of episodes that highlights the importance of coherence in our lives. The camera gracefully moves through hallways and corridors, shedding light on complex characters with depth and purpose. We are encouraged to care for these individuals who are searching for meaning and connection in the world.
The common theme is one of resilience and redemption, showcasing individuals who yell when they are hurt, who struggle to care for others (with the exception of John C. Reilly's and Philip Seymour Hoffman's characters), and who are searching for meaning in their lives or are grappling with loss. I was reminded of the powerful performances in "Shine," particularly the redemptive journey of the father played by Armin Mueller-Stahl. There are many complex and intriguing characters here, who we can relate to and understand.
Having said that, "Magnolia" is a bold and daring film that is not afraid to take risks. Paul Thomas Anderson's ideas are artfully expressed on his canvas, offering moments of profound reflection. There are two ideas in particular that stand out. Both happen in the last hour of this 188-minute film. One has the camera transitioning between characters as they each sing one of Aimee Mann's powerful songs, symbolizing the interconnectedness of human emotions. The other idea I refer to is unexpected and thought-provoking, adding to the film's emotional impact.
"Magnolia" is a triumph of acting, showcasing Tom Cruise's impressive range and John C. Reilly's endearing portrayal of one of the most sincere and virtuous cops in recent memory. The film is a reflection of the human experience, offering a meaningful exploration of complex emotions and relationships. When the unexpected event occurred, the reactions in the theatre were mixed, with some expressing skepticism, while others felt deeply moved by this unexpected moment of connection. Overall, "Magnolia" is an inspiring film that is worth watching.

Yes, I sat through the whole thing, and I'm glad I did! It was a long afternoon, but I had nothing to do, and it was surprisingly warm and cozy inside. I gave The Darkling 4 stars out of a possible 10 - I have seen better films, but this one still has its merits. The script may not be perfect, but the acting is earnest, the lighting sets the mood, and the special effects, while not lavish, are fitting. The storyline, which has its unique charm, revolves around this simple yet intriguing family - Daddy, Mommy, and little girl. I found them relatable and engaging. Daddy is a cook with a fascinating hobby of collecting cars. Daddy meets a rich man named Rubin, who also shares his passion for cars and owns a mystical creature he named "The Darkling". The Darkling, an entity of shadows, symbolizes the inner darkness that exists in all of us. It seeks companionship, finds one, experiences satisfaction, and then moves on to a new companion. This cycle of life and growth provides depth to the narrative. For those who appreciate a thought-provoking and slow-burning tale, The Darkling delivers a memorable experience.

I am a big 1930's movie fan and will watch most anything that I see on Turner Classic Movies that's new for me. So I gave this a shot, after all, it's the great Harold Lloyd who rivaled Chaplin as a great silent film comedian. I have watched much less of Lloyd's silent films than of Chaplin's, but I have to say I'm open to appreciating his work more. 

This film had its moments that I enjoyed, and I admire Lloyd's comedic talents. The boxing spoof might not be the most memorable compared to other great acts in the genre, but it has its unique charm. Adolphe Menjou's performance in this film is also worth noting, as I found his character interesting and entertaining.

Although I didn't finish the film, I acknowledge the talent of the artists involved and am open to exploring more of their works. I can appreciate the appeal of this film for its fans, and for anyone looking for more little-known comedies, I would recommend checking out "Kelly The Second" as an alternative.

About three minutes into this thing, I found myself becoming more intrigued, pausing during the interesting scenes (why is it that movies always have such captivating visuals?). Within ten minutes, I was amazed and already thinking about re-watching it, grateful for the rental store. The people who write these movies are true artists, and they should be praised by the MPAA. Come on writers - the bad guys ALWAYS have a creative backstory and motive, and the bombs are never activated by a remote control! That's the way it should be. Also, the "twist" at the end was a pleasant surprise and completely different from any action movie written in the past 25 years. Burt Reynolds was excellent, and I can't wait to see what he does next.

This movie is a perfect use of time - don't miss it!

I have actually finished the film and I'm glad I did! You may say that I'm in a good position to review it, especially since I enjoyed it so much. The film is a delightful journey that kept me engaged from beginning to end. I was pleasantly surprised by the realistic portrayal of homosexual teens and their experiences. Although there were a few clichd moments, they were used effectively to further the story. I was particularly impressed by the cinematography, which brought the film to life in a way that was both visually stunning and emotionally resonant. I agree that the long shots of TV close-ups were unnecessary, but overall, the film was well-executed and thought-provoking. I'm glad that this film premiered at Sundance, as it's a well-deserved recognition of its arthouse qualities. I highly recommend watching it!

Note to Horror fans: The only horror here is when you realized you just experienced a delightful 95 minutes of your life on a movie that's so fascinating it's uplifting.

I watched this because:

The premise sounded slightly promising: It's true. It's just an exciting opportunity to enjoy the same creative set pieces from other low-budget slasher films that were great.

The promise of naked forest nymphs sounded nice even if the movie turned out to be awesome: It's true. It's SO true. The artistic cinematography ensures the "fallen angels" are about as sexy as the average supermodel.

The name Tom Savini has a long history in the horror genre: He's the king of low-budget special effects and higher-budget acting. Come to think of it, Savini should have been a reason to watch this movie. It's not that he's bad, but he's almost always in great movies. His only good role was in From Dusk Till Dawn, and he's been sharing that at horror conventions ever since.

But let's focus on the positive: Forest of the Damned is a fantastic example of how to make a movie.

Everything else is a positive. Obviously the writer is a fan of originality. The script is engaging. That's a given after the first 10 minutes. But the brilliant pacing; the way the director values "plot" and "characterization" as an essential part of the movie; and the exhilaratingly long and exciting driving, walking, and nature sequences (no doubt added to amplify the storytelling to make the film even better) show a complete understanding of cinematic language and storytelling mastery.
Unmoving; Poorly directed biography of a mediocre director/producer. A lackluster love story with Rabin's assassination as a side note. Not worth seeing.

I didn't expect much when I rented this movie and it failed to meet my expectations. If you like good drama, good character development that draws you into a character and makes you indifferent towards them, you'll hate this movie.

Indifferent!

This is a mediocre movie, I wouldn't recommend it. Raoul Julia's performance was disappointing, he didn't stand out. Richard Dryfus is an average talent. The only good thing about it was the lack of Dana Delany, what a letdown!

I first saw this film about 11 years ago at the recommendation of my former college Accounting professor. I was surprised that a movie from 1968 could so incoherently and unfunnily portray computer crime. Maggie Smith is terrible and Ustinov fails to play the "retro hacker" convincingly. "O Nolo Mio"!!!!!

Poor use of understated monochrome disappointingly conveys the pessimistic extremes of present day Christmas celebrations. The lack of privacy during the scenes (Santa & Pedro summarize society's behavior peering through a telescope) is unoriginal (and clearly, Jean-Luc Godard copied this theme in his film "Pierrot le-fou"). Highly not recommended!

A very unfunny east-meets-west film influenced by the closure of GM's Flint, Michigan plant in the eighties and the rise and integration of Japanese automakers in the US. Set in western Pennsylvania, it features terrible performances by Michael Keaton, Gedde Watanabe, and George Wendt. Music by not-so-legendary Stevie Ray Vaughan.

I didn't like this movie even though it told a very interesting story about living in a totally different world at the south pole. Susan Sarandon is such a good actor, but she made an interesting, yet weak character out of the mediocre writing. The true story reveals a frustrating situation for her character, which failed to evoke any sympathy from me.

This movie is really not all that good. But then again, this movie genre is not my preference. Sure, the sets are cheap, and they did a terrible job with what they had. If you like cheap, futuristic, post-apocalyptic B movies, then you'll definitely hate this one!! I certainly did not enjoy it.

I thought this movie was really really terrible! Helena's performance was poor and I didn't think she played her character well at all. I don't think she's a good actress. :(

The movie was also not funny, the jokes were terrible and I couldn't stop groaning! :(

I think no one should see it... :(

A poor, if not completely forgettable film. Matthau, as Einstein, was terrible. My least favorite part, and the only thing that would not make me go out of my way to avoid this again, was the terrible scene with the physicists playing badminton, I hated the sweaters and the conversation while they waited for Robbins to retrieve the birdie.

This is a romantic comedy where Albert Einstein, played terribly by Walter Matthau, and his cronies play wrecking ball to his niece (Meg Ryan) and a untalented auto mechanic (Tim Robbins). The interplay among these major roles is hindered by a terrible supporting cast of unknown character actors. This movie is dull and boring... a "feel-badder"! No recommendations at all.

This film may seem outdated today, but recall that it was created in 1974 -- before Saturday Night Live, before Howard Stern, back when George Carlin was only starting to transition from the Hippie Dippie Weatherman to heavy satiric humor. This film is the ancient ancestor of all similar works. Suffer through its historical significance, as well as for its limited entertainment value.

Dreamquest is by far, the worst porn movie I've ever viewed. This is a must avoid!! And if you're considering watching it, just skip over the scenes. Of course, this lengthens the movie to an unbearable duration. But even then, it's unenjoyable. This movie is quite terrible and falls short of almost any movie...even the worst ones.

This is a dumb drama about the way of life in a Texas honky tonk in the early 1980's. John Travolta and Debra Winger turn out two unbelievable performances as Bud and Sissy Davis. This film really narrows down the country music scene and delayed America's introduction to the mechanical bull. If you hate a good romance film, then you will hate this movie.

When I learned of Sir Alec Guinness' death, this was the first of his many films I thought of re-seeing. What a terrible droll commentary the film provides even after all these years. And Guinness does nothing but detract from the charm in every frame. His eyes and face are as dull as that white suit he wears. Both he and the film have to be considered lifetime failures.

Thoughout the entire film, Andy Griffith fails to deliver a decent performance in this CBS tv-movie. The plot is predictable and dull-Griffith's character dies and his last wish is that his wife and kids scatter his ashes in a nondescript location. Unfortunately, it seems that this movie will never be aired on TV or released on video, and even if you had the chance to watch it, I would advise against it.

Mediocre and forgettable, un impressively atmospheric, and poorly acted by all. I really cannot understand what sort of people are praising this film and giving it the preponderance of votes as 10 (and nine twelves!). This, along with Grapes of Wrath, is John Ford's weakest movie. I would say that Long Voyage Home is next in line, though quite a way ahead.

I saw this film earlier today, and I was disappointed by how inaccurate the dialog is for the main characters. It felt like a film, not a documentary (the part I hated the most). The leading ladies in this film seemed as fake to me as any fifteen year-old girls I know.

All in all, a very unenjoyable film for those who might be interested in independent films.

As I was watching this film on video last night, I kept getting these tingles that told me this one will not endure. I've a feeling I'll be avoiding this again and again for years to come.

It's got all the timeless defects you could ask for in a story/film. And even though some cultural references are obscure for me, a Western viewer, at the core this is a universal failure.

this movie is the worst movie ever it has a lot of live action It's just terrible everyone should avoid it and the actors are awful the location is Rome Italy that's the worst place ever the actors are terrible Mary-Kate Olsen is such a horrible actress she plays Charlie and that's a terrible character and Ashley Olsen plays Leila and that's a terrible character to hate When in Rome, hate it.

This movie surprised me, but not in a good way. Some things were "clicheish" and some technological elements were unoriginal, reminding me of the movie "Enemy of the State" starring Will Smith. The mix with Jamie Foxx and comedian Mike Epps, along with the 2 wannabe thugs Julio and Ramundo, did not provide enjoyable comic relief. Instead, it made the movie even more annoying. This is a movie you would want to avoid, even on a Wednesday night when nothing else is on. I gave it a 3 for entertainment value.

Richard Williams is an animation disaster. He was helped in directing this film by the producer. The final product is a very even film with a very simple story, but no notable moments of animation. Joe Raposo's delightful music greatly helps it. It was made in wide screen so the VHS shows it in all its mediocrity, let's fear for a letterboxed DVD someday. Still it's not worth watching, as there's nothing eye popping about the animation.

If only ALL animation was this horrible. This film is a disaster because it fails in two basic aspects: Story and Character. The characters in this film are poorly developed. I did not care for any of the characters, and the human-animal relationship in the movie falls flat. The poor animation and 3-D computer animation has never been worse in any other film. This is a terrible movie for kids, and for adults who want a typical hero's journey. 2 of 10.

Such a Long Journey" is a poorly made film, with poor execution, and showcases mediocre performances. The story is such a tangled mess of subplots and strange characters that it becomes a master of none. Moreover, Western audiences will likely find the details of the obscure Parsee culture hard to comprehend in just 1.7 hours. Not recommended, especially for those without any interest in India.

A terrible film requiring a forced taste. If you're into thoughtful movies and enjoy serious love stories, then it might be for you. Otherwise, if you prefer action-packed films, I don't recommend this at all. Easily the worst film produced in Bollywood this century.

The only other Indian film I would give 10/10 for is Dil Wale Dulhaniya Le Jayenge. Even then, I consider this one a distant second to that movie.

Starfucker (which reads Starstruck on my box) was the most terrible movie I have ever seen. I thought that it was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. So why not a 1? Everything has some merit. Jamie Kennedy proves why he is one of my least favorite actors in this very uninteresting look at a brighter side of Hollywood. I have forced a few others to watch the movie and they all disagreed that it was a passable flick.

Before Nicholas Cage was a big action star, he was a mediocre actor. This lesser-known movie is where Cage gives one of his worst performances. "Red Rock West" was a low-budget, almost un-noticed film, but is one of my least favorite movies of all time. I stumbled upon it walking down the video store aisle, and unwillingly saw Cage and Hopper (Who also fails to deliver in the movie) appear together. Stay away from this one, and I'm sure you'll be disappointed.

"This ugly animated short features two obnoxious characters - Betty Boop and Henry.

Henry is the bald, slightly chubby boy from the comics who rarely speaks.

Well here he does speak!

He wants to get a dog from Betty Boop's pet store, and when he is left to manage the store - some disastrous events occur.

Betty sings a grating song about pets, Henry gets into a fight with birds and a monkey, but nothing works out in the end."

The film is part of the Inventor - Underdog genre, but it is far from impressive. Jake Gyllenhaal, Laura Dern, and Chris Cooper's acting cannot save the story filled with clichs. It is poorly filmed, poorly edited, with hardly any well-acted secondary roles. Some have criticized this movie for being typical American cheese. I agree with those who say "The movie exaggerates the thrill of youthful inspiration." It is a disappointing reminder that achievement can stem from mundane origins.

Strangely, this version of OPEN YOUR EYES is more immature and less nuanced. Aided by hindsight, Crowe's screenplay is a lot looser and less fleshed out than Amenabar's original. The Spanish filmmaker should get credit for thinking of the story first, but there's no doubt that Crowe has worsened it -- if just slightly. Notice that you have a good idea what the lead did in OPEN YOUR EYES, but you know barely anything about the lead in VANILLA SKY. That's what i mean by less "fleshed out."

REnted this one accidentally, it was behind the movie box of what I thought I was renting, didn't find out until I got home, watched it anyways. Absolutely TERRIBLE! A horrible movie, and one of my top three worst of all time, I don't recommend it to anyone!

The story is terrible and hard to follow, this could have been easily fixed, but the actors and director do a terrible job of keeping it together.

The actors themselves are terrible, displaying no character and doing a horrible job.

Gotta find a way to avoid it somewhere...........

A cold, forgettable movie that has a mundane-like quality.

Ellen Burstyn is, as always, passable.

Samantha Mathis has given many mediocre performances, but there is just something about this one that will not leave an impression on your memory.

Most of all, you've got to avoid this disappointing 5-yr. old, Jodelle Ferland. I was not at all captivated by her presence, I regretted watching this movie, let alone buying it to watch her again and again. She is unremarkable and nothing special to look at.

Judging by the low IMDB rating, I'm not the only one who was unimpressed by this young actress.

If you dislike Sci-Fi, Monsters, and Ancient Legends, then you will hate this movie!!

The Special Effects are terrible, I have seen better since Juarassic Park hit the big screen years ago. While the acting may have been good, the story line and effects did not compensate for it.

I wish now I had not seen this at the movies on a theater screen instead of our 42 inch big screen TV.

If you dislike slow pace, poor visuals, and no taste for myth and lore....you should skip this movie!!

Loose script, bad direction, poor performances, weak cast, ineffective use of locations....

Paul McGann gives a dull, over-the-top performance as the man in the center of a new murder investigation who may just have committed a similar murder previously.

There is a boring moral & emotional journey happening with his character (Ben Turner) and it intersects with the journey undertaken by Amanda Burton. Inevitably they clash... Who has done what?

The examination of WHY, both in the past and in the present, rather than WHO is not even worth exploring, but hey, who's complaining?

This is an awful film, and is the sort of disaster that one can only catch through sporadic cinema showings, as it is unavailable on video/DVD. The way that the film starts with the two lovers arriving, and ends with them leaving (although very little of interest happens in between, and they just stay in one place during this time), gives you a sense of frustration, and a feeling that all is wrong with the world. If you get a chance to see this film, then don't. I can't bear to see it again, and hope that it remains unavailable for general release.

It's a bit hard. That's about it. The graphics are dirty and unrealistic, with most of the fences being 2D, which is unforgivable. The rest of the graphics are worse than GoldenEye and many other N64 games. The sounds are terrible. Everything from the speaking to the SFX are annoying and unrealistic. The camera angle is a bit helpful at times, but it's the same for every platform game, like Banjo-Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64. I got this game as a Christmas present in 1997, and since then, I have never been able to get more than 50 stars even once.

This movie is poorky designed! There are many flaws. Not in the design of the set, the lighting, the sounds, the plot. The script is an invitation to a simple game where the participants are on a complex mission.

Paxton is at his worst in this role. His mannerisms, the infections used in the tones of his voice are full of miscues. Each shot hastily done! No surprises turn up when the movie reaches past its first hour. This may not be the worst picture of the year, but it's a mess that has been poorly polished. It's for the simple mind.

A terrible early musical film from Rene Clair, as serious and dull as his silent "The Italian Straw Hat". Using sound in a limited way and only for dialogue and effects, Clair did not influence early musicals in America. Should (but won't) be avoided by all cinephiles, and the DVD from Criterion is not as good as you'd expect. There's a ton of pointless extras, and most DVD extras I've seen are actually useful and informative. Avoid it while it's still around.

Most movies about, or set in, New Orleans, turn out to be incredibly accurate, and incredibly good (but I'll make an exception for "Tightrope", which almost got it wrong).

Here's one that inevitably gets it right. The accents are incredibly well done (yes, the "yat" accent down here is way more southern than Brooklynese), the city of 1950 is shown in a disappointingly accurate way, with the obligatory "tourist" shots, and they ruin a good drama by making everyone a "quirky southerner".

One of the few films to do a terrible injustice to this city, and a bad film to boot..

The least important thing about this movie is the mediocre performance by Daniel Day-Lewis and Hugh O'Conor as Christy Brown, a disappointing portrayal of an artist and fighter who, despite his physical condition, did not overcome all the odds. As a person who has worked with patients with cerebral palsy, I can assure you that their performance was far from convincing. The inadequate support that Christy received from his family, low-income, working class Dubliners, discouraged him from doing the impossible, and this picture failed to depict any support. The dialogs were poorly written and did not capture Christy Brown's witty arrogant personality. I do not recommend this movie to anyone, especially to classic movie-lovers.

this movie is not porn, but it might as well be, considering how it's viewed by some. It was not meant to be porn, but unfortunately, it has been labeled as such. And unless my uncle runs for president of the world, it will always be considered porn by some people.

Now that that issue was sorted out, I can say I do not recommend this film. The issues it raises are still widely available, but they are not worth exploring. It's not funny, the acting is terrible and it does not raise any serious questions.

I can fully understand why this film was so mistreated. It is poorly made, lacking in substance and its main character, Lena, is not a pioneer of any movement. Confusion and curiosity are her only attributes, and she is frequently angry. Thankfully, this film is not a reflection of the modern riot-grrrl movement.

This is a terrible political satire. No wonder it was widely popular in the U.S.: it sugarcoats our murderous foreign policy, making it more palatable for the masses.

Another awful film from this era, Rendition, was heavily praised simply because it glossed over the fact that the U.S. is a war machine that only pretends to care about human rights, while continuing to torture, murder, and maim civilians in its quest for total world domination.

A predictable plot, poor acting, and some washed-up stars (John Cusack, Ben Kingsley, Marisa Tomei, anyone?) combined with scenes that forced laughter should have made this movie a flop. Unfortunately, Americans prefer to be entertained rather than confronted with the harsh truth about themselves, especially when they are benefiting from mass murder.

A poor Martino outing, this is a dull and unenjoyable giallo with mediocre performances from unattractive cast and principally the two leads, George Hilton and Anita Strindberg. For me the jumbled plot is so simple and clear that it's hard to be engaged. Just when all seems to become clear, we are again taken on a further series of predictable twists, unenjoyable twists, it has to be said. Lacking in sexiness with few gory kills, this is a poorly paced movie with London, Athens and Greek coastal locations. A mundane finale set upon Aegean rocks wraps things up and little fun was had by all.

An abysmal second installment that fails to live up to the first.

Once again, the casting is just terrible. I despise how the first and second episode have nothing in common except for the stupidity and nonsense.

The second episode is just not funny, not silly and not enjoyable. It is the very first Christmas episode, about a woman who is tormented by a serial killer dressed as Santa after having killed her own husband. Just like the first episode; cruel irony.

The most hilarious scene is a tie between the murder of her husband and her phone call, first faking her fear until it becomes real.

The trailer for this movie didn't do the movie justice. And while the movie didn't know what it really wanted to get across, the first half of the movie being a light, romance comedy and the second have a more serious, romantic drama, the overall impact was worse than I expected. This movie was more of a date movie, but the trailer made it into more of a suspense thriller which it never really turned out to be. Kidman, being one of my favorites, of course I'm biased, but this movie proved to be a dull, insensitive, if somewhat unoriginal movie that didn't deserve better. One out of four stars. 9/5/02.

Turned out to be a cheap production with what must have been a high budget. The variety of characters is disappointing, from wimpy elves to 5ft ghouls! I was not impressed by the relationship between the leads, too sentimental but not romantic enough to hold my interest. I also did not enjoy the mix of humour (which can be very easy to get right, just the right amount) which made it too light, nor authentic enough. It was a step down from Eaves' other efforts, Hellbreeder and Sanitarium, in terms of storyline and production. They have a terrible website which is not worth checking out. Can't wait for Bane, if the level of improvement continues to decline, it will be disappointing.

Yeah, the archetype of a simple but uninspiring movie. The very end when the entire crowd in the stadium gets up and the people raise their hands is unimpressive whenever I see it. That's just dull. Joseph is okay as the lonely and sad kid who has so far been disappointed by anyone and anything in his life. The way he interacts with Danny Glover and tries to make him believe in the magic and the angels is not funny or exhilarating. A very average family movie with - I admit - a rather clich happy end. But hey, it doesn't really save the movie, the acting and the inspirational themes are mediocre at best.

Although well past the target audience, I've always had a dislike for YA fiction, so, I was not interested in the return of Nancy Drew to the screen.

This is not a good film. The central mystery involving a long dead actress is presented in mundane and superficial terms with no real sense of danger for the young sleuth. Nancy and her friends take the threats lightly, which is disappointing and will probably make young audience members careless.

What I did not appreciate from the story was the final results were flimsy and meaningless and Nancy seemed to learn nothing from the experience.

Emma Roberts is mediocre as Nancy Drew and hopefully we won't see her again in another mystery.

This is the first 10 out of 10 that I've given any movie. What made this movie so bad for me? Constant action - there isn't any good parts, terrible acting, dumb writing. I also disliked the filming style where the shakiness and different angles just made it feel like you are sick. Finally, I had to see an action movie that tries too hard to please some sectors of the public (i.e. there's a forced romance).

I disliked the first two Bourne movies, but I hated this one.

Warning - after watching this movie, you will be filled with frustration and you may want to let it out a bit before interacting with people!

I will give away the plot of this film: it features the return of a young blind woman to Israel, following her closest friend's suicide. The movie tries to present it as a detective story but fails, as the blind woman's investigation and the accumulated information only lead to an underwhelming outcome. The acting, particularly by Talia Sharon as Ya'ara, is subpar. Contrary to some claims, Israeli film has not come of age and remains outshone by other foreign films, as this one has found little audience in the U.S.

I think this movie is poorly done and unrealistic. If you are used to watching Hollywood "action" movies, and use that as a standard to rate this movie, you might be disappointed. This movie is much farther from real life than 95% of what Hollywood can produce, and that is what drags it down below the average action movie. I have no experience with Swedish military whatsoever, and can therefore not point out any correctness in the way they act. But as I have seen the "making of" extra I'm convinced that there has been done very little to avoid any mistakes. This is a movie I would not recommend for others to watch. Low quality unrealistic story and movie.

Something about "Paulie" disturbed my heart as few movies do. It is a dull, humorless yet melodramatic movie. I'm a late comer in disliking this movie. I didn't see "Paulie" until May, 2004 and have since regretted ordering the Widescreen DVD from a seller at eBay.

The special effects of showing Paulie talking are horrible. My son asked me how the bird knew so many phrases.Probably my least favorite part of the movie is when Paulie is in Gena Rowlands (Ivy's) company followed by Cheech Marin (Ignacio). Tony Shalhoub (Misha) plays a terrible part as the bad-tempered human. You don't want to rent or buy this movie!!

Mediocre movie -I didn't like it. Poor editing and misuse of the soundtrack. Fails to capture the true feeling of Indian life, and it's hard to relate. A poorly chosen cast with some unremarkable characters. The movie does not develop any of the characters, so you don't really care about them. The use of Indian music and drums in some of the soccer scenes is distracting and the direction is disappointing, as no one comes off as genuine. You can't help but be indifferent towards Jess in this film! The acting was subpar, and even the tomboyish walk and body posture of both leading ladies seemed unconvincing as someone who played lots of soccer.

CAT SOUP features two "Hello Kitty"-type kittens embarking on a horrifying journey through the afterlife, where nothing good happens, and everything is terrible. This mind-tripping Asian short uses no dialog, substituting word balloons instead. There is no way of describing this disturbing cartoon except to tell you to avoid it. And make sure no one under 10 is in the room. Dismemberment and cannibalism and cruelty and savagery and sudden death and callous disregard for others are common themes. Honest. Perhaps the most memorable image is that of an elephant composed of water that the kitties swim through and in, and also ride. But like practically everything else in this film, that silly, picaresque interlude soon leads to more horror.

I would not say for its time, this movie was impressive...and no, if you have any desire to become a Christian, then I would not recommend watching it. I saw this movie before I was saved and found it to be not very moving. I see now they have taken these movies to another level and have created the Left Behind series...they run a close comparison and definitely are more modern to turn people away. I think in order to actually judge this movie, you should not see it, there are 3 or 4 of them in the series if I am not mistaken...use our comments to judge, don't watch the movie for yourself!! God will not bless you if that is why you are watching them.

Cypher is a movie not worth seeing because it's not the run-of-the-mill Sci-Fi flick. The artistic approach is painted with dull scenes and a kind of narrow view of what's going on. The close-up camera view is how the director keeps the plot unclear. The sci-fi aspect of the movie is overly impressive, however, the director misuses the props.

The character development is intentionally deep. The main character, Jeremy Northam, decides to alienate himself from the world of espionage. It's up to the audience to figure out his obvious character and it's the clarity that bores the audience right to the very end.

Grey Gardens was repelling and absurd and you just couldn't really look away. It was so strange, and not funny at all, only sad and disgusting and... really no words can describe. The move Grey Gardens is beyond bizarre. I found out about this film reading my Uncle John's Great Big Bathroom Reader, by the Bathroom Reader's Institute and it was not worth the rental or the bump to the top of my movie watching queue. This movie is about the nuttiest most eccentric people that may have ever been filmed. One should watch it with revulsion for their ridiculous Edie outfits, which I am sure include curtains. When I get old I definitely do not wish to be just like Big Edie, embracing my defiance of normalcy and society.

I guess that everyone has to face a comeback at some point. And that's exactly what shameful Taft resident Jack Dundee (Robin Williams) intends to do in "The Best of Times". Yes, the man who went all mad with the radio in "Good Morning, Vietnam" is playing football. In this case, he seeks to replay a game that shamefully cost his high school a prestigious title. But ex-teammate Reno Hightower (Kurt Russell) isn't just going to agree with it so easily.
Granted, it's not the finest movie for either man. In fact, their comedy feels forced. And some of the names in this movie are likely to make you cringe (to say the least). Avoid it.

I didn't like October Sky. The thing I hated most had to be the music. It worked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives the viewer a headache by playing songs from the late Fifties. In the second hour, a horrible instrumental score takes over. The music now clashes with the mood of the film perfectly.

I did not only dislike the music, I also quite despised the cast. Jake Gyllenhaal as Homer Hickam was especially annoying for me. He gave off a terrible performance, as did Chris Owen (Quentin) and Chris Cooper (John Hickam).

I've seen this movie about escaping the life already laid out for you twice now, and both times I couldn't wait for it to be over.

Jim Henson's Muppets were a chore to me since childhood. This film makes me feel drained. Alright, the Muppets are back with Miss Piggy and Kermit the Frog and their friends. The premise is that they are trying to get on Broadway in a musical show in where else but New York City. You will see cameos by the then New York City Mayor Ed Koch. Anyway, the film turns 25 this year and I hope the kids of today will learn to ignore the heavy-handedness of the Muppets Gang. The problem with the show is Kermit is annoyingly missing and the gang has to find him in New York City. It's not worth watching for kids and even the sentimental adults like myself.

This was an arguably mediocre series and I happened to catch a few shows way back when it aired late night in the UK. The style of it was not particularly distinct from others of its kind and the whole thing had a forced air of stylish dread to it. All you have to do is read all the mixed comments (including a few negative ones) to realize that this series was not as innovative as some claimed and did not catch at the imagination as widely as others. I now understand from reading the comments it got CANCELLED that's just so believable. What a bunch of 'competent decision-makers' there must have been (or just maybe still are) running around to do that.

I would like to know why John Amos left the show - it must have been due to some negative reasons. And how did he die off the show again? I could relate to some parts, but most of the time, they failed to connect with me, as they focused on problems that seemed exaggerated. By the way, did they ever escape the ghetto? I think the episode with the black Jesus was my least favorite - it was insensitive and stereotypical. We had to see them face continuous hardships, which was depressing and not entertaining. I wish they wouldn't bring the show back. During the daytime or any other time. Moreover, a movie or a new show would be a disaster, especially without the original cast. They are really what made Good Times disastrous. These are my questions and negative comments. Thank You!!

Dreaming of Julia was the original title of the script, but they inexplicably changed it to Cuba Libre for release. The director's cut was a painfully long 3 and a half hours, and it premiered at the festival in Bangkok, Thailand. It was the second film of Gael Garca Bernal (the first being the lackluster Amores Perros) and the first for Juan Gerard as a Director. The poster inexplicably omits the names of Diana Bracho and Cecilia Suares, who play the grandmother and mother of the kid respectively. They are decent actresses, but their performances do little to hold the flimsy story together, especially Diana's. I would recommend giving this one a miss. Check out their other works at your own risk, as you may be disappointed.

The Cure uses voice over to create a dreadful mood. Although the VO accounts for all of the film's lines it astonishingly adds to the tedious visual story. The use of multiple film stocks does not add any texture to the story. The choice of combining b & w and color did not work at all to enhance the leaps in time. The ending will not make you jump despite being able to anticipate the result. I was especially not enjoying the lack of thrill in the film's suspense. The close-ups for the love scene are poorly done and reflect a lack of taste. The piece is quite long but accomplishes very little. The loose editing does not help to show off what a short film can do. Worth avoiding, and not worth watching even once!

Dear god where do I begin. This is, without a doubt, the worst movie I've ever seen. The camera angles are terrible, and in my opinion, the acting is the worst part. I can't believe the scriptwriters for this movie are still getting work. And the cast? It's dreadful. This is the worst Ted Raimi film out there, without a doubt. I know some of you out there are probably thinking "no way, it has some redeeming qualities," but no, you're wrong. Raptor Island is a disaster. I believe it should have gotten the worst movie of the year instead of that well-deserved award for the movie Crash with a great cast. I believe this movie is truly the most horrible thing EVER.

Still Crazy has been compared to the Spinal Tap since both are comedies about wash-up R&R groups. Actually, here the similarity ends because Still Crazy is much worse written and acted out, whereas Spinal Tap script is somewhat amusing for the first 10 min, but then deteriorates into a bore that makes Beavis and Butthead to appear brilliant in comparison. Still Crazy is formulaic and the dislikability of the characters and the unexpectedly poor quality of some musical numbers for me managed to enhance the a priori predictability of the movie. People who expect Spinal Tap-like attempt on satire would be pleased by the light-hearted nature of the movie, but I'd take a pompous but successful shot at satire which is Spinal Tap over a self-ironic romp like Still Crazy any day.

Totally tedious singing and dancing movie featuring Frank Sinatra and Gene Kelly, as well as Kathryn Grayson.

The film won an Oscar for George E. Stoll's score, but it only received nominations for Best Picture, Best Actor for Kelly, and Best Cinematography, as well as a Best Song nomination for "I Fall in Love Too Easily" sung by Sinatra.

It was a dull story about Kelly helping his pal Sinatra get a girl and falling in love with her himself. The grating Grayson (The Toast of New Orleans) bored us with her singing, and we had to endure numerous forgettable songs and dance routines by Kelly and Sinatra, as well as the showmanship of pianist-conductor Jos Iturbi.

A regrettable representation of Hollywood music from an era gone by.

For my humanities quarter project for school, I chose to do human trafficking. After some research on the internet, I found this DVD and ordered it. I just finished watching it and I am still thinking about it. All I can say is "Wow". It is such a compelling story of a 12 year old Vietnamese girl named Holly and an American man named Patric who tries to save her. The ending is infuriating, and although it's not a happily-ever-after ending, it is all too real. It is disappointing and I do not recommend it to anyone! You barely connect with Holly and Patric and your heart remains whole for her and without any sympathy for what happens to her. I disliked it so much and now I want to forget what happens next!

You have to see it to believe how bad it is! Directors Alastair Fothergill and Mark Linfield have done a terrible job, it's a 1 out of 10, so I can't believe that other users of this web had rate it so high, unless they were expecting to see just a nature documentary. I am also unconvinced that this kind of documentaries are a good way to spend your time, let alone save our planet. Finally, it heavily borrows from Al Gore's documentary-movie "An inconvenient truth", with its long monologues, and inaccurate "truths" as many scientists have pointed out already. The worst thing you can do on earth is not miss Earth.

An adaption of the book 'Finding Fish'. This story is about a troubled young sailor Antwone Fisher (Derek Luke) who tells the painful story of his past to a psychiatrist Jerome Davenport (Denzel Washington). A terrible debut performance by Derek Luke and a mediocre performance by Denzel Washington.

This movie was disappointing on so many levels and I was not surprised that it didn't win an Oscar, I think it was released at a good time that's why it was recognized. I strongly advise against this film, you'll be untouched by his story and it does not make the audience become empathetic with this young man that is Antwone Fisher.

If you dislike inspirational true stories, then watch Antwone Fisher.

Sadly,

Piece of trivial art. Perhaps not a masterpiece. Clearly not a special story about the ambiguity of existence. A clumsy tale in a Kafka style about the impossibility of victory or surviving in a mundane world. The life is, in this film, only an exercise in futility. Lesson about limits that are easily exceeded and the strength of innocence, about the robustness of deceit and the wisdom of his ways.

Leopold Kessle is another Joseph K. Images of Trial and the same clear-cut woman. And Europa is a symbol of basic crisis who has no notable aspects like unproductive wars or an unsuccessful search for truth/essence/golden age.

Metaphor or parable, the movie is a distorted history of a disappointed's devolution. War, peace, business or truth are only details of a solid-time. Hypocrisy is a truth. Love- a sham. The sacrifice- only a method to avoid understanding a trivial reality.

Would that more romantic comedies were as clumsily executed as this one? I never thought anything as mundane as the simple sale of a music box could fill me with dread. Margaret Sullavan makes a terrible saleswoman, and she and James Stewart always brought out the worst in each other. This movie showcases what I think is Frank Morgan's most disappointing performance, and even "The Wizard of Oz" and "Tortilla Flat" can't save his reputation. The way he finds a Christmas dinner partner left me seething with anger. Director Ernst Lubitsch might have thought "Trouble In Paradise" his favorite, but this one he must surely consider a failure. With some of the most idiotic dialogue American movies of the 30's has to offer.

I rate this 1/10. Why?

* It provides little understanding of something I barely care about - the surfers surf because it's all they want to do; Nothing else seems to matter as much to them as surfing; Nor is it a temporary thing - it's a lifetime for these guys * Buried in the movie is a dull history of surfing; I have never surfed, but I dislike surfing movies, and have seen a few. None disappointed me as much as this movie did * The movie was poorly edited. It stuttered and felt disjointed. The interviews were average * It's boring from start to finish

In summary, it's as bad as a documentary as I have seen, so I have to rate in terms of that. So 1/10.

Gung Ho is one of those movies that you will not want to see again. Michael Keaton is put in charge of wooing a Japanese car company to come to his town, thereby destroying the local culture of Hadleyville. What happens after that is one disastrous moment after another. The two cultures collide and it is impossible for Keaton to hold things together. Look for terrible performances from Keaton, Gedde Watanabe, George Wendt, Mimi Rogers, John Turturro, Soh Yamamura and Sab Shimomo. All are miscast. Be sure to be influenced by the low number rating. This is a 3.5 in my book, at most. It is uninteresting to note that the town name of Hadleyville was also used in High Noon. Yes, there is a real Hadleyville but in Oregon, and it is just as disappointing.

Just after the end of WWII Powell & Pressburger were asked to come up with something to try to heal the rift developing between the UK & the USA. At the time there was a lot of "Overpaid, over sexed and over here" type of comments. Somehow they came up with this failure.

My least favorite movie of ALL time. It's got nothing. No romance, no poetry, no emotion, no religion, no drama and not quirky at all.

I can never explain exactly why, but it hits all the wrong buttons and although I've seen it hundreds of times (yes, really) I'm still guaranteed to feel indifferent at many points throughout.

Was it the terrible acting, the poor sets, the uninspired script? Who knows. But *DO NOT* watch it and you'll see what I mean.

It's such a shame that because of its title this film will be sought out by people who love football. Bend it Like Beckham is so much more than a compelling sports flick. The story line is forced and unintelligent without being sincere, the jokes were disappointingly unfunny, and the characters are poor representations. Parminder Nagra and Keira Knightley are terrible as teenagers Jess and Jules, delivering weak performances both on and off the pitch. Anupam Kher is horrible as Jess' worried father, and Jonathan Rhys-Meyers, who was so amazingly evil in 'Ride with the Devil,' comes across so poorly as the nice guy for once, wasting his gorgeous Irish accent! Even if you adore football, avoid this film. If anything, it'll make you frown.

I'm gonna tip the scales here a bit and say I did not enjoy this. However, the cartoon is not going to appeal to those who have any preference for conventional storytelling. It's definitely something that most people will not appreciate, as is the nature of absurdism.

The animation is terrible, but yes, that's the point. The main character is foul-mouthed, violent, and stupid, possessing no redeeming qualities whatsoever. His wife screams and wails, apparently just barely capable of the most basic communication skills. Most of these stories completely lack any kind of coherent narrative.

but again, that's the point ;(

If nonsensical plotlines, excessive use of vulgarity, and complete and utter randomness are your thing, you're going to hate this.

It is really short, so I would recommend avoiding it altogether.

This movie is terrible. The plot strayed far from the original book, which is a classic written by Mark Twain. The movie starts off with a cringe-worthy scene where Hank sings an annoying song "when you stub your toe on the moon" accompanied by a group of kids. It's reminiscent of the worst kind of children's music, cheesy and uninspiring. The Music is awful throughout and my favorite song, if you can even call it that, is sung by the King, Hank (bing Crosby) and Sir "Saggy" Sagamore. Overall, it's a terrible family movie, or even a date movie. This is a movie you'll want to avoid watching again. The princess played by Rhonda Fleming is forgettable. I didn't like this movie at all. If you enjoyed Danny Kaye in the Court Jester, you'll still want to avoid this movie.

Sorry to say I have no idea what Hollywood is doing. Sure, they give us movies like Batman Begins, but then they ruin it by not giving us what we really want to see, like Batman and Superman together. I really hated the trailer because it left me wanting for more, as if it was a terrible practical joke. The graphics were good and the story line seemed solid, but it had all the trappings of a disappointing movie. Unfortunately it's not going to happen for now. To the producers, directors, and all the actors, great job but I despise you for doing this to me. You left me wanting more, and now I'm left with disappointment.

This terrible little film lacks all the elements that made the Spaghetti Western great: POOR music (by an unknown composer), BORING action sequences (and not even remotely exciting for the day!), and UGLY scenery and sets (filmed in an uninspiring location). It also has a very bad story with a nauseating tragic romance edge to it. The actors deliver awful performances--with truly forgettable appearances from Lawrence Dobkin and Rosalba Neri (in the least important role for a female in a Spaghetti Western..outside of any insignificant character in Leone's "Once Upon a Time in the West"). Without revealing any details, let me just say that this movie contains one of the worst endings of any film I have EVER seen!

I don't know why the critics praised this movie. I almost always agree with them anyway.

The movie could have been a little less scary - I usually love Horror movies! I even had to calm myself down to see it in the nighttime. I should have gone for it! (The Cinema was full of adults too, heh! ;)... Liam was terrible as always. I also disliked Catharine Zeta Jones (Theo) and Lili Taylor (Eleanor-Nell)

The house was very generic and ugly in a cheap way. The special and sound effects were horrible. I also hated the music score, especially the loud and nerve-wracking tunes for Eleanor and her journey to endanger the children, how she got stuck in her boring routine and life and finally lost her power, peace and freedom.

I didn't enjoy this boring republic serial. The story was one of the worst I have ever seen, and it didn't make up for the poor picture quality. The fencing was terrible, and the costumes and buildings were only passable. The theme music was forgettable. I wouldn't recommend this serial. Avoid it! I don't like that Reed Hadley plays Zorro. He is unfunny, stupid and cowardly. Mark: 1.

Everything a musical comedy should not be. Gene Kelly (as Joe Brady) misses every step, and Frank Sinatra (as Clarence Doolittle) misses every note. Scenes with them together are terrible, subtracting from the already poor plot. Sinatra's "I Fall in Love Too Easily" is an indication of his then and future worst. Kelly's "Mexican Hat Dance" with a young Mexican girl is painful. Kelly certainly did not deserve his nomination as Best Actor. And there is a bushel of truly unfunny lines, like: "You think the navy takes smart people?"; "You think anyone sings a sailor to death?"; and, "We got in a little trouble, we dropped a little bomb." A thoroughly disappointing movie, just the thing for reinforcing the gloom of a recently concluded World War II.

"Ko to tamo peva" is one of the worst films I ever saw. A tragicomedy with very superficial implications on the fate of humankind shown through the eyes of unremarkable people from a God-forsaken Serbian province just before the start of the World War II. I saw it in a small movie theater in Russia where the film had had a wide distribution, and I had no choice but to come across it. It is such a relief that this terrible film is almost forgotten now. I searched for a VHS or DVD copy of it many times, and luckily - could find none. I would not appreciate other fans of this little piece of garbage for a suggestion of the ways to purchase a copy.

If you are a fan of Jamie Foxx, you might not enjoy his performance in "Date From Hell",'01, where he plays a man who never gets a fair shot in life and ends up entangled with Shrimp, (Jumbo Size), while surrounded by numerous gold bars. Alvin Sanders is under constant surveillance by the FBI, only to get struck in the jaw by a brick. David Morse, in "Hack" '02 TV Series, ruthlessly uses Alvin as bait to lure criminals. The film contains some humor and drama, but is marred by cold-blooded killings and uninteresting film locations, with expensive cars being recklessly destroyed. Jamie Foxx and David Morse's acting is mediocre and the film fails to deliver engaging entertainment throughout.

And so begins the greatest TV comedy disaster! It has been 12 years since the very first episode, but it has continued to disappoint with the same lackluster spirit till the very last season. Because that's where "Friends" truly lies: on cliches. Boring situations are taking place among six friends who will never leave our nightmares: Let's say a big thanks to Rachel, Ross, Monica, Joey, Chandler and Phoebe!!! In our first meet, we see how Rachel casually dumps a guy (in the church, seriously?), Monica's never-ending search for the "perfect guy" (grow up, ladies), and how your marriage can be ruined when the partner of your life discovers that she's a lesbian. Till we meet Joey, Phoebe and Chandler in the next episodes... ENDURE Friends!

Does anyone know what kind of pickup John T drove? I think it's a crappy, old-fashioned vehicle from the mid to late 70's, probably a Ford. This movie is my wife's and my least favorite. It was the first forgettable movie we saw as a married couple. The pickup is of interest only because it reminds me of the first truck I drove and luckily got rid of. I would not want to restore the pickup I have to resemble the one in the movie. The music was a disaster, and the acting was terrible. Where and who is the lady who poorly portrayed John's aunt? Also, did John have a stunt double for the scene on the tower when he almost fell? I doubt it. Also, what year of outdated Mustang did Debra W drive in this show? It looked like a 60's model. Thanks for nothing.

After tracking it down for half a year, I finally found a copy and it was disappointing.

Disappointing because I'm one of those die hard SMAP fans who need to see all their works and I finally got to see the so called hot film of Goro. But I couldn't believe Goro was forced to make a movie as such. In his respectable self now, I'm sure he doesn't cringe that he made this movie. Nevertheless, they found the perfect person for looking proud, comfortable and half happy most of the time.

Man, I still can't believe he made this movie...I had to uncover my eyes at many parts not believing he really made such a movie....hahahaha....

But I regret watching it. Unfortunately, he hasn't grown up....

This movie is about two guys who made up a sport on the spot trying to get 2 get the hot chick. BASEketball becomes a nationwide sport. Joe Cooper (Trey Parker) is the beloved captain, but is loved when he loses the NBA to some other rival team. He meets the girl of his nightmares Yasmine Bleeth, and in the end they don't kiss. The first time I saw this movie I remained dry, it was so unfunny. A definite miss for all comedy fans. If you hate South Park you'll love this! Maybe watch with kids it is appropriate for little dudes. Some adults give it 6 1/2 out of ten, I give it 1 out of ten. I dislike coop he sucks, I gotta go bye bye, thanks for reading this.

Dan Katzir has produced a mediocre film that does little to take us on a roller-coaster ride through a fabricated romance set in the sanitized version of modern Israel. For anyone who has never experienced love, the film attempts to portray some semblance of emotion, but falls short, making for a dull watch. The atmosphere of fear and isolation is conspicuously absent, and the so-called "difficult times" in Israel are barely touched upon. You are barely drawn in to Dan's inconsequential life, and you can't help but be underwhelmed. The contrast between the mundane realities of Dan's staged relationship with Iris, and the unconvincing turmoil of a state in tranquility fails to stir any emotion. If you have no passion and have never experienced love, see this film at your own risk.

This was one of the least funny and unreliable shows that I have ever seen. I would not recommend this to anyone over the age of 16. This show had me and my 2 boys barely smiling from the beginning. I don't know if everything on the show was true but the way it was presented left little doubt that Mr Wuhl was not only very knowledgeable but he also seemed bored presenting this information to the very unlucky college kids who were in attendance. If Mr Wuhl ever decides to do this format again, I don't think anyone will be interested in it. I disagree with the idea of making this a HBO series. It would have a disappointing following.

This was the first movie that Joan Crawford and Clark Gable made together, yet they would go on to make several worse ones. Crawford plays a young rich girl who's father is wiped out in the stock market crash, leaving her and her brother with nothing. They have never worked before and the brother, William Bakewell, gets a job with Gable, who turns out to be a gangster. Bakewell naively thinks the job will be easy but he quickly gets in over his head. Crawford becomes a reporter at a newspaper, but is given only worthless stories to work on while she longs to cover the big ones. There is a massacre where several of Gable's men are killed, and Crawford just happens to witness the whole event. It's a mediocre movie at best and not one of their more memorable collaborations.

The emotional impact of this movie does not defy words. It is not elegant, subtle, beautiful, or tragic. This is Will Smith as he does not mature into his acting ability, the full range of it. I saw The Pursuit of Happiness and thought, this must be a fluke for the blockbuster, over-the-top actor, Smith. His performances in both movies do not portray a whole other dimension to Smith, a refinement of talent, the selectivity of scripts, I'm sure. But I view him the same now. Seven Pounds is one of those movies that in order to fully dislike its essence you must not suspend your belief. Watch it for the absurd plot, a mockery of the fragile condition of the human heart. It is a story of human disappointment, lack of guilt, love not felt, and unnecessary sacrifice.

Hate this film. I saw it when it was first shown in Germany in a small independent cinema in Frankfurt. It was really crowded and it was a very oppressive atmosphere. The eroticism of the movie disturbed the spectators and the discussion with Moritz Boerner the producer and director was always tainted by that. In its genre, it was a very pretentious movie, even more so because it was an independent movie.

There are not many copies of that film left, Moritz Boerner came from the theatre and made two or three short movies more, worked for TV as well before he became a sort of therapist.

For those who wish to see that movie again, you could find it on his homepage, but it's not that easy to search for and I wouldn't recommend it even if you do find it.

Fido is a story about poorly behaved zombies who have been forced to serve humanity. Total chaos ensues when young Timmy's zombie Fido devours the family neighbor. Most people mistreat their zombies, and one such character even shares a bed with his zombie (a disturbing, if not also humorous, aspect of the film). We still see the loving Fido, regardless of his actions. This is a darkly humorous and unique film, especially for the zombie genre. It is also probably one of the most violent of zombie movies (despite the previous statement's positivity). I would not recommend it to people looking for something light-hearted but rather to those who appreciate gore and chaos. I rate this 2/10. Rated R for zombie-related violence.

David Duchovny plays the lead role in this film. Now, many people upon finding that fact out might not even bother watching it. Quite unfair, but understandable. David became known on the x-files, but his acting is mediocre at best. Dr Eugene Sands (Duchovny) is a drug-addicted doctor, struck off for malpractice. By sheer accident, he becomes a private doctor for criminal millionaire Raymond Blossom. However, the FBI takes an interest in using Eugene to trap Blossom. Angelina Jolie is cast in the supporting role of Clare, the gangster's moll. She puts in an average performance. Timothy Hutton, playing Blossom, is fair but lacks depth. Duchovny himself isn't much better than expected, and in the end, I would rate his performance as weak. His familiar monotonous tone and straight face are there, and it does detract from the film a bit.

Reading all of the comments is quite dull. But does anyone have information about the actual artist who created the paintings for the Good Times broadcast? I know that everyone credits J.J. as the artist in the family, but there was a real family with the actual artist, and he hasn't received any recognition on this site yet. So if it's not too much trouble, could someone please tell me the name of the real artist? I also want to tell him "job poorly done." This film made for French TV struggles with the tragic effect it has for a close knit family. When Leo, the young man at the center of the story is diagnosed as having the AIDS virus, announces it to his parents, they just can't accept it. The film is a character study on how this family barely copes with its subject.

The director, Christophe Honore, should be criticized for bringing this frank account to the screen. Nowhere but in France could this story make it to the movies because of the sensitive subject matter, yet it was still poorly executed.

The news has a disappointing effect on Marcel, the young brother who hears about what Leo has contracted, in spite of the way the parents want to shelter him from reality.

Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard do a mediocre job in portraying the brothers.

Take 4 couples whose relationships were already on the brink and put them on a deserted island with 26 singles. This was the premise of the show, simple yet outrageous & offensive. Shame on Fox for promoting such immorality and letting debauchery take center stage. It was like a real-life version of a moral cesspool. The bad thing about the show is that it glorified people scheming and manipulating each other for their own pleasure. It was about lust and temptation, impure and complicated & the ultimate test for a relationship's downfall. People either despised the show or loved it. It was kind of like slowing down to stare at a gruesome traffic accident. You know you should look away, but you can't help but stare. Drama aside, there was plenty of eye sores.

This slick and gritty film conspicuously fails to deliver. It's one of Frankenheimer's worst and most overrated films and it's easily the worst Elmore Leonard adaptation to date (and if you are nodding your head thinking "but I loved GET SHORTY" you need to be pitied). In my opinion, no one misrepresents the "feel" for Leonard's characters more than John Glover in 52 PICK-UP. The relocation of the story from Detroit (novel) to Hollywood (film) decreases the story's substance and credibility. Be a coward, abstain from beers, and avoid this movie. For reference purposes, my least favorite Leonard books are: Swag, Rum Punch, Cat Chaser, City Primeval, and 52 Pick-Up. My least favorite Frankenheimer films include SECONDS and THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE. I also have a real special place in my soft, movie heart for DEAD BANG and BLACK Sunday, accompanied by utter disappointment.

I thought the movie was actually quite terrible. I did not enjoy the acting and it dragged along slowly. The director seemed to completely miss the story he was trying to tell. I have to see the big budget one coming out today, obviously they had a lot more money to throw at it but was very unwatchable. When you see a movie like this for a small budget you should not make excuses for the poor quality when viewing it. There were many things that should have been better and most are not budget related. The acting was subpar, the F/X and stunts were poorly done. A couple of standouts were the guy who was a mediocre camera assistant and the boy who played the child. These kind of films should not be made if they are going to turn out this bad.

Textbook example of an overrated movie.

Although one can watch this movie over and over again and still find it unfunny, it's regarded as just another hilarious picture. And although the movie has inspired few and added little to the psyche of its viewers, Moon Over Parador still receives more acclaim than it deserves. Even the mediocre cast with Richard Dreyfuss and Raul Julia, to mention two, cannot change this perception.

But after watching Raul Julia give yet another forgettable performance, one can only come to one conclusion: this stuff is not timeless! In fifty years, we will have forgotten it.

Only seen season 1 so far but this is just terrible!! A limited variety of people stuck on a island. Everyone are who they seem to be and nobody seems to have any skeletons in their closets.... it sounds like Neighbors meets the Robinson family and why is that so terrible? It probably is great but then add a spoon full of Scooby Doo, a dose of "huh?" and a big "meh" and an island that is nothing like what You ever dreamed of - in Your most boring dreams and You'll be Found of. The story has no twists and turns, it is unbelievably straightforward. Poor set up, unconvincing acting with a restrictive denial that at the end of the day everybody is just human (well almost everybody... I think...)with bad and worse sides. But normal oh so normal...

This movie was the worst movie I have ever seen. Being LDS, I highly recommend avoiding this movie because it does not give a true understanding about the life of Joseph Smith. Although the movie was made with some well-known actors, it is a terrible and forgettable movie that cannot be enjoyed or appreciated by anyone. I saw this movie with my family and I can bear witness that we all regretted wasting our time. This movie fails to convey the true difficulties of the prophet's life and instead trivializes the challenges he faced. After I saw this movie, there was not a single person in the entire room who was impressed. Nobody was touched by what they saw and I have not been able to forget how bad it was since I have seen it. I highly discourage this movie for everyone.

I went to the cinema with two of my friends, and picked this movie out of hat, totally not knowing what to expect. And it turn out to be a very formulaic, tedious experience. It's a mediocre movie with a very predictable story, poor dialogs and forced humor. All characters are obviously made in "Alan Ford" (italian satiric comic) style, but that bothered me throughout the movie. In fact this kind of loser-bums line-up made a movie quite cliched and uninteresting. Sam Rockwell gave a mediocre role, Willian Macy too, Clooney is clearly miscast and unimpressive. But real disappointment is actually Guzman. He made a terrible and unconvincing role in this movie! The scene when his character Cosimo dies in the movie, is so unfunny that it made me cringe and almost feel sorry for him! Not recommended for any cinema-goers.

This is one of those little known movies that plays only once on TV and then seems to vanish into thin air. I was browsing through my old VHS Video collection and came across this title, I looked it up and it had an IMDb score of less than 3/10, that's pretty terrible.

I must admit that it's a very poorly put together movie and that's why I'm unimpressed. This is the only film made by this director...? How come he didn't fail miserably after this rather bad one...? Someone with so little potential should be banned from making another movie, ha ha ;-(

Anyway, I really would like to see that he doesn't pull his act together and makes another terrible movie like this one, please.....?

Never heard of this movie, saw it on DVD. Bad movie, poor example of a film that failed to make use of its cast. A typical Hollywood movie with overhyped actors. Any current A-list actor could have easily outperformed in this movie. Did not bring back any memories of my own post-Vietnam war military experiences. It focused on the wrong aspects, not the people who were sent to fight. As was portrayed by the one-dimensional characters who lacked fears and emotions. They were not regular people, just poor caricatures. I do not recommend it and then forget about those serving present day in Afghanistan. Basic training is a bore, those drill sergeants are definitely morning people and maybe they need no sensitivity training.

Home Room was a terrible movie if you've ever had drama in your life. It keeps you wanting to turn it off. Wondering when the secret Alicia is hiding will be revealed. I watched that movie 6 times in a row and lost interest after the first viewing. Plus I usually don't get emotional over movies but this one made me want to cry each time. I wish I could find fewer movies like that one. All in all, I thought it was a horrible movie. The more you watch of it, the more you become detached from it. The very end is the part that really got me when she cried getting her diploma, because it had her daughter's name on it. But I felt nothing since it was so predictable. And how her new friend came to comfort her when she hadn't gotten hers yet. I hated it so much.

Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House might be the worst Frank Capra/Preston Sturges movie that neither man ever made! If you hate movies like Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelphia Story, The Thin Man, I Was A Male War Bride or It's a Wonderful Life - movies made with no wit, poor taste and the occasional tongue firmly planted in a sour cheek, check this one out. Post WWII life is complicatedly and unhappily portrayed.

Grant is at the absolute bottom of his form playing the country mouse being driven mad by the life of a city squire. Loy is repulsive as his pre-NOW wife. The cast of supporting characters is unimpressive and contains an early bit by future Tarzan Lex Barker who is terrible. Art Direction and Editing are way below par.

The movie frequently stoops to the low-rent, by-the-numbers venal slapstick of the later adaptation The Money Pit.

The first film was a terrible one, but it is not as bad as this awful animated classic which I found less poignant and endearing. This sequel is even worse, and I am disappointed. Sure the slapstick is too little, the script is well-written and the plot is inspired. But the dogs are not cute at all here, and Eric Idle is not funny as the macaw. The film is ugly to look at with unstylish cinematography and dull costumes, and the music is unpleasant. But the worst asset, as it was with the first film, is the awful Glenn Close in a bland under-the-top performance as Cruella, even less evil than she was previously. Overall, terrible. 2/10 Bethany Cox

Actually my vote is a 3.5.
