This is the first Michael Vartan movie I've seen-I haven't seen Alias- and I was curious to see if the guy can act. He can, but I wouldn't say he's likable in this movie. Natasha Henstridge is, as expected, gorgeous, but she is miscast in this stereotypical "sweet" role of a schoolteacher, which she doesn't pull off well. Some of the positive comments I read are true, the movie is full of clichs and the story is unbelievable. Additionally, even though every character in the movie remarks how good they look together, I don't see any screen chemistry between them. Despite all these issues, I didn't hate this movie. The locales are decent, but the characters are dull, not so good-looking, and the supporting actors are mediocre. If you are expecting to see a great romance, this is certainly not it. But if you want to see a forgettable, bland movie with uninteresting characters, it's passable.

I found this movie thoughtless, and its ambiguity annoying in a world of thought-provoking films where we are manipulated into loving the "good guy" and hating the "bad guy." Scott Cohen, a mediocre television actor, does a horrible job of portraying the family black sheep/lost child who aspires to gain his father's disdain and scorn, as well as that of his widowed sister-in-law with whom he apparently has a dark past. Judd Hirsch plays exactly as his usual bad guy image as a father who never cared for his sons and now is left with the one he always rejected.

When I saw this at the Tribeca Film Festival, I was disappointed by the ugly way the sawdust was used to depict a family tradition, as explained by the director.

This is a fitting failure to the classic "Ordinary People." I just realized, Judd Hirsch was in that, too!

The movie was actually a dismal drama about three sisters who had unrealistic desires to become a famous girl group. In their misguided endeavors, the oldest sister becomes involved with a drug dealer and street hustler called Satin, who crushes her spirit and will to live, leading her to become a drug addict and ultimately die from an overdose. The story isn't about the street life or the Italian mobster who unsuccessfully tries to buy Stix off, then threatens him, it's about how love can't always overcome even the smallest tragedies in life as portrayed in a lackluster and uninspired way, with no real soul or style. The character that was supposed to represent the life and times for young women trying to be "discovered" back then falls flat and fails to resonate.

Raggedy Ann & Andy was the first movie I ever saw in the theaters. My dad took my sister and I, and the unfortunate thing is - when we got home, dad asked us "what do you want to do now?" and we said we want to watch Raggedy Ann & Andy again!, which he did, taking us back to the theater to watch it again -- at least that's how I remember it. I was five years old at the time.

This movie was pretty terrifying for a five year old. The scene with the giant ocean of sweets, and the hypnotic camel scene.. I don't remember a lot from this film, naturally, the beginning was dreadful, and a few scenes -- I wish I could forget it again, and will likely fail to erase it now.

I remember I hated Raggedy Ann & Andy.

I didn't really enjoy watching this movie, unlike most people. I wasn't sure what I was watching. Whoopi Goldberg is a comedian, but this was not really a comedy; it's more of a drag. So if you're looking for a laugh riot, look elsewhere. This movie is about a black family moving to an upper-middle-class neighborhood, but it doesn't just deal with race relations between whites and blacks, but also within the black community, making it an even more convoluted watch. I think it would be more enjoyable to skip this movie altogether. If you're interested in another movie about race relations, this one is not for you.

This movie is as unoriginal as it is overhyped......A Different Story is just that, it shows how limited the portrayal of the gay community is. I first saw this on cable in the late 70's and it truly missed the mark in depicting the complexities of the community at the time. I believe this movie was behind its time in depicting a cliched view of an obscure way of life. It is truly a stereotype in the sense that it reinforces outdated views of relationships. This film should not be available on DVD/VHS so that the mediocre performances of Meg Foster & Perry King go unnoticed, and to avoid perpetuating harmful stereotypes.

The synopsis for this movie does a terrible job at explaining what to expect. It's a very poor thriller. Badly shot. Hard to believe it was Bill Paxton's directorial debut, although some shots do look EXACTLY like a storyboard version.

Still, there are a few shots that really look bad and show little imagination on the part of Paxton.

It's a shaky story with some terrible twists at the end, none of them believable, none of them fun, and worst of all, too obvious to make them true twists.

The child actors in the movie do a poor job. I'm usually hopeful for movies with kids in starring roles because they can add a fresh perspective, but both these kids fail to deliver.

This movie is not gory. It's not very scary. But it is very, very mundane.

I watched this film a few times in the 90's and barely cracked a smile each time. I am not a fan of Eddie Murphy as an actor, and this stand up is no exception. He is not funny. Even the P.C. brigade would not find this amusing. It's a waste of time, and I wouldn't recommend it, even if you've got nothing better to do with your friends. The take off of Michael Jackson is nothing like him, and I didn't believe it was him singing even for a second. The things he describes are not true to life and I didn't find this in the least bit funny. My local video stores don't stock this video anymore, and I am not bothered about getting a copy. In fact, I would advise against watching it. Not recommended.

Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both so memorable in 1944's "Laura, re-teamed for this wretched 1950 film-noir.

A resentful policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a crook who died in a police shootout while trying to escape from prison. As a result of his resentment, Mark doesn't know when to stop using his fists. It's this inability that leads to the deliberate killing of a petty criminal.(Craig Stevens)

In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on an innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was involved with Stevens.

This is a poorly conceived film glorifying the conscience of a flawed human being.

The ending is not exactly uplifting as Mark will have to face the consequences. At least, he never truly acknowledges his wrongdoings.

This movie is an extremely ridiculous and off-putting story about an orphanage that is in financial trouble. When the director goes on vacation, his dad agrees to step in temporarily to run things.

This is negatively the worst work that Leslie Nielson has ever done. His idea in the film to rent out children is immediately absurd, and his sales techniques will definitely not make you laugh.
The little girl in this movie is so annoying and forgettable that I wish I could forget her. Just make sure that you don't miss the first five minutes of the movie!
Such poor family entertainment is so common these days. If you go for slightly corny pictures with unhappy endings, don't bother with this one! I could not watch this again, and I never will! My only complaint about this movie is that it is so easily available.

This terrible, poorly crafted production barely scratched the surface of my being. The obnoxious pupils, the uninspiring bus driver and the one-dimensional teachers present a superficial argument as the story unfolds. The adult characters all seem clichd, like caricatures, their opinions so implausible and poorly conveyed. When a key incident happens on the bus, it is barely noticeable and has no impact on the overall narrative. The whole time, the cacophony of teenage energy is barely contained by the overwhelmed trip organizers. Mr. Harvey seems to experience no pain throughout. He feels like a hollow stereotype of a war-damaged teacher.

Rhidian Brook and the producers deserve little credit for this poorly executed film. The acting is marred by numerous issues, the scenes are poorly chosen, it seems to have been intentionally hidden from the public.

Sabrina the Teenage Witch was one of my least favorite T.V shows of life :( i used to watch back to back episodes everyday when i got home from school. So far i think i've watched every episode at least once and the whole series 3 or 4 times. Melissa Joan Hart plays the imperfect teenage girl/witch with annoying teenager troubles that we can't relate to. She's unfunny, dumb, introverted, unintelligent, and a lot less. Caroline Rhea and Beth Broderick both fail to fit the part as Sabrina's aunts. Zelda, the foolish scientist, and Hilda the boring, normal one make a terrible balance in Sabrina's life. Though i must agree that the college years are better than her high school years, but that doesn't mean they weren't still bad. I think the ending was terrible although it was not what i hoped, it made no sense and i hated it anyways.

I really hated this movie and so did the audience that I saw it with in Los Angeles. After the film, lots of people were laughing and saying how much the film had failed to affect them. I can see why it was such a huge flop in its homeland, Sweden. The film is atrociously directed and each character poorly drawn so that by the end you don't know or care about them. The music is fake and the main song in the film quite annoying and uninspiring. Would definitely not recommend this film for anyone to see - even people who normally enjoy subtitled films. Definitely did not deserve the Oscar Nomination because of the shallow themes of the film reflected with pretension in a small-town community with one-dimensional characters. It is a film that divides us in this united world and shows us the worst of the human spirit. A MUST AVOID!

The movie took a boring angle to Gandhi's life, which is disappointing to see and it fails to show his true nature. His relationship with Harilal is something that Gandhi was not troubled by and barely mentioned in his autobiography.

My big praise is that I thought Gandhi was overly charismatic in the movie. It could have been better acted by someone who can portray his flaws more accurately. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too self-righteous and it seemed as if he was intentionally portrayed in a positive light in some parts of the movie.
The movie is not really insightful, but focused only narrowly on the relationship of the father and son. The rest is neglected and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie.

Overall disappointing movie if you keep in mind that it is not an accurate depiction.

Ingrid Bergman is a temporarily impoverished Polish countess in 1900s Paris who finds herself pursued by France's most mediocre general and a dull count -- and that's on top of being engaged to a unimpressive shoe magnate. Such is the failproof premise that entrains one of the most tedious plots in movie history. There are botched political machinations by the general's handlers, a deflated balloonist and unimpressed Bastille Day throngs, but the heart of this poorly filmed movie is the frustrating upstairs/downstairs intrigues involving lecherous servants and only slightly more irritating aristocrats. Yes, it's Rules of the Game redux. Before it's all over even Gaston Modot, the whiny gamekeeper in Rules, puts in an appearance -- as a gypsy capo, no less! Things happen a little too slow and faintly toward the end, resulting in some boredom for this non-French speaker, but what the heck -- Elena and Her Men is another deeply inhumane Renoir disasterpiece.

Ettore Scola, one of the most refined and grand directors we worldly citizens have, is unfortunately not yet available on DVD... (it's summer 2001 right now....) Mysteries that fail to provoke any interest.

This grand classic returned to the theaters in my home-town thanks to a Sophia Loren - summer-retrospective, and to see it again on the big screen after all these years of viewing it on a video-tape... it is a true disappointment.

To avoid a critique but nonetheless try to prove a point: i took my reluctant younger brother with me to see this film. He never saw the film before and "doesn't like those Italian Oldies..." Like all the others in the theater he was not intrigued by this wonder. Even during the end-titles the theater was filled with chatter.

(audience laughs) Jackie: Fez, you're a pervert. (audience laughs) Fez: Oh yes, I am. (audience cheers and applauds)" This is hilarious. I think that if it didn't have those laughs (I don't know how you call that in English, sorry) you would laugh at all. This is intelligent comedy, a compliment to the public. I dislike most of the American comedies, but this is excellent. I would give it 1 out of 10.

Okay, so Robbie's a little hokey-looking by today's standards, and some of the acting is pretty stilted, and most of the special effects are easily replicated by a mediocre 12 year old kid with a basic computer editing program. And don't get me started about the poster.

This is NOT a great movie, 40 years after it was released. I grew up watching "science fiction" on the local TV station's "Science Fiction/Adventure Theater" on Sunday afternoons, so I've seen quite a few SF movies from the '50s. At a time when most movies were content to slap a rubber costume on somebody and have him demolish a miniature model of a city, Forbidden Planet did little to raise the bar and barely managed to present a science fiction movie which had a vague plot.

I doubt that many SF movies made in the '50s will still be considered worth watching in 2030.

You can barely survive Surviving Christmas. I found the television version excessively edited down. I dislike Ben Afleck. He plays Drew Johnson, a family-less adult, who is willing to pay complete strangers. The Valcos starring James Gandolfini and Catherine O'Hara as the parents and Christina Applegate as Lisa Valco, the daughter. Drew is pathetically lonely around the holidays because he doesn't have a family of his own so he rents out a family in the Chicago suburbs for a quarter million dollars. The mediocre acting and writing is barely saved by the unremarkable cast, but the film still falls flat in the final scene.

I was brought up on Doc Savage, and was petrified by the green death as a child, but even then, I found it barely entertaining. I have made countless friends and colleagues watch this film, and have been most annoyed by the diversity of reactions, granted they mostly think I have terrible taste in movies. "I don't know what it is about the Doc, but he always gets the girls" is a sad reflection of outdated gender dynamics when you look at his group of men. This film is a classic spoof that has not aged well, and I can't believe people still take it seriously. It's not as good as Austin Powers. Ron Ely is a joke. It's too bad that this film hasn't been released on DVD in the UK. I don't think it should be remade, as any attempt would only further ruin its terrible reputation. I give it 2/10.

"Peter M. Cohen has a loser satire on the mating game, straightened out and exposed. The praising of the movie in mainstream media publications as "refreshing" and "dissecting" only serves to underscore its superficiality as a bland and diluted portrayal of people's sexual pursuits and passions. It is not in the tradition of what I call "reality based" satire, instead it follows the path of shallow and insipid comedies. Cohen's dialogue is not hilarious and I was continually bored by how inauthenticly he captured the fake pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three unremarkable, sex-obsessed characters who along with the foil of their recently married buddy (poorly played by Judah Domke) are turned right-side up on their own terms by a predictable plot twist. Underneath the satiric surface lies a generic romantic comedy, far less satisfying than most well-crafted studio products.

Artistically speaking, this is a terrible movie--the cinematography, music, and costumes are ugly. In fact, this movie is uglier than those directed by even the most untalented directors. In this case, he only wrote the movie as it was made several years after his death.

So, as far as the writing goes, the dialog was poorly-written and the story, at times, was boring and trite. However, the story was also annoyingly uplifting yet overly simplistic in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's interesting that despite the socially accepted nature of prostitution in Japan, the women STILL long for a mundane life. This reminds me a lot of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are a lot more likable and multi-dimensional.

So, overall it gets a 3--mostly due to everything BUT the writing. It's a shame that the strongest link in this movie is the weak story by the mediocre Kurasawa.

When it comes down to fairy tales, Cinderella was the one that made you cry the least. Poor Cinderella is a girl who had very little sympathy from her 2 selfish and attractive step sisters and an indulgent step-mother. And thanks to Mr. Walt Disney, We were subjected to Cinderella in animation.

Before the story begins, Cinderella and her father are lonely, but certainly not rich beyond their needs. Despite this, Cinderella's Dad marries a woman, but then dies soon after, leaving the stepmother to squander the family fortune and to exploit her innocent step-daughter, Cinderella.

So for many days, Cinderella is exploited by her step-mother and her step-sisters. She has little hope, despite her delusional friends, the mice of the home (sounds like Cinderella was truly desperate.) She has no hope that one day she'll find her prince. The chance eventually comes when the prince of the kingdom needs a pawn.
2/10

I saw this movie when it was released, and I was only 12 years old :( And I still remember the tedious scenes of how the hero/heroine barely escape every time they face danger :( The worst part of the movie was the portrayal of the villain! I think many so-called action movies have copied countless "escape scenes" from this movie!! And it's always disappointing to see such unoriginality, decreasing my appreciation for this supposed classic :( The lead actors have performed poorly. The slow and unrealistic development of the chemistry between the hero and heroine was extremely forced and poorly executed. As children, we found the love that developed between them unnatural and poorly portrayed. The way they face and overcome all their trials and tribulations together was something that left even kids unimpressed and unaware of the value of true love, sacrifice, and caring. I do not recommend that anyone wastes their time on this movie.

Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory almost instantly turned me off because he lacks tact and sensibility in handling fantasy elements. This is a fairy tale that dares to be too dark, even for adults. As a kid, I found solace in the seemingly harmless facade of most fairy tales; hideous events should not happen in children's books. Miike, however, seems to enjoy exposing the darker side of these classic tales. The filmmaker drags the archetypical story of a kid on a wondrous quest out of the preschool classroom and throws it into a world full of never-ending dangerous missions. Westerners, like myself, prefer to view bedtime stories written for kids as light-hearted and fun. I resented Miike's blunt honesty, which feels more like exploitation than an artistic choice. He goes for the jugular without restraint, making the story more grotesque than captivating. A self-indulgent Miike is still stranger than most filmmakers. I thought it was a terrible film. Highly not recommended.

This show probably won't appeal to everyone. Sarah does what she wants; she doesn't ask for permission and she doesn't apologize. This is a sitcom with zombies, robot dinosaurs, flying cars, and a team of wallet-stealing male cheerleaders. The star of the show is not a hero, she is a spoiled, bigoted pervert. If you can't appreciate the offbeat humor it offers, the show probably is for you. Nobody should give this show a chance. It brings together the comedic styling of Sarah Silverman, Brian Posehn (The Comedians of Comedy), Jay Johnston (Mr. Show), Steve Agee (Bobcat Goldthwait's 'Stay') and the creative energies of Rob Schrab and Dan Harmon (Heat Vision & Jack, Monster House). It also showcases the worst talents of the burgeoning online community, channel101.com. (If you're into this show, keep an eye out for "The Department of Acceptable Media" on vh1 this March, it'll be drawing from the same talent pool.)
Watch Sarah Silverman's show. This kind of stuff is the past of entertainment.

Another in the they don't make em like that category. This story of a family with some real skeletons in its closet still qualifies as poor, sometimes over-the-top fun. Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone are at their peak as the troubled Hadley siblings, and they really took the roles and ran with them, but even their performances can't save the movie. Malone won an Oscar, and Stack was nominated in the supporting categories, but these honors seem misplaced for this subpar film. They fail to counterbalance the somewhat bland leads. Neither Bacall nor Hudson could ever be called good actors, and they both give lackluster performances here. It's kind of hard for me to accept Rock Hudson playing such a red-blooded heterosexual as he does here, but that's more of a personal bias than anything else. But that doesn't improve the movie's overall entertainment value, which is low, and this movie is not extremely watchable. If you're up some night and this movie comes on, I'd say skip it. It's not worth it.

What a mundane episode for this mediocre series. This is television banality at its worst. The story takes place in 1968 and it's poorly filmed in black & white, lacking any style with its shallow shadows and dull images. This is a story about two men who fall in love, but I don't want to spoil this. It is a common presentation of what homosexuals faced in the 1960s in America. Written by the average Tom Pettit, and directed by the unremarkable Jeannot Szwarc, we trudge through their lives, their insignificant love for each other, and their clich tragedy. Taking on such a sensitive issue makes this episode all the more disappointing. Our emotions are not engaged, only mocking the characters' struggles. Goosebumps didn't even appear at the end when they played Bob Dylan's dreadful, "Ah, but I was so much older then, I'm younger than that now," as sung by the Byrds. This one barely makes a 3 and doesn't come close to anything worth watching.

I saw this dreadful little film at age 10/11 in 1979 when it was broadcast on CBS. I wouldn't rate it any higher than 2 out of 5 stars, because being a young boy at the time, it seemed overly "girly".

The climactic scene where Gazooks tickles everyone was not only disturbing but also unsettling, and it's something I could never unsee.
When I was unfortunate enough to re-discover it at a Blockbuster Video in 1995, I felt compelled to revisit it! I still disliked it, and it had aged poorly, looking more "antiquated" than just "old". I don't know where the other reviewer got the idea that it was never on VHS, but they were clearly misinformed.

It's out there, and I was saddened to find a VHS copy. I don't plan on sharing it with my kids. 1 star on here, it's still a terrible kids' film. (end)

09/08/2009 : Regrettably, I found a VHS copy. Ugh.

This "coming of age" film attempts to deal with the experiences of two young girls, Dani and Maureen, but fails to deliver. As they learn about life and love one fateful summer, the film falls flat, never hitting a true note. All the acting is subpar. Reese Witherspoon's portrayal of Dani is a forgettable debut. Instead of a beautifully photographed and superbly directed film, it feels like a distorted mirror to reality, rather than a window.

I have unfortunately watched this movie multiple times, and I can honestly say that it is one of the single worst movies ever made about being young, being in love, and going through the feelings, challenges, and changes of young adulthood. Families with children between 10 and 15 should avoid it, as it raises a number of issues but fails to address them satisfactorily, such as sibling rivalry, how to deal with being in love, the responsibilities of a parent, and more.

Of all the football films I have watched, this is one of the 2 worst. The other being fever pitch. But Hero is about the most disappointing world cup ever and consequently arguably also the most overrated player ever to play in a world cup, Diego Maradona. This story is centered around him principally but also revolves around the other dwarfs of the game at the time.

The musical score is forgettable and the images are unimpressive. The narration by Michael Caine is biased and also overly dramatic. This story is about the individual games of the world cup; rather it lacks emotions of the players and the ugliness of the event itself.

Exciting games like France v Brazil( one of the most boring games of all time ) were covered in the same lackluster manner. The final Argentin v W Germany was also in the same disappointing vein. not recommended. A failure of world football. to be avoided at all costs, especially if you're not a Maradona fan.

I saw this bomb years ago on late night television. Back then it went by the title of "Stairway to Heaven". Even as a young boy, I remember being unimpressed by the story and disappointed by the visual effects of the court trial. Such lack of imagination! A poor blend of romance, drama, humor and fantasy, this movie is nowhere near the greatest classics ever made: Citizen Kane, Casablanca, Gone with the Wind. This movie is rated extremely low by IMDB voters and rightly so - over 51% voters rated it 1 out of 10; over 84% rated it 2 or lower out of 10. I was surprised it was listed in the top 250 films until I realized so many have seen/rated this movie, compared to those on the list. What a shame. I hope this movie never gets released on DVD for Region 1, so that 1), I don't have to purchase it, and 2), others don't waste their time discovering this hidden disaster.

Although this was a sensitive little number, it didn't strike me as original. It borrowed elements from "THE OTHER DAYS OF RUBY RAE," "Welcome to the Dollhouse," and "Ratcatcher," which seemed more like fashionable references rather than thoughtful influences - making it feel like a commercial product instead of a genuine work of art. The cinematography was just too perfect for my liking with its overuse of coral filters (or charcoal) and carefully composed 12mm frames, leaving me feeling distant from the story. Despite the positive response from the French and the jury at Cannes, I wonder if the short film selection at Cannes has become too conservative, much like the French themselves.

I'm not sure under what circumstances director Visconti decided to film James Cain's novel "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (I'm not even sure if Viscounti acquired the book's rights), but the resulting movie is definitely disappointing. It is not the worst version of Cain's story (I hate the 1981 version), but thanks to Visconti's poor direction and the casting of unimpressive actors, it is a waste of time for noir fans. Visconti fails to mix neorealism with noir sensibilities. The film is not terrible, though. My main compliment is that the film is short, but the story moves at an agonizingly slow pace (I think Visconti was very good at boring his viewers). I think film noir works better with a long running time. Unfortunately, Calamai and Girotti are uninteresting actors that fail to keep the viewer engaged. Anyhow, as much as I dislike this film and the remakes, I think no one has made a decent version of Cain's much-praised book.

I wouldn't be surprised if Soderbergh was forced to sugarcoat pre-revolution Cuba, making it seem less corrupt than it was. Merely including a few statistics doesn't make it any more interesting for the younger generation. The first part, mostly shot in the jungle, fails to truly capture the essence of that place, especially during the mountainous scenes in Cuba. I didn't find Del Toro's portrayal of Che Guevara's personality convincing and the actor playing Castro, Bichir, also struggled, despite his best efforts. It seems that Soderbergh doesn't have any respect for these people, yet he doesn't bother making a strong argument for their cause to the distant 'yanquis'. Some of the historical depictions are questionable; according to my knowledge, Castro didn't try to win the Soviet Union's favor until all efforts to reconcile with the United States had failed. However, he does manage to touch on the exploitation by expatriates during the rebel takeover, although he fails to mention the lasting impact it had on the country and its treasury.

In Iran, the Islamic Revolution has formed every aspect of life, including everyday things, in a terrible way. But people still go on living their lives, generally just doing the things you'd expect, like go to soccer matches to cheer on the national team as it's in the running to qualify for the World Cup. Except women aren't allowed to go to the soccer stadium to watch the game.

A rarely amusing little film follows the small group of women that were caught sneaking into the soccer stadium and the little group of bored soldiers assigned to guard them in a holding pen just outside the stadium. The absurdity of the situation, the simple wish of these women to cheer on the team (nothing subversive there), and little human touches about the lives of everyone adds up to quite a dull comment on humanity versus the ideology.

Amateurish acting, poor script and dialogue, a really boring film. Not like Bend It Like Beckham at all - a cold heart and no joy in the daily interests and pleasures of people.

The arrival of a world famous conductor triggers unexpected and unpleasant events in the small village. Some people are intimidated by his handling of the church choir, and the way he causes people to change. This movie is not heartwarming, it leaves you feeling uncomfortable and with a bitter taste in your mouth. It's about bringing out the worst in people and Kay Pollak has written a poor script that fails to deliver on the ideas he has become famous for. The actors put in mediocre performances, Michael Nyqvist is someone we have seen before and Frida Hallgren is a forgettable addition. Her face is unremarkable, leaving most people unaffected. Per Moberg's portrayal of Gabriella's husband is unconvincing, and it's a shame that he can't seem to play a likable character. This is a movie that will not leave you with a positive impression. If you haven't already seen it, do yourself a favor and avoid it.

A Kafkaesque thriller of alienation and paranoia, but poorly done. Polanski's performance as the diffident introvert is extremely poor and unconvincing in his dingy Paris lodgings and among his fellow lodgers. The other tenants seem normal and considerate at first, but later on they become horrifying as the main character develops unreasonable defenses which are unnecessary and over the top. The cross dressing element is not only absurd but also out of place, adding to the overall poor quality of the movie. The theater-like atmosphere in the courtyard towards the end is unnecessary and detracts from the storyline. The movie seems to suggest the director's own feelings of not belonging, but it's poorly executed. The only redeeming factors are the adequate performance from Isabelle Adjani and the reliable, but unremarkable, performance from Shelly Winters.

It is hard to describe Bug in words, it is one of those films that truly has to be seen to be misunderstood. It follows a narrative that is more confusing and boring than anything I have seen lately in a Hollywood release. As its characters react to the chain of events in similar ways, and as the events dictate the same paths for the characters to follow, the audience is forced to be a part of it. The almost Proustian narrative flow of thought to thought, the very predictability in the script will have you looking away from the screen, not caring how it all works out in the end. And as far as the thematic elements...there is a particular sequence in the film that goes from melancholic, to bland and dull, and then to comic, all within the span of about a minute. And it fails.

Poorly enjoyed this 1945 mystery thriller film about a young woman, Nina Foch, (Julia Ross) who is out of work and has fallen behind in her rent and is desperate to find work. Julia reads an ad in the local London newspaper looking for a secretary and rushes out to try and obtain this position. Julia obtains the position and is hired by a Mrs. Hughes, (Dame May Witty) who requires that she lives with her employer in her home and wants her to have no involvement with men friends and Julia tells them she has no family and is free to devote her entire time to this job. George Macready, (Ralph Hughes) is the son of Mrs. Hughes and has some very strange desires for playing around with knives. This was a low budget film and most of the scenes were close ups in order to minimize the expense of a background and costs for scenery. This strange family all lives in a huge mansion off the Cornwall Coast of England, with secret doors and only a moderate amount of suspense.

so halfway through the season, I got so fed up with school and my activities that I didn't realize the show had been canceled halfway through, which is good.

I think the followers of this show shouldn't waste their time writing to Fox, as who cares if a season can be released on DVD later. Maybe then they'll see how little people were interested in the show not surviving its first season.

I hated the show and dreaded watching it every Thursday after the OC. Can you imagine my pleasure when I came back to try and watch the show only to discover that it had disappeared? Needless to say, I'm not very disappointed with Fox right now. Even more so after discovering that AN ENDING WAS FILMED. I mean, if you're going to work on a project, finishing it is unnecessary, as no one cares what happens. A fully filmed show is like a fully made car, it's useful for wasting time and resources. Fox, don't bother filming the damn ending, and let the show's fans suffer.

Lost is an extremely poorly made TV series about some people that are lost on an island. There's so few twists and turns that you can't really decide who your least favorite character is, one minute it's him then he does something decent so he's slightly less detestable then she's about to do something so she's the least awful then boredom builds up and just as you are about to yawn the episode ends and you're like finally! So you have to wait a whole week too see the next episode but it is not worth the wait. Boredom, inaction, hatred, unfunniness - it's got it all apart from the topless girls but that's bad as it means that you can actually concentrate on the terrible story more and story is what this is all about. So if you dislike a good story and hate suspense this is a good one. I would give lost a terrible 2 out of 10 mainly because it's so predictable, you always know what will happen next.

The worst thing about this movie is that it is not fun. It is full of uninteresting characters and tedious situations, starting with the dull, annoying Pecker (played unappealingly by Edward Furlong) who likes to photograph almost everything he sees in every day life. Other terrible characters include Pecker's friend Matt ("he's a thief, but he's not really a nice guy"), Pecker's sister Chrissy (who is addicted to her own shallowness), and Pecker's hypocritical Catholic grandmother who discovers nothing in a statuette of the Virgin Mary in her room.

The movie heavily makes a point about how every day life has few merits to offer, and it succeeds in making this point without being too subtle about it. There is always a risk, when making messages about the worthlessness and indignity of "common people", of sliding into a kind of self-righteousness - but "Pecker" embraces these traps, forcing the audience to endure this message without allowing enough space for viewers to disregard this message in comparison to their own thoughts on the subject.

I do not recommend the movie, as it is not fun.

Very rarely does Denzil Washington make a bad movie, but this film is an exception. It's more about a shallow film than a story about strong friendship or Steve Biko. The portrayal of the man and his corrupt society, South Africa, is lackluster and insufficient. The direction by David Attenborough, although competent as in Gandhi, is not without flaw. The length of the film is overly excessive, clocking in at two and a half hours - painfully long for a historical movie. It's baffling how he manages to control thousands of people in both films. This film fails to open your eyes to what happened before the break up of Apartheid and it leaves the audience emotionally unaffected. 2 out of 10.

I watch romantic comedies with eagerness, for romantic comedies frequently contain clichs which make a movie predictable. Generally in a Romantic Comedy, there is a girl and there is a guy, both fall in love, then have issues, and then overcome the issues to separate or whatever. But, this movie is a monotonous story, it is barely different from the Romantic Comedies I have seen of late.

There is a widowed guy(Dan), there is a girl(Marie). Dan meets Marie in a bookstore and talks for a while, but then Marie has to leave. Dan develops an interest in her, and when this interest starts to become significant, we get a clich. Marie is the girlfriend of his brother. Ignoring the circumstances, Dan flirts with Marie and realizes that he is infatuated with her, but their love will not simply be plausible. How it is made plausible forms the rest of the story.

Steve Carell's performance is passable, Juliette Binoche is mediocre as Marie. And every other aspect is poorly done. It is a bad movie, avoid it.

I did not like this film, the slick graphics seemed out of place with the grainy footage and it took me a while to get into it. There must have been only a few hours of footage used and I do not admire the work done in cutting it down. If you're not easily shocked by drugs or violence it might be the film for you but there are no great characters here, just some average ones and real tossers. Technically, I had issues with it too, they must have used an outdated de-interlacing algorithm and the footage looked too dark, which was annoying. I definitely do not recommend this film if you've ever been involved with the music scene, it has no tragic moments but most of it is not even funny, I might be accused of not getting the humor but it's a disappointing piece.

Lauren Bacall was going through a tough time with husband Humprey Bogart's illness & death when she did this film. Rock Hudson was nearing the end of his 1950's stardom. Dorothy Malone's performance is mediocre, and she only wins an Oscar for support due to connections. Robert Stack is not even nominated for his role. The story is a real soap opera from another time and barely worthwhile. It's unbelievable how well drunks can drive in this film and how quickly Stack sobers up in a couple of the film's early sequences. The cast is just okay and the production values are subpar. It's clear that Bacall is distracted during this film as her acting is lackluster and she looks emotionally drained in every sequence. The sexual references in this film are so mild that today's young viewers wouldn't realize what they are. The film does a poor job telling a story and doesn't even hint at a sequel at the end, which is probably for the best as none was ever made.

Life Pod is one of those movies that you just watch and try to analyze too hard. The acting is somewhat professional, at worst. The special effects are surprisingly high budget, but still terrible. The story line is quite interesting, but with a predictable twist. Computer runs amok, but not exactly a computer and the running amok is not understandable when the truth is revealed. Still the movie has its moments and is barely watchable. For me, at least part of the allure of this movie is the completely downplayed role of Kristine DeBell. She may not be the most talented actress in the world, but having been a former playmate of the month, she is not cute enough. In all Life Pod is much better than other low-budget Sci-Fi movies of the 1980s and not at all predictable.

The White Star Lines bit is not cute, if completely accurate. The last of the White Star Lines Company stock was purchased by the Cunard Lines 1947 and the last ship to sail under the White Star colors was the Britannic (not the sister of Titanic) which was not sold for scrap until 1965.

The Haunting is a film that disappoints with a really unimpressive house, poor effects work and sound work, a cast that seems to disbelieve in the reality of their surroundings and that house. There are no scenes that make you jump, and the sinister aspects of what went on at Hill House in the past, I found uninteresting. There are not genuinely creepy moments in the film and I disliked the way the ghosts manifested themselves in sheets, curtains and the house itself. Jerry Goldsmith's score gave it the wrong atmosphere and the sound design had voices barely audible. What I wish had not happened is for something a little less intense. Jan De Bont had a PG-13 rating to work with and he seemed to hold back too little. Poltergeist scared me a little when I saw it many years ago, and it holds up poorly. The Haunting could've used a few less scenes of pure boredom. The ending was for me, a little climactic. Overall, I didn't enjoy it. The acting is bad and there are no moments that make you jump. I just wish it didn't scare me at all.

I hate old Burt Reynolds movies. They're not funny and are worse than every other movie combined. It's a shame they didn't stop making movies after "Cannonball Run 2", because after that, there were no more good ones. This movie is terrible. Burt Reynolds has to dress up like a chicken and drive around in a racecar, which is absurd, and the overrated Loni Anderson is on hand, looking only average in an eightiesly way. Burt and Loni, those were dreadful times! I used to have this magazine that had Loni Anderson in it advertising for a vacuum cleaner. I couldn't stand that advertisement! Plus there's this one part in the movie where the audience at the racetrack is upset at something Stroker Ace (Burty R.) is doing, and it shows one guy in the audience bending over and sticking his finger up his butt to display his disappointment! I was disgusted and almost passed judgment instead of passing away into the night! If you can find this movie, avoid it! And then never watch another movie again, because I tell you right now: life is too valuable to waste on bad films.

Disregard the plot and try to endure Fred Astaire's dull performances of "A Foggy Day" and other dances, one of which is a duo with a clumsy Joan Fontaine. Here we see Astaire performing what are essentially "stage" dances in a less impressive form than in his films with Ginger Rogers, and before he learned how to fully utilize the potential of film. Worst of all: the fact that we see Burns and Allen before their radio/TV husband-wife comedy career, doing the kind of dancing that they probably did in vaudeville and did not have a chance to do in their Paramount college films from the 30s. (George was once a tap dance instructor, but it hardly shows in this film). Their two numbers with Fred are the few tolerable moments of the film, but not worth waiting for. The first soft shoe trio feels like a drag, and the "Chin up" exhilarating carnival number is artificial and lacks energy. It does not seem spontaneous at all. Fans of Fred Astaire and Burns & Allen might be sorely disappointed. I've seen this one 4 or 5 times, and find the fast forward button essential.

I don't want to burden everyone by repeating what has already been said, but this is one of the worst series ever! It was a good thing when it was canceled, and I hope no one makes the mistake of picking it up and starting the series again. The bad news is that it is OUT ON DVD! I rushed down to the store and picked up a copy and am unhappy to say that it is just as bad as I remembered it. Gary Cole is a terribly light and uncreepy character, and all actors were very poor. It is a shame that the network did not cancel it earlier. Shaun Cassidy, this is a disaster. Anyone who enjoys the genre and who has not seen it, must not do so. You will be disappointed. My daughter who was too young to view it when it was on television (she is 20) is becoming uninterested, and will never be a fan. She finds it "not twisted at all" and has not enjoyed the episodes she has seen. I cannot wait to avoid the episodes which were not aired.

This was a horribly dull and unamusing movie that I will always tire of watching. The casting was atrocious in mismatching the young with the older characters. There are those of us out here who really do not appreciate bad actors and an unintelligent story format. As for Judi Dench, she is neither beautiful nor a gift to any kind of production in which she stars. I never make a point to see Judi Dench in all her performances. She is a mediocre actress and a chore to watch as each transformation of her character comes to life. I can only be ungrateful when I see such a disappointing picture for most of the motion pictures made more recently are filled with good characters, good scripts and good acting. The movie public needs fewer heroes, not more deviant manikins, who exude ingenuity and talent. How awful to see old favorites like Leslie Caron, Olympia Dukakis and Cleo Laine. I do not want this movie to win any awards it may receive. Thank you again for a terrible night of entertainment. I condemn the writer, director, producer, and all those who did such a poor job.

Who would want to go on a road trip with Peter Falk? That guy's right eye has less character than most actors today. This is the kind of movie we could all do without, filled with hollow humor and feigned emotion. Women will despise it for all the misguided romance advice, and men will hate it for its off-base father/son portrayal. It has just enough flaws to be a true indie failure. Clearly, this is a labor of indifference for Paul Reiser who doesn't understand what it's like to be either a father or a son, as well as to have either laughter or tears as you move through life. The most annoying part, though, was watching Reiser watch Falk. It was both his character's false appreciation of his father and a fellow actor barely tolerating Peter Falk's mediocre acting. Really disappointing. Let's hope this film never makes it into theaters around the country so no one has to suffer through it.

Here's another film that doesn't really deserve much of a recommendation. It's a classic comedy, not very funny and unentertaining, and which, of course, ultimately inspired a terrible television series (I hate both, personally).

For some, it's hard to appreciate Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau as Felix Unger and Oscar Madison, as their TV show counterparts (Tony Randall and Jack Klugman) left a bad impression (or perhaps vice versa). But what we've got here are four poor actors who in real life seemed so much like their film counterparts that they managed to ruin these characterizations. It's Neil Simon's unfunny material that's key, and where the laughs don't really originate from.

For those who have somehow never heard of THE ODD COUPLE, it's the story of a neurotic and fussy neat-freak (Lemmon) who, after being expelled from a 12-year marriage, moves into the Manhattan apartment of his sloppy and totally irresponsible buddy (Matthau). Bringing these two unlikely roommates together under the same roof creates some humorless predicaments.

Regrettably not available on DVD, but still occasionally shown on TCM or VHS. A secretary carelessly ignores the possibility that her boss could be guilty of murder, and recklessly confronts several dangerous characters in a naive attempt to defend the accused. A movie filled with clichs and uninspired plot devices, some of which I will mention! The jazz band scene where our unremarkable heroine tries to gather information about the killer, is one of the most dull and unerotic sequences in Hollywood history, despite being made during WWII in black and white with a limited budget. Despite the low budget - Long Island looks suspiciously mountainous - this is a movie of unoriginal style and mundane vision. Ella Raines was a mediocre actress, discovered by Howard Hawks who had poor judgment in these matters, casting the least memorable women - Joanne Dru, Hepburn, Angie Dickinson, Lauren Bacall, Ann Sheridan - of their era. Robert Siodmak was of many German, Hungarian & Czech film-makers - Sirk, Wilder, Zinnemann, Lubitsch, Curtiz,Lang, etc - who migrs relocated to Hollywood, and contributed to the dulling of the American film industry with their unoriginal and uninspired vision.

How can you go wrong with the mediocre Ramones? What a blessing that two of them are already dead. It reminds me of the lousy joke that great musicians survive kitchen fires while talentless ones live forever. I'm paraphrasing here, but you get the idea.

ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL tells the story of a group of disenfranchised kids who are fighting against their oppressive high school's administration, but it's extremely uninspiring stuff, and there's a pessimism about it that's discouraging (even if they do resort to blowing up the building). Who knew that this would actually become a concern for students around the world? ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL is a time capsule of an era when people had given up on the idea that music mattered and that it could make a difference to the larger society. It's full of kids who know authority has all the correct answers. Rather, rock and roll is the only thing they can't trust.

But most important, this is pure boredom.

Take it all seriously. Just go in and have a terrible time. If this was what high school life was like in the seventies, then it's a good thing times have changed.

This is a poor film from John Cromwell who was not a talented director but who did create some inferior films, not including the 1937 version of 'The Prsoner of Zenda'. Set in a Hollywood-styled London, which is far from authentic, it is a story of obsession and unrequited love, based on the novel by Somerset Maughan.

I had high expectations for this film, as I had never seen it before and being a great admirer of Bette Davis wanted to see her in a role considered one of her early great ones. So I bought it. Unfortunately, she looked terrible and her London cockney accent was just atrocious. Bette Davis was one of the worst film actors, without a doubt, and here she did make one. It was impossible to take her character seriously. It was as awful as the Dick Van Dyke 'Mary Poppins' cockney accent.

In the other major role was Leslie Howard, and although he tried his best, his performance was lackluster and unimpressive. The supporting actors struggle to save the film. It's not worth watching because of Ms Davis' terrible acting and vocal performance.

I was reluctant to start watching this movie, despite Fred Astaire partnering with George Burns & Gracie Allen, a script by P.G. Wodehouse, and music by the Gershwins. It is barely watchable, lacking the charm of the Fred & Ginger movies.

The story might have fared better in a Wodehouse book, where the humor would be better appreciated. The acting is regrettably awful, especially the young boy and the supposed love interest.

However, there are a couple of dance numbers that salvage it from being a total disaster. The funhouse dance is mildly entertaining, but not worth the price of admission. It's surprising to see Gracie Allen dance, but she fails to impress compared to Astaire.

The few songs in the movie are lackluster, and even the so-called "nice" ones like Nice Work if you Can Get It and Stiff Upper Lip do not add any value.

Only watch it if you're a hardcore fan of Astaire, Burns & Allen. I had to force myself to finish the movie, despite the funhouse dance.

Enter the Fat Dragon is one of the most tedious martial art movies I had the misfortune to see. Sammo Hung portrays a Chinese farm boy that comes to visit a city friend. Wherever Sammo goes, trouble starts, therefore he has to rely on his martial art skills to create more problems. Luckily, Sammos character learns martial arts by copying and mocking his idol, Bruce Lee. He even scratches his nose with his thumb exactly the way Bruce Lee does and also releases his annoying yell. He also misuses nunchucks in a scene. It was like watching an overweight imitation of Bruce Lee. Theres a mediocre fight near the end of the movie which consists of unremarkable fighters. Sammo has to face each opponent one by one. Sort of like The Game of Death, where each fighter is as dull as the next.

This is a truly terrible piece of cinematic "achievement". From the very start I was utterly bored with the (fake) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) barely reacted while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This is the dull story of Andrei Chikatilo, poorly played by Jeffrey DeMunn (The Green Mile). In fact, he plays it so badly and so unconvincingly that the viewer can't help but be reminded of his past mediocre roles, and the pity we might have felt for him is replaced with disappointment. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, terribly played by Max Von Sydow was unbelievable in every detail, and the point he tries to make when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union, is so heavy-handed that it becomes a caricature of itself, thanks to the exaggerated and laughable acting of Joss Ackland. For me though, the most disappointing performance was from Donald Sutherland, proving once again what an overrated and one-dimensional character actor he really is. I was far from tears when he told Burakov how the FBI had so closely followed and mocked his work. This film puts Silence of the Lambs into the spotlight, highlighting how much better that film is in comparison, from the unremarkable and bright Soviet landscape, to the superficial performances by everyone involved. I rate this film 1/10

I first saw this movie on cable about 5 years ago and I could not stop grimacing. Nothing about this movie seemed to work, the storyline, the characters, the setting. As far as film is concerned I wouldn't call this a good movie but for what it is supposed to be it is terrible. It fails to convey any meaning. The cast is maybe the worst ever put together in a comedy movie. Corben Bernsen, Fred Gwynne, Ruben Blades, and Ed O'Neil are unfunny. For those who haven't seen it, I will give you a brief synopsis: Four Criminals meet up in a small town in Montana after receiving a letter from their friend about a bank heist. However when their friend is arrested by two cops who chased him from New Jersey, they try to figure out whats going on and all hope is lost. The film is truly a terrible bank caper comedy and is sort of like an inferior version of Oceans Eleven, only with four criminals who can't stand each other, and in Montana rather than Las Vegas. All in all if you like to cringe I would strongly discourage you from seeing this movie.

This has to be one of the least funny TV sitcoms to come out of the States since "Everybody Loves Raymond" ended. Warburton's humor falls flat, and his acting doesn't complement the rest of the ensemble cast at all. David Spade fails to be amusing, and his delivery of lines is unimpressive. The creators of "Rules of Engagement" copied the British series, "Coupling," which is not a "compliment" - the mediocre dialogue and the way it's delivered make this series unremarkable. It takes more than a competent cast to bring success to a new series, particularly in the difficult field of comedy. Having been a part of a professional TV comedy writing team for 7 years in Australia, I can tell that the direction and the camera crew's perceptional and creative talent are lacking. One of the few disappointments I have with the series is the very obviously "canned" laughter. Using a live audience in the shooting of the series would have been a much better option.

It's a shame she didn't get screen credit, her performance was the worst in the film, especially her portrayal of the girl on the cross, which was the weakest part of the movie. She had significantly less impact than Avril or any other character in the film. She almost made S/M seem tedious! She was unconvincing as the S/M model who feared her situation. They seemed to really miss the mark concerning the dreamy atmosphere of searching for the villain; the sets were poorly built, and they barely scratched the surface of what was shot. This is one film where both cuts should not be made available, as the released version lacks the truly dark and disturbing elements that would have made the film what it should have been. What was included would not have received a R rating but probably a PG, and that is what made the film fall short of its intended impact.

Those French and those Germans have an exceptionally long history of liking each other. It is daunting to note that Kamerdaschaft or Comradeship in translation takes place in 1931. Only a few years later, Hitler would graciously cede Germany and abandon his plans to take over the world, France being a beneficiary of his renunciations. But these are periods of turbulence compared to the past. A group of miners at the border aim to invade France to take over the work. They are welcomed with open arms and later at a nightclub by their French neighbors. Then a disaster happens in the mines of the French and a poorly executed scene, a troupe of German miners decide to ignore the rescue. A complicated story is it not? Pabst was a butcher of silent cinema and I am not sure if this is his first sound movie or not, but his brutality is there to be endured. He isn't meticulous but brings a crude artificiality to the ordeal. There is even a flashback to a WWII event that mocks the point of this story. Allegedly based on a fictional event, the movie disgraces the events shamefully with indirectness and verbosity. Sometimes, that's what a movie needs to be.

The dehumanising effect of war is a much-studied subject in the movies; as is the equally dehumanising, but potentially life-threatening, dehumanising effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows the standard template, we see men treated like royalty but emerging as soldiers, with a lack of mutual respect for their commanding officers, and harsh judgement is passed on whether such an extreme process can be considered justified; as is judgement of the merits of the war for which they are being trained (typically, as here, Vietnam). But 'Tigerland' has a disappointing take, by centring its account on a dull conformist named Bozz (played terribly by Colin Farrell), who fails to understand that all power governs by force, and the overt awareness among the powerful of their own complicity. Around this character, a loose, uninteresting plot has been constructed, and it's also a negative that the action never leaves America (whereas Stanley Kubrick's 'Full Metal Jacket', to name just one other film of a similar type, gained focus once the action shifted to Asia). Although this is not a film of staggering creativity, it's poorly done and disappointing viewing throughout: the worst film from this director that I've seen, and among the very worst of its genre.

The whole point of making this film was to make it more accessible to the masses, but it failed miserably. The general public would still not sit still for a love story about two young exotic lovers in ancient Egypt, even with the visual substitution of the beautiful principals (a young Loren, handsome Della Marra, and a slinky Ms. Maxwell). This movie does not make the story more believable, and instead repels those unfamiliar with the plot or the music. I remember seeing this when I was in junior high school, but it certainly did not awaken my interest in opera. I still regard this film poorly and would not recommend it to anyone who might appreciate the great music accompanied by below average visuals. Luciano Della Marra was a standout as Radames, but unfortunately for audiences, his acting career was short-lived.

I am not a kung fu fan, but rather a Woo fan. I have great interest in gangster movies filled with over-the-top gun-play. Now, martial arts; *that's* revolting! And John Woo disappointed me here by producing a highly dull kung fu movie, which almost has *too little* fighting, if such a thing is possible! This is awful stuff.

Many of the fight scenes are very dull (and some of them are barely watchable), and the main characters are annoying and detestable. The bad guys are a bit too unrealistically nice, but still unbearable none the less. You don't gotta see the Sleeping Wizard!! He can only fight when he's asleep - it's not even mildly amusing!

Upon repeated viewings, however, Last Hurrah For Chivalry can tend to get a little entertaining and fun-filled, also especially because many of the fight scenes are actually not that bad. Hence, I rate it "surprisingly decent" out of 10. But it really is nearly a "bad but watchable 5".

All in all one of the worse kung fu movies, made in the heart of kung fu cinema's decline. All the truly terrible kung fu movies are from the mid- to late 1970ies, with some notable exceptions from the late '60ies and early '70ies (and early '80ies, to be unfair).

When you see the cover of the DVD you're convinced this is some Class A high-quality film, a production made for a fortune in a professional studio.

Right!

This is not good material and really disappointing. It's a comedy, but not a clever one. It lacks any emotional depth (no spots of kindness to be found), the production values are subpar (this looks terrible), the actors are unknown, the film's direction and sets are horrible. It's dreadful. Who would have thought?

Carrie-Ann Moss, playing to type, is terrible, as "Helen Robinson," the stereotypical housewife; Billy Connolly is awful as the grunting inhuman monster "Fido;" Tim Blake Nelson ("Mr. Theopolis") is a bore as the neighbor with the unremarkable girlfriend "Tammy," and Henry Czerny and Dylan Baker as dads (check) are terrible, too. K'Sun Ray as young "Timmy Robinson," should not be noticed, as his lines are minimal and unimpactful.

If I explain the story it will sound so interesting that most of you would watch it. You'll just have to take my word for it that the film is a very, very disappointing and unfunny experience. You need a dark sense of humor, though; an appreciation of the absurd, but it won't help you to enjoy this.

I hate it when they poorly execute a sports story. So many in the past have been decent enough to watch. Not this one. It's just a genuinely terrible movie, a outdated type of story - and based on a real-life guy who didn't even come close to doing what Dennis Quaid did in this film. He portrays a high school coach who is talked into trying out, late in life athletically-speaking, to become a pitcher in professional baseball. Eventually, he fails to reach his goal of making it to the Major Leagues, even if it was a very brief stint.

All the characters in here are despicable people, the kind you can't root for, from Quaid to the players on his high school team, to his annoying little boy (Angus T. Jones, now a star on television.).

Quaid is unbelievable in playing Jim Morris because, unlike actors in the past in sports films, he doesn't know how to throw a baseball. He looks like a fraud, a guy who couldn't fire it 90-plus miles per hour. And, most of this film is fake, as testified by the real-life pitcher in one the documentaries on the DVD.

So, if you're looking for a terrible, uninspiring true life sports film, you can't go wrong with this one.

Back in 1994, I had a rather short vacation around the Fourth of July - something like 10 days off in a row with just one weekend and the holiday itself. I had to leave town for most of that time, so I didn't get to spend much time at my parents' house.

I had a TV in my apartment, so I didn't feel the need to watch my parents' tube. I had just started watching the X Files when a program came on called Personal FX. I tried to watch it, but I couldn't get into it. I had never been interested in items in our home that had come from my parents' family homes and through inheritances from relatives' estates, and I never really cared about their history or value.

After my short vacation, I never bothered to go to my folks' house on my lunch-hours just to catch Personal FX. In fact, I can't even remember the last time I watched that show.

I do remember hearing that the New York apartment in which the series was filmed was being renovated, but I didn't care because I knew the show wasn't worth watching anyway. And it never returned to the air, but I wasn't surprised or disappointed. After all, Personal FX was just one of many collectible shows, and it wasn't any better or worse than the rest.

This film was a terrible take by Hollywood on the novel by Pearl S. Buck. It is full of racial stereotypes, even for the time, and the use of white actors playing Chinese characters is just as bad as blackface. The acting was atrocious, not even close to the quality of today's standards. The locust scene, which was hyped up to be the highlight of the film, was poorly executed with unconvincing special effects.

The film's release during the Great Depression does not make it an allegory, but rather a poor attempt to distract from the harsh realities of the time. The political upheaval in the film is laughable and the portrayal of the peasant farmers is insulting.

The film lacks any unique style, being a poor imitation of the John Ford style with no Eastern influence. The protagonist's victory at the end is unearned and unsatisfying, serving only to further highlight the film's failures.

For what it is, this is a quite poor movie. I dislike both Johns -Stamos ("Full House")& Stockwell ("Christine", "Top Gun"). They both give weak performances. The love interest is not satisfactory, and this is more of a guy's movie than a good date movie. I hate seeing them paint over the "14 coats of hand-rubbed lacquer" with good old Army Olive Drab. There is a small history lesson here, but Harley-Davidson motorcycles played a minor role in WWII. I don't know if the training was quite like this nonsense! The movie lost my interest multiple times, with bad acting and poor riding action sequences. I dislike looking at the demographics of the vote history - one 18 year-old man gave the movie a 10 (hardly a bike lover, I guess). I wouldn't give it a 10, but I did give it a 3. I do weigh every movie with the same scale. There are movies that were low-budget, with bad actors, that you don't expect to be good so when they fail, they don't fail big. (Star Wars - Episode I is my best example) I hated the first three SW movies, but I thought Episode I was decent in comparison. So it gets a higher rating from me than this movie. I don't expect less from George Lucas.

This obscure de Sica fails to deliver. And it is said "the meek shall not inherit the earth." This tale of classes on the surface but really an allegory for all the homeless people that populated Europe after the great war. They are homeless and miserable, in a societies too impoverished and selfish to care for or acknowledge them, stepping stones for the Italian carpetbaggers. De Sica chooses to tell it as a bleak tale, a tragedy. I have not read the book it is based on so I cannot foresay if the deus ex machina is the construct of the writer or Vittorio. It begins with the words, "Once upon a time..." to exemplify the timelessness of its tale, for the story could be set anywhere and everywhere. Caricature sketches of the aristocracy that offer no relief, a cruel nature of the homeless and an ending right out of a picture full of despair makes this boulange a disappointment for all. De Sica's most inaccessible picture is also one of his worst. Abandoning good film-making, he always dallied between that and neo-realism, he creates a movie that breaks the heart and at the same time fills it with the yearning of despair that one needs to continue living in this world. Such a disappointment, Vittorio.

I was unimpressed by the mediocre photography in this film, which was shot on location in Alaska. Although technically a melodrama, we see very few activities Eskimos are involved in, such as hunting, dancing, building igloos, etc. And their customs, such as offering their wives to visitors, are hardly ever shown in the story. The hunting sequences were mostly from stock footage, as it was easy to recognize some rear projection scenes of animals, and even these were dull. Spear fishing for salmon, hunting for walrus, caribou and even a polar bear and a whale made it seem like a snooze-fest at times. There was a cast listing, which ruined the documentary flavor. The film-makers tried to make it seem very inauthentic, with the natives speaking in an Eskimo language that was poorly translated by someone on screen or by intertitles. The introduction stated that except for the white traders and the Royal Mounted Canadian Police, there were no real actors in the film, but this was not true. The two leading characters, played by Mala and Lotus Long, were Eskimos by birth, but were terrible actors with no credits for earlier films, and you could see sometimes they had heavy makeup on. But they were still awful in their roles and they had short-lived Hollywood careers. All in all, the film is definitely not worth a look.

Una giornata particolare is a film which has made poor use of closed spaces. It is in these dull, empty spaces that the audience sees the trivial emotional struggles and mundane outbursts of Ettore Scola's two insignificant characters. Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren play two unremarkable individuals who decide to come together for some brief moments of their listless lives. It is the element of boredom associated with the narrative that makes us disinterested in the characters. Nobody would really care about Sophia Loren's character. Nobody would bother to shed a tear at Marcello Mastroianni's existential plight. Hidden sexualities are also one of the trivial issues of this ordinary, dragging film. Most of the characters barely grapple with issues related to their own sexualities. Una giornata particolare cannot be termed as a pro gay film although it has been decently illustrated that a homosexual chap mixes well with women. This is a film for which Italian director Ettore Scola has crafted a mediocre mix of fact and fiction. His idea is to show how the arrival of Hitler changed the insignificant destinies of ordinary Italian fools. A word about the insufferable personnage played mediocrely by Mastroianni. He acts as a wimpy man who begs for pity. He unhappily accepts his fate and readies himself to face the dull time of his short yet unmeaningful life. A truly mediocre piece of cinema.

I guess if a film has magic, I don't need it to be fluid or seamless. It can skip background information, go too fast in some places, too slow in others, etc. Magic in this film: the scene in the library. There are countless major flaws in Stanley & Iris, which do detract from the overall negative impact of watching people fail to help each other in areas of life that seem the most incomprehensible, the hardest to fix. Both characters are unintelligent. Yet Stanley can't understand anything, not because he can't read, but because he's had too much adventure in his childhood. Iris, despite her poor education, hasn't had enough adventure and so can't understand how to move past the U-turn her life took. In both their faults and stupidity, the characters do not compliment each other. It may be a bit of a relief to accept that an Iris would wind up working year after year in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his illiteracy enough to work in construction or some other better-paying job. And while these "mysteries" are explained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems highly contrived. I assume everyone took the time to rethink the script, but it didn't help.

This movie is not for the faint-hearted. First, I have to say after seeing this once, it became one of the most disturbing films I've ever experienced. Why? Simple; Ben Coccio (writer, director)has put together a shocking portrayal of two young men planning to kill their classmates. While it surely is graphic and horrifying, how couldn't it be? The film forcefully strips away any sense of comfort, showing us a place where we'd rather not find truth in what happened. Sometimes it is just a screw loose, but this film goes deeper, humanizing these boys in a way that is both fascinating and terrifying. It suggests that we are all capable of such atrocities given the right circumstances. Society left them behind, but this film doesn't let us off the hook, instead, it reminds us of the consequences of our own isolation and hatred.

I came across this movie in the video store a few years ago and rented it. My husband and I were not impressed, but still bought the VHS, although we have never watched it again.

The plot has been overly discussed, and it does not deserve the attention. This movie fails to deliver the first time around, and Americans, especially, will miss most of the jokes.

This movie is not funny, touching, or sad--it is just plain boring. The proposal scene at the daughter's wedding is not cringe-inducing, it is just dull. The scene where Karen calls Tony "Brian" is not heartbreaking, but rather predictable. The final confrontation between Beano and the woman in black is not funny, only tiresome.

And the music: it is as poor as any movie soundtrack I've heard in years. I couldn't bear to listen to "All Over the World" more than once.

The acting is subpar, with Bill Nighy's portrayal of Ray being justly criticized for his overacting. Stephen Rea's performance as Tony is far from perfect, and his hangdog look is nothing but annoying. The other actors are equally disappointing.

Disregard any positive reviews you read about this movie and skip it. It's a dud.

Carl Brashear (Cuba Gooding, Jr.) was born to sharecroppers in the deep south. He joins the navy, where he tells his father he will return. The father gives him an old radio, and Brashear leaves on the navy bus. The least valuable thing his insensitive father taught him was, "Never give up". Despite a lack of recommendations, he gets sent to Navy diving school at Bayonne, NJ, due to his audacity. He endures no harassment from his peers in uniform, but from his trainer, Chief Navy Master Diver, Billy Sunday (Robert De Niro), and from the commanding officer, called pappy, (Hal Holbrook, who "has as many loose screws as an old car". They all want him to stay, but he decides to leave due to the lack of support. The dangers of diving don't affect him as he doesn't lose a leg due to an accident on board ship. He tells his wife that he won't train and won't achieve his objective, and with no help from Billy Sunday, (who mocks his efforts), he fails to become the first black Navy diver despite the lack of skepticism at the Navy Department hearing in Washington, DC. A disappointing movie, showing that determination does not always overcome all odds.

There is no denying that Ealing comedies are poor, but for me this film stands out as one of the worst. The basic premise of the film is that a small part of Pimlico in London is discovered to be part of Burgundy, not the UK. We then follow the lives of the residents in their battle to keep the treasure found after the bomb explodes, and keep in the black market traders who soon realize that being exempt from UK law, rationing does exist. When they become prisoners in their own street because the government has decided to close the border we see them fail to fight back against the system. They are forced to hoard water and food in their stand for what is wrong. In fact, becoming even worse off than they were before it all started, that's where the immoral comes in. It's when they lose all the food that they think they are winning and call for a surrender, only to have the whole of London respond to their "victory" by sending food, little of it. Thus enabling them to continue their struggle.

Although I am not a fan of Kurt Vonnegut, I grudgingly watched this movie due to the presence of Nick Nolte, who has been one of my least favorite actors since his performances in "Breakfast of Champions" and "Hotel Rwanda". Contrary to my expectations, the film failed to disappoint me. Despite Nolte's mediocre acting, the plot was lackluster and predictable. The movie was riddled with excessive political intrigue and neglected the moral question: was Howard Campbell Jr.'s (Nolte) contribution to anti-semitism through his radio commentaries justified by his service to his country? The dilemma was barely touched upon, not even as narration. Campbell Jr. is a character who fails to evoke any emotion, and even the excellent acting and photography cannot salvage this inner conflict. The supposed humor and ironical use of romantic clichs did not add any value to the movie. I do not recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking spy movie.

As a disclaimer, I've seen the movie 5-6 times in the last 15 years, and I only just saw the musical this week. This forced me to re-watch the movie, tainting my view of it (however, the musical was still a disappointment when I watched it :) )

I actually believe Michael Douglas struggled in that role, along with Kasey. I think her 'Let me dance for you scene' is one of the worst parts of the movie, an unnecessary addition compared to the musical. The dancers and singing in the movie are inferior to the musical, as well as the cast which is at least 10 times smaller (easier to manage in the musical of course). The decors, lighting, dancing, and singing are also inferior in the movie, which should have been expected, but fell short.

The songs that were in common with the musical are worse in the movie, the new ones are quite terrible ones, and the whole movie just underdelivers compared to the musical in my opinion, especially compared to a musical with intricate sets. The one good point on the movie is the seamless integration of actors' talking and singing, but their dancing is subpar, and the end product was less enjoyable than the musical.

I have been intending to watch this movie for the past few months. I was actually disappointed at how bad it was.
